In 2011 I was diagnosed with systemic lupus which causes chronic debilitating pain as well as low energy levels. 
By the end of 2012 I was taking so many different types of medications administered by doctors 
( from plaquenil to prednisone to soma)  that I could no longer hold a job. 
I was no longer active and my life basically came to a standstill.  By 2014 I started looking into more herbal type alternatives to meds. 
This is where I stumbled onto kratom. Besides the effectiveness on chronic pain it allows me to be energetic and lead a normal life. 
I experienced NO bad side effects. It is virtually impossible to overdose and it does not get you high contrary to popular belief.  I will continue using kratom once I am legally able to do so. I cannot even contemplate going back to those dark years in constant pain. 
I plead with you to please do proper research and recognize the healing abilities of this herb.. 
You can regulate usage to 18 years and over but please do not make this plant illegal. 
Thank you for reviewing..

documents.commentText:
My name is Laura Seltzer and I am 35 years old and live in Salem, Oregon. I am a Case Management Coordinator at the Department of Human Services. I have used kratom for Restless Legs Syndrome and Irritable Bowel Syndrome since 2008. Before finding kratom I tried every prescription drug that is on the market for both of my chronic conditions. Every single medicine I tried was ineffective, or the side effects were so bad I was unable to continue treatment. In fact, the anti-Parkinson's medication my doctor prescribed for my Restless Legs Syndrome actually made my symptoms worse (this is a common side effect called "augmentation").

I am a law-abiding citizen (I had to pass a background check to be employed at my current job), and I respect the law greatly, and one of the main reasons I chose kratom (like the hundreds of other people I have talked to in the kratom community), is because it is LEGAL, and because it does not alter who I am as a person like some of the medications I used to take for my chronic health conditions. It does not impair me, or alter my thinking or behavior, or affect my judgment. 

The DEA may think it's as simple as choosing not to use kratom anymore if the ban goes into effect. But I have two serious chronic illnesses that have been successfully managed with kratom for more than 8 years now. I can sleep at night and not crash my car when I'm driving because a Restless Legs Syndrome flare up happens all of a sudden, because my Restless Legs Syndrome is helped greatly by kratom. I can focus at work because my Restless Legs Syndrome symptoms are under control. I can not wake up every morning sick to my stomach and throw up every day before I go to work, because my Irritable Bowel Syndrome disappears completely when I take kratom. 

Most kratom users respect the law like I do, and are not criminals. We don't abuse illegal drugs, most of us don't even drink alcohol or use other prescription drugs. We are moral, ethical people by and large. But we also have chronic illnesses that require treatment, and kratom is the only thing we have found that works. It has given us our lives back. That is why you will find such passion among us. We are literally fighting for our lives.

documents.commentText:
Dear everybody whom this may concern,

At the age of 16 years old, I was diagnosed with a rare life altering renal disease. As a result, I suffered daily from extreme spasms and kidney pain. The daily agony did not stop there. About once every couple weeks up to once a week, I developed kidney stones that placed me in a state of misery. I was first prescribed hydrocodone, then oxycodone, then hydromorphone, and before I knew I was physically dependent to the point of no clear return to my normal self. Before I was put on narcotics, I was a successful and happy teenager, student, boyfriend, and genuine friend to many. 

But then my life took a dark turn.

I began missing school, failing classes, I lost my girlfriend of 2 years who loved me very much before my addiction took control. My situation describes many thousands if not millions of people who never thought they would have become addicted. I began to understand why people stole, robbed, and committed destructive acts to get these medications. Finding opiate narcotics wasn't to get high, it was only to not feel like the absolute worst flu you've ever had in your life. I describe a withdrawal as being thrown out in a tundra blizzard naked while wet from being in a previously warm and relaxing bath, then kicked while vomiting and feeling like you are being stabbed by a thousand needles all over your body at random.

This all changed when I found out about Mitragyna Speciosa, or 'Kratom'. The feeling of Kratom is not like taking a Vicodin or Percocet. It's more along the intensity lines of coffee yet it's effects can be either mildly stimulating or calming. It does not make you feel high, extremely euphoric, or manic. However it can tremendously help with mild pain such as migraines, joint pain, and muscular aches as well as prevent diarrhea and has been found to possess anti inflammatory and antioxidant properties. Kratom saved my life. I truly and wholeheartedly know that. Also you cannot overdose from it, Kratom is so natural and kind that it will force you to vomit if you even attempt to abuse it.

Here's the most important thing to consider: IF Kratom is made illegal, recovering opiate addicts including heroin users that are tapering down with Kratom just to ease withdrawals, the US WILL not may , but WILL see an ever increasing spike in prescription drug and heroin overdoses and deaths because that will be the only thing left for them to turn to. I pray to God this natural plant does not become illegal for the sake of thousands of lives. An addict could be anyone. Do you want your spouse, sibling, child, family member, friend, to turn back to the harmful drugs instead of easing cravings and withdrawal with a natural plant that grows from the ground out of a seed created by God? It's here for a reason, and I believe to save us from the evil substances in a sense.

documents.commentText: Kratom offered my sister a workable path away from use of more dangerous opiods. She has been clean for 5 years now, and everyone in my family believes her outcome would have been dramatically different (i.e. death from overdose) were it not for this plant. If nothing else, the active ingredients in Kratom should be studied for their combination of their agonist action on certain opioid receptors, while still producing a punitive effect (i.e. not just binding to mu-opioid receptors en masse).  It is my understanding that this makes overdose less likely than other opioid agonists, and chronic overuse somewhat unpleasant (from the research I've done - at least much, much less "high" producing than any other scheduled opioid).  The active constituents of Kratom should not be scheduled; even if leaving it unscheduled only saves a few hundred lives from opioid overdose, that is still more good than harm, by a huge margin.  It is my understanding that only a few individuals have died after ingesting Kratom, and these cases involved polydrug abuse.

documents.commentText:
I am 32 years old and did have an opiate addiction since I was 16.   Due to a back injury I was prescribed pain medication.  Gradually my tolerance increased and I began abusing pain medication and benzos due to depression. This was an on and off cycle of abuse for years.  Finally around, 2012, I found this product, Kratom.  I used it to taper off of my opiate and benzo use.   Now I only have to occasionally use it to manage my pain and anxiety.  At no time did I even feel that I NEEDED kratom as a craving.  

ALL IN ALL, Kratom saved my life.  I can understand putting a possible limit on the amount one can buy, but KRATOM SAVED MY LIFE.  I can use it occasionally to manage my back pain and don't have to be resort to  going to the doctor and being prescribed a worse addictive drug like Lortab or Percocet to manage my pain.  

I would not be alive today if it was not for Kratom.  I consider it as a dietary supplement that  can be used as an alternative to American over-prescribing doctors .  I have read the so-called horror stories online, but have never heard of anyone dying from Kratom itself.  
My doctor when I was on Methadone at one point was the one who recommended that I try Kratom to taper off opiates and benzos.  
I also suffer severe anxiety and Kratom, along with therapy, has helped me get through that.
I have a cousin who takes it occasionally to assist with his anxiety.  
I firmly believe that problems come when people mix substances together, but Kratom taken alone has done nothing but help me and I never have felt a withdrawal effect from it.  I still keep it on hand for painful injuries or panic attacks, which is a whole other story, because I also was addicted to benzos during my entire use due to anxiety and veing overly prescribed controlled meds by my doctor then suddenly getting cut off.  With proper use of kratom helps with that as well.
Bottom line, I would be DEAD if I had not found Kratom.  I now have a full life with a family and I would really feel bad for anyone with chronic pain or anxiety that uses Kratom and suddenly can no longer take it.
PAIN CLINICS ARE WHAT NEED TO BE TARGETED. IF KRATOM GOES ILLEGAL THEN PEOPLE WILL RESORT TO PAIN CLINICS AND BE PRESCRIBED EXTREMELY ADDICTIVE NARCOTICS OR OTHER CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES, OR OTHER ILLEGAL DRUGS AND THAT THOUGHT IS JUST TERRIFYING.

I truly hope that my story helps make a difference to keep Kratom a legal product.

I have used kratom for 5 years to help with my chronic back and neck pain. I have experienced many benefits and no ill effects and I implore the DEA to reconsider its classification of kratom as a schedule 1 controlled substance. I am a 25 year old male in Minnesota and I work as a server at a nursing home during the day and play violin while not working. The physical demands of my work and my music all day every day has gradually taken a toll on my body. The kratom plant has given me an alternative pain management strategy that has kept me off of potentially dangerous pharmaceuticals like hydrocodone or morphine, and it is an alternative that carries a lower risk of overdose. 
     
     Kratom has absolutely changed my life for the better, I can move around freely and play my music to the best of my ability, without the limitations of muscle and neck pain; without it kratom it hard for me to perform at my highest level as I have diagnosed tendonitis. At the nursing home kratom allows me to move around and give the elderly the quick service they deserve. Additionally my girlfriend also uses kratom for anxiety, and has stated that it has helped her more than anything her Dr. has ever prescribed her, without the serious risks of addiction to benzodiazapenes. 

     Taking this plant away will harm millions of Americans, including the grandparents, law enforcement officials, and veterans; some of the very people that fought for the freedoms the DEA is now poised to take away from them. The elderly who do not want to be sluggish and dulled from opiates, cancer patients, chronic pain patients, and sufferers of anxiety and depression who need a cheaper and safer way of dealing with their issues. Kratom presents a very good alternative to fueling the opioid epidemic that is plaguing our nation. Please do not criminalize users of kratom and block their access to the many benefits of this benign plant.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern, 

I'm an active member of society who's worked in education for over fifteen years. In 2001, I was struggling with lower back pain and after many visits to the doctor, I learned that I had sacroiliac lower back pain. I was given opioid pain meds and like most, I found that it not only relived physical pain, but emotional pain as well. After a divorce a few years later, I began abusing the prescription drugs and soon found I needed them just to get out of bed. A few years later I decided to get off of pain meds and was fortunate to find krantom to be listed as one of the most safe and effective ways to ease the withdrawal. 

If krantom was not available I would have continued abusing pain meds or found alternative drugs. Trust me, krantom does not get you high the same way true opioid does. What it does is offer a safe "stepping stool" for those not ready or unable to afford the monthly visit to the clinic. And why should there only be one method for getting off opioids? If ingesting a plant offers relief for those suffering why take that away? You're only forcing them to obtain it illegally (like we need more people suffering from addiction in our jails), or have them find other drugs to ease the pain. 

If we've learned anything from the past (alcohol prohibition), it's that banning a substance that offers relief doesn't work. Isn't it better to learn from the plant and figure out why it's so effective?
Enough is enough.

documents.commentText:
While I appreciate the stay on the Kratom ban, I wanted to reiterate my displeasure with any further push toward the ban. 

1) in a time when opium use is skyrocketing, banning Kratom is asinine. Kratom is effective and safe when used to help addicts, and it's far safer for pain relief, preventing addiction in the first place. 

2) it's in heavy use by our wounded troops who served our country overseas, and banning it would leave them no choice but to use illegally, or turn to opioids, which is no choice at all. That's just un-American. 

3) Kratom is safe, and used by millions. No action was needed in the first place, unless you're only consideration is the pockets of the pharmaceutical companies. 

4) more and more people understand the war on drugs is a failure, and adding an herb that can be used to LESSEN the use of opioids is not just wrong, it's double wrong: you're growing the list of banned substances unnecessarily, and you're forcing people to turn to the use of far more harmful substances. 

5) millions of people will become criminals overnight. 

Please listen to what the nation wants and needs, and act accordingly.

documents.commentText:
See attached file(s)
As an "educated" healthcare professional, I have safely and responsibly consumed kratom powder for approximately eight years. I began to seek alternative, herbal options when I was experiencing anxiety which started when I was laid off from a home care agency due to the company closing. Kratom, for me, has been a safe, effective alternative to the xanax my doctor initially prescribed me. After taking only a few xanax to help my brain be quiet at night, I realized how horrid it made me feel. I felt groggy, drugged, lethargic. I couldn't go to work in the mornings when I took xanax. I talked with my doctor and discontinued xanax. I have purchased kratom through natural herb shops, the only places locally I could find pure kratom. I do not want to take kratom laced with other medications or altered in any way. In my experience, when I have taken kratom, I have slept through the night. Occasionally, if it wears off and I wake up during the night, I will take another small dose to help me go back to sleep. I am consistently able to manage my anxiety and have restful sleep at night to help me function in surgery the next day. After years of quietly taking kratom, mainly because no one knew what it was, I began to see many other friends and family struggle with pain, inflammation or anxiety. Those who were homeopathically inclined, I have suggested kratom to and on a few occasions, offered a sample of mine. All have become regular consumers. All have found what I experienced, no side effects to speak of and effective at improving their pain from arthritis, joint pain from tendon and ligament damage and reduced anxiety. I will be devastated if this wonderful plant is banned. In the past few months, I made the attached graphic to compare kratom, which is fairly obscure, and turmeric, a well-known spice commonly in your spice drawer. I have also attached the sources for my research. Please hear our cries, our pleading with our government. We the people are asking you, please, with respect, do not ban kratom. If you find, after hearing all of our voices, that there should be some type of regulations put in place to protect the public, let those be that kratom be sold to people who are adults. Restrict kratom from being sold in a blend with other substances that could be part of the misguided targeting of kratom, so kratom can only be available as the safe, natural plant hundreds of thousands of Americans responsibly consume everyday. Thank you for your allowing us due diligence and a public comment period.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.  
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

I would like to share my story with everyone. Most who know me know I have suffered with severe pain for 3/4 of my life. I recently came across some information on a plant called Kratom. I spent four months researching everything about it. When you live with severe chronic pain the way I do, you are willing to try anything and everything to help you feel as close to "normal" as possible! For many years I have felt like nothing more than a pincushion with a delusional hope of being even half the person I used to be. With appointment after appointment. Scan after scan. Surgery after surgery (including a spinal neurostimulator that is supposed to help reduce my pain and doesn't). Injection after injection. Pill after pill. So many, I have become quite a pharmacist without a degree! Not that I've ever asked to be one or even had a liking for pills of any kind! I've never been the type to enjoy taking anything at all. I remember a time I would struggle with a headache just to avoid taking an asprin. Little did I know... taking pills would be my life. The unpleasant side effects of Pharmaceuticals are something you can only understand if you've been subjected to them as your only option to relief for an extended period of time.. all of which are horrible! Little did I know that my suffering could have ended a long time ago by drinking an all natural tea called Kratom. I am on month two of my Kratom journey and my body hasn't felt this good in a very very long time! When taking my regular meds, if you were to ask me what my pain level is my answer normally is anywhere from a seven to plus ten! However, here I am on month two of Kratom tea and my pain level has been NO more than a four....which to me is almost INVISIBLE! I have taken zero meds and have experienced NO withdrawls from dropping them either!!! UNBELIEVABLE to think that I am finally going to get the life I worked so hard for back! I honestly never thought I would as my condition (DDD) only gets worse and worse. I am still in shock and my emotions have been a complete Rollercoaster. I have been stuck between crying because I can't believe how great I feel...and unspeakable anger because our society allows people like me to suffer while making big Pharma richer and richer with no real pain relief for patients! Anger because I finally found something Natural that ACTUALLY WORKS and the FDA/DEA wants to take it away from us!!! Something so harmless in comparison to all the pharmaceuticals ever prescribed to me. The same pharmacuticals that have destroyed my stomach, intestines, gallbladder and liver to name a few. I have gone to extents that NO person should have to....just to find one single ounce of relief so that I can just be a mom, a woman... who can wash her own dishes, make dinner and care for her children. My journey has been unbelievably dark and full of more suffering than any one person should ever be forced to endure! Pain takes over my entire mind, body and soul regardless of how hard I fight! It changes you and makes you feel lost and worthless because you aren't the same person anymore. Many, many times I have contemplated my existence and lost any and all hope for a functional future. Suicide has danced through my mind way too often over the years. I honestly never thought I could feel "ok" again until Kratom gave me my life back! 
I am begging you to leave Kratom alone! Us chronic pain patients have had things shoved down our throats for years...let us drink our tea in peace. Please do not ban this harmless plant. Please focus your attention on the things that are killing people not the things actually helping to FIX the problem Big Pharma has created. #IAMKRATOM #KeepKratomLegal #KratomSavesLives #PLANTSNOTPILLS #PlantsNotPoison

documents.commentText:
I am a board certified practicing anesthesiologist.  I also have 2 years experience performing bench neurophysiology research at a US medical school.  Currently I practice in an area with extensive opiate abuse and THC abuse.  I find the pharmacological potential of cannabinoids very intriguing, but extremely limited by lack of research.  The endogenous cannabinoid system suggests an immense potential for pain treatment without the opiate induced respiratory depression that kills thousands of people.  I suspect that much of our lack of understanding of pain, pain treatment, and the endogenous THC system is a sad consequence of THC being listed as schedule 1 drug, and the effect this has had on reduced research. 

Honestly, I do not know much about Mitragynine and 7- Hydroxymitragynine.  But I know there is an absolute crisis of tragic deaths in the USA from opiate induced apnea (we have had a handful locally, each one devastating to the families and our community).  We need to know more about treating pain without respiratory depression.  Most likely, there is no fundamental reason for the two to be linked.  When we know more, we likely will be able to treat pain better than with opiates, and without killing thousands of people.  I want to know more about this drug, and the pain pathways through which it works.  Scheduling this drug category 1 will shut down the learning process, and lock in our ignorance.  How many deaths might it also lock in?  I am not for encouraging or enabling recreational drug use, but please do not impair our learning, innovation, and medical progress, especially where it is needed so desperately.  Thank you.

documents.commentText:
My name is Alex and i'm a 28 year old lawyer in Florida. I am against the DEA listing kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances. I was very disappointed that the DEA attempted to list Kratom as a schedule 1 substance without providing a comment period before, breaking the long established custom to review all comments before making such an impactful decision on all the kratom users country wide. I began using kratom while in law school as a substitute for more dangerous drugs such as adderall and vyvanse, which I see get abused so often in law school and other demanding graduate schools. This tea provided me with the focus and concentration to graduate from law school and pass the Florida Bar exam on my first attempt. It has also been a great help in productivity in my career and other endeavors. This substance is much less harmful than alcohol and many other substances not included on the schedule 1 classification. Kratom is a relative of the coffee plant, and to me is no less harmful as such. It provides similar effects of coffee and is no more addicting that its relative plant.

I've examined a kratom study from the 50's, which was the longest study that I could find, which studied the Philippine migrant farmers who were regular users. I am unable to locate the study currently, but it should be examined before any final rulings are made. To briefly summarize, the study showed that the drug was as addictive as coffee, but did not provide any negative health issues although it had the same addictive qualities as coffee. 

In conclusion, I think listing kratom as a schedule 1 substance would do a disservice to many people as kratom is a safe and useful plant. It has pain relieving qualities, cognitive improving qualities, and the ability to help people suffering from drug addictions, such as heroine. I implore you to keep kratom legal and help the many law abiding citizens have a natural remedy to aid them in their lives.

My name is Myles Cooney and I am a 26 year old technology professional living in the Chicago area. I work in a technical sales role at a software technology company. I would like to write a few words about the positive effects of Kratom.

Throughout my life I have experienced mild anxiety and at times a lack of focus. I started taking Kratom on and off about 1.5 years ago to combat some of these negative cognitive effects I had been dealing with. Since starting to use Kratom I have garnered the focus to  accomplish following:

-Start public speaking and performing stand up comedy. Since I have let go of the taking of kratom and can get on stage without any use of it. However, it helped me get started.

But so can caffeine, nicotine and marijuana, which is increasingly becoming considered harmless and made legal in many states in the USA.

documents.commentText:
I am a clinical psychologist who has worked in drug/alcohol treatment settings for the past 9 years. I am writing to urge the DEA to deschedule kratom so that it can resume its over-the-counter status.  I support descheduling kratom for the following reasons:

1. Preventing further harms caused by the War on Drugs:  Over the past 4 decades, we've tried to control drug use in this country by criminalizing use. This has led to spending billions of dollars annually on what is now seen by many analysts as a failed US policy.  Furthermore, a recent report by the John Hopkins-Lancet Commission has concluded that policies stemming from the War on Drugs have increased the death rates of opiate users. http://www.jhsph.edu/news/news-releases/2016/leading-global-health-commission-calls-for-reform-of-drug-policies-worldwide.html  Kratom is a substance used by many former opiate users as a harm-reduction measure.  What justifies us scheduling this substance if it means more dollars spent on enforcement and criminalization in the spirit of what is now considered by many to be a failed US policy? What further harms will occur to current kratom users if they are driven back to using opiates? Scheduling kratom is a step in the wrong direction.

2. The harms of kratom are relatively low:  Kratom has been used as a natural supplement for centuries.  Toxicity is a rare event.  Abuse potential is low.  During this time, the clinics I've worked for have treated thousands of patients for various addictions, and I've only heard of 2 patients ever entering my program for problems related to kratom.  Both times it was complicated by a history of opiate dependence. For comparison, this number is close to the number of patients I've heard of in my clinic that presented with an "addiction" to ibuprofin. The DEA should research not only the base rate of harms associated with kratom use, but whether these harms outweigh the true and significant harms of criminalizing the use of this substance. I strongly believe the harms of criminalization far exceed the harms of kratom use. These harms include driving users to the illicit kratom market; driving users to return to using a more harmful substance: opiates; the harms caused by arrest, incarceration, and probation; and cost to the taxpayers for enforcement.

As a treatment provider who cares about the wellness and safety of drug users, I strongly urge you to deschedule kratom.  The relatively few harms caused by substance do not outweigh the significant harms that will result from scheduling this substance.

documents.commentText:
I respectfully request that you not proceed with your ban on Kratom for the following reasons:

-Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
- If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
- Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
- Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
- Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
- Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: My name is Chris. I'm 51, and a professional painter.  I do not think the DEA should ban Kratom because I believe it helps so many people who suffer with chronic pain, such as myself.  4 years ago I was diagnosed with Degenerative Disk Disease, Osteoarthritis, and Spondylitis in my low spine.  My condition is very painful. In an effort to put off surgery, I kept my weight down, exercised, had regular visits with a reputable chiropractor, as well as regular use of opiate painkillers prescribed by my doctor.  All of this is well documented in my medical records.  One year ago, I had to have ALIF surgery on my L5-S1 vertebrae because my condition worsened and the pain became intolerable.  6 months after surgery, I was able to stop taking the handful of daily opiate painkillers.  I experienced withdraw for a terrible week when I stopped.  After several good months, a new pain presented in my back that radiates down my legs.  While the surgery was considered successful, it appears that my L4-L5 disk has become a painful issue I now have to manage.  I was warned by my surgeon that this may happen.  I'm currently in as much pain as before my surgery and do NOT want to start taking the painkillers that gave me awful side affects and terrible withdraw.  I started Kratom last May.  I read about it online while researching 'opiate painkiller alternatives' and it manages my daily pain bringing it to a tolerable level.  I experience no side effects. I stop taking Kratom from time to time to gauge my pain.  I have never experienced withdraw as I did with hydrocodone.  The Kratom plant has given me relief and I'm able to perform the physical labor my job requires that I otherwise would not be able to do.  Please do not ban this wonderful plant.  Kratom helps me and I do NOT wish to return to addicting opiate painkillers and all their side-affects.  I may have to live with chronic pain the rest of my life, but Kratom has improved the quality of my life.

documents.commentText:
My wife and I have been augmenting our medicine regimen with Kratom for a year and a half. Other than speeding tickets, neither of us has broken the law in our 25 years of marriage. It was on a long car trip to a family member's memorial service that my son suggested my wife and I give Kratom a try for our pain incurred during the drive. Before that time neither of us heard of Kratom.

My wife suffers from Rheumatoid Arthritis, Diabetes, Spinal Stenosis, ADD and Depression. I am a disabled veteran with Degenerative Disk Disease, Chronic Back Pain and Major Depression. My wife will not write a comment for fear of retaliation that is why I'm including her story. And hers, frankly, is more incredible than mine. You see all her doctors are amazed that she's not on disability herself.

On this car trip we looked online for a place near our hotel that sold Kratom. A store was located about 30 minutes away so we went there. The Kratom helped both my wife and my pain levels go down significantly. It also helped me feel more at ease around family we hadn't seen in years. This is how our introduction to Kratom began. 

My wife takes 21 medications and had to clear taking Kratom with her various doctors. None of which had a problem with the addition of Kratom to her regimen. She is prescribed narcotics, but they are very tight with them and she refuses to take them at work. She augments her non-narcotic pain medication with Kratom so it doesn't effect here ability to do her job.

I add Kratom to my medication regimen on particularly painful days when my medication doesn't quite do the trick. I'm not prescribed narcotics because I've had problems with them in the past and do I not want to have problems with them in the future. Kratom also helps me in the social areas where I have such a deficiency. Some people drink alcohol, well I do not. Kratom takes the edge off enough for me to relax when I need to be in a social setting. I loath social settings. 

Kratom is a plant that we take to help with our pain and  help with anxiety. It is not a miracle, nor is it a drug. This controversy that has been created will change nothing in our eyes. When you outlaw it you will have created thousands of criminals out of ordinary taxpaying US citizens.

documents.commentText:
Hello. Thank you for withdrawing the emergency intent to classify kratom as a Schedule I substance. I am a 50 year old nurse (for 25 yrs), a mom and grandma. I also drink kratom tea for chronic pain. As I read through these comments, a couple of things stand out to me. 

First, an overwhelming majority of commentors have had positive effects from kratom, and in most cases, it greatly improved their quality of life in one way or another. For some, it actually played a part in saving lives, whether for those that are battling addiction, or are struggling with depression, or PTSD. For others, kratom allows people to live and enjoy their lives without debilitating chronic pain, or having to take opioid pain medications, which come with their own problems.

Secondly, and most importantly, each and every person commenting is a real person. These are real people, living real lives, with real struggles that kratom helps them manage. They are not numbers, or a statistic. Each and every person's life is important, just like yours and mine are. 

The average kratom user is over 30 years of age. Many are grandparents, like myself. Most are law abiding, productive citizens. They are going to work every day, paying taxes, raising their families, enjoying life with loved ones. These are not people looking to get high (because kratom does not get someone high). Many are actually using kratom to keep them AWAY from harmful, addictive substances. If kratom use produced a high, it would be much more popular than it is with people looking for that effect. It is not a substance of abuse. Kratom simply lifts mood and helps to provide an overall sense of well-being, making it useful for those dealing with depression. It is also useful to aid in opiate withdrawals. It helps keep cravings at bay, thus helping an addict work on recovery and sustain sobriety. Of course, being sober allows a recovering addict to reclaim their life and be a positive member of their community. It keeps them out of jail, out of the court system, out of the ER. All of those are costs to taxpayers. Most of all, kratom helps to keep people out of the grave from OD. 

Kratom also helps in alleviating pain, allowing people with chronic pain to actually live a quality life. Waking up every day in terrible pain, unable to move, has a profound effect on how someone lives. They can't enjoy life like everyone else. They are limited at what they can do, and if they hurt every day, they can't really do much at all. You can't understand how hard it is to live with pain, until you have to. This simple natural tea can give someone their life back. Why take that away, from even one person, let alone thousands (possibly millions)? By prohibiting or limiting access to this plant, you will be causing a severe negative impact on people's lives, real people. This will hurt individual people, and their familes. It will effect more people than you may realize. Please, reconsider taking away a natural remedy from good people that just want to live their lives the best they can. As you read these comments, understand that these are real lives you will be effecting. By allowing kratom to remain legal and accessible to adults, you will be helping people, and literally helping to save lives. Thank you.

I am an adult male in my mid-30s. I am married with 2 children and a third on the way. I am a certified teacher finishing a Masters degree in the spring in Education Administration. For about a year, I have been using kratom as an anxiolytic treatment to minimize the social anxiety I experience in large crowds and at social events. I have tried other pharmaceutical treatments such as Buspirone and Xanax with little success. Kratom, on the other hand, has been extremely useful in managing my anxiety in these situations. 
I began looking into treatments for my social anxiety once I became aware that social drinking had become a default self-medication strategy to address my social anxiety. For obvious reasons, I found alcohol to be a problematic approach to managing my anxiety because of the significant side-effects it presents, such as impaired motor function, impaired judgment, long term health risks, and withdrawal (hangover) effects. In my experience, kratom does not impair my motor function or judgment, nor does it carry any significant withdrawal effects. I would go so far as to say that kratom has been instrumental in helping me avoid alcohol use as a self-medicating strategy for social anxiety, and thus it has opened up for me the many benefits of an alcohol-free lifestyle. 
In my experience, kratom does not have a high risk for abuse. In the last year, I have had no trouble limiting my use to no more than once or twice a week, and I have gone months at a time without using it. 
Prohibiting my access to this substance would significantly lower the quality of life I've experienced while using it. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Hello my name is Calvin. I'm 22 years old and I professionally cook in restaurants in NYC. I have been using kratom on a daily basis for a little less than a year now, and I would like to share some of the impact that this plant has had on my day to day life. I work long irregular hours on my feet, in a very hot environment, doing work that is prone to injury and heavy lifting. I believe. People deal with physically taxing activities differently. I'm not someone who will take the vicodin that my doctor recommended for my knee, as painkillers have caused a dependency problem for me in the past. Im not someone who takes Advil or Tylenol. From injuries to the physical ache of waking early in the morning after working late the night before, kratom gives me a truly unique relief of pain and physical peace that I deserve as a human being. 

Secondly, I don't drink coffee. I've had problems with insomnia since high school. And while I do enjoy the energy and increased output from coffee, I will definitely have trouble sleeping early that night. A fast strain does the same thing as coffee for me, without the catch. Moreover, slow strains will help me sleep. Finally, there are mental, psychological effects from kratom. They are by no means debilitating, nor would I even describe it as a "high". But through exploring strains, I have seen the motivation of coffee, even enough to exercise at times. I've seen the creative calmness of strong Asian teas, relief of stress and anxiety, even stage fright. As a young man, there is a storm going on in my mind, between subsiding hormones and the first responsibilities  of adulthood. As a person, I'll always pursue the chance to "make the noise stop". What about people that don't drink alcohol, or live in states that still outlaw marijuana? I believe that people should at least be free to at least pursue natural means to relieve whatever ailments life may have.

I will conclude by urging the DEA to step up in regulation of quality. I believe that extracts should be regulated more carefully. As a daily kratom user, I steer clear of any extracts. I believe they are much more likely to cause issues with dependency. I believe that kratom in alot of headshops or tobacco shops (the ones that are packaged like they came from the same company that makes k-2) is often low quality and sometimes dangerous. I have only used high quality product from a trusted vendor. I take controlled doses at controlled intervals and have a 7 day rotation of strains (mainly to prevent an increase in tolerance). In doing so, I have taken kratom every day for many months now, with only good things to say. Kratom is not dangerous. Starbucks gives me more negative side effects than kratom. Many people that properly use kratom see that, and it creates a justified frustration that the DEA have priorities that don't have much to do with protecting the people. But I believe that the issue was a lack of understanding for the plant and the people who use it. I do hope you see kratom from a different perspective this time around. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

I am writing to you today to voice my concern over the potential scheduling of Kratom.

I am a responsible Kratom user for about 2 years now, and currently use it a few times per day to help me deal with my difficult mental and physical symptoms.  During my life I have been diagnosted with depression, PTSD, and fybromyalgia.  Kratom tea helps me deal with the symptoms of these conditions, and scheduling it would absolutely have a detrimental effect on my personal well being.

Throughout my life I have been through the full cycle of doctors, psychiatrists, psychologists, and have been prescribed all types of medication for depression and pain management.  The side effects of these medications are too extreme for me to be comfortable with taking them on a regular basis, and being physically or chemically dependent on them is not a solution that I consider rational or sustainable.  Since taking Kratom I have stopped drinking alcohol completely, and have not had the desire to use any synthetic drugs at all.

Even if I was not a personal user, I would be opposed to it being scheduled.  It is currently and for the foreseeable future legal in Canada and Mexico.  Scheduling it here will just create another black market for the cartels in Mexico, and organized crime like the Hells Angels in Canada.  The hundreds of thousands of people that use Kratom responsibly will still want it even if it becomes restricted.  If the leaf itself is difficult to import, the home made extract business will thrive in its place.  This type of product would just serve to further deregulate what is currently a healthy, self-regulating market.

Scheduling it will also effectively cancel current research on it.  If it can be shown to be effective at treating drug addiction or depression, it could save countless lives across the country.  It is definitely worth looking into considering there is a growing opioid epidemic.  Banning a healthy and safe alternative to classic opioid medications is only going to lead to more deaths and abuse of synthetic opioids, which nobody wants.

Thank you for reading my thoughts.

documents.commentText: I stumbled across kratom in online forums about a year ago. I'd never heard of it, but the more I researched, the more I thought I'd give it a shot to see if it could help my wife and I out. After a bit more research on the effects and to find a reputable vendor, I bought some. It only took about a month and a half to two months, once we found a helpful vendor and a brief learning curve on making capsules, and habit changes and slow tapering-- we were able to finally kick a nearly six year painkiller addiction. I don't know many people who have had a problem with painkillers or opiates that do not want to kick the habit. It's a difficult thing to do, and I can honestly say that kratom was a godsend in that it finally  allowed us to get over that hump that we'd been trying for years to do without the agony of cold turkey withdrawals which, having tried before, left me nearly suicidal and in agony for days until I finally gave in and found more pills. Having gone through that, I can understand why some people are so desperate to try and move on to things like heroin. Luckily I we never reached that point and I'm not sure we could have done so without the support of others and the help of kratom. We've since stopped using kratom, except occasionally when I need a bit of relief from  a nagging lower back problem...but not more than a cup of tea or a couple of capsules. It can be addictive- but I assure you it is nothing like the stranglehold of opiate painkillers had on us for so many years. Please consider something a little less severe than a schedule I classification. There is immense benefit to this product if used responsibly,  in a manner similar to wine, or other regulated but legal products.  Thank you!  -RSB,   Leesville, LA

documents.commentText:
TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN, my wife is totally disabled and wheelchair-bound due to advanced rheumatoid arthritis. I was diagnosed in 2012 with multiple sclerosis. We moved from Michigan to North Carolina two years ago to be near family for health support.
Until recently my wife was on massive amounts of opiate painkillers to deal with her situation. After years on these opiates she wished to break free, she was able to do so through the use of kratom. 
MS creates terrible muscle spasms which at times are unbearable for me.  Doctors have prescribed various muscle relaxers (Baclofen, Tizanidine) none of which have proven effective. The only thing that has helped me is kratom.
Ive become aware that the DEA is calling for the banning of kratom and it greatly concerns me. Without the availability of kratom our quality of life will be greatly affected. At present, it is the only substance that allows me to any relief from intense muscle spasms and gives me the ability to get any sleep. I simply cant imagine what life would be without kratom.
While I can appreciate the concern to protect those who may attempt to use this plant for recreational purposes, I fail to see how banning kratom would prove effective. Those who wish to use it illicitly will still find ways to get it and those of us who are law-biding and truly benefit from it will be irreparably harmed.
Given that there is no solid evidence that kratom use causes any real danger, what is the reason for the knee jerk reaction to quickly deny it to everyone?
Though it may have been found in the systems of some who have died from drug overdoses, there is no proof that kratom was a contributing factor. Such abusers where likely prone to take anything to elicit a high in the hopes that it would work.
It appears senseless to out rightly ban something like kratom that has no proven health concern when a substance like tobacco, which is proven to kill, remains freely available.
There must be some way to address this problem, if indeed it is a problem, without the whole-sale ban of a product that provides much needed relief to those of us already plagued with a horrible disease.
Please, PLEASE be our advocate in this matter!

Charles Nicholls

documents.commentText:
Two years ago, I was diagnosed with Ulcerative Colitis (UC). For those unaware, this disease is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes frequent (8-12x/day), bloody diarrhea during flares. This disease exists in broader class known as Inflammatory Bowel Diseases and includes Crohn's Disease.  

I started taking the current state-of-the-art medications (5-ASA derivitives) to control this illness, but unfortunately, I am one of those who suffer from a severe side effect, known as recurrent pericarditis (inflammation of the lining of the heart). To counter this, I was prescribed immuno-suppressants and corticosteroids. Both of these drugs are known for not only their severe risks and side-effects, but also for the strong resistance that the body develops for them.   

It was around this time that I found Kratom. Kratom is an interesting herb for Ulcerative Colitis and other IBD diseases because, at least for me, it performs two miracles: it helps to prevent diarrhea during flares and it has incredible anti-inflammatory effects.   Many of the immediate effects of Kratom wear off within 6-10 hours  the effects that people talk about, like the mood-lift. The anti-inflammatory effects, however, appear to linger for 3-4 days! 

Along with some other alternative treatments, I believe Kratom has dramatically reduced the inflammation caused by this disease. I have been using Kratom for almost two years, twice weekly, using roughly 6 grams of dried leaf material made into a tea.  

A kratom ban would be a great loss for myself, and I assume many others, who use this herb for this purpose. Those who have this condition are contraindicated from using typical anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen and Naproxen, as these NSAIDs worsen our diseases by causing ulcerations and bleeding within the GI tract. We dont have a lot of other options!

I'm able to get out of bed every day and go live life.  I can't say enough how much this simple, safe plant has improved my way of life.

While I've been using kratom, I've recommended it to several of my friends and family members, and they have all started using it, too-- some of them have even given up using opioids for their pain since they no longer feel like they need to take them.  Others have even been able to stop abusing pills/heroin or living stuck on suboxone.  It's truly miraculous. My city is completely overrun by this heroin epidemic...I've had many friends die as a direct result of opiate overdose...to see, not just one or two, but several friends/acquaintances stop taking these harmful drugs and be able to get their lives together is one of the happiest things I have ever witnessed.  This plant is miraculous.  I've seen studies that suggest it's nearly impossible for people to abuse kratom, and even if they manage to take such a large quantity, they won't die like they would on heroin.  This plant absolutely needs to be researched! Our country has been completely swallowed by opiates/opioids, and right here we have a possible solution that isn't jsut as harmful and addictive as the medicines we currently use!  Not one person I know that has been put onto a methadone/suboxone treatment has managed to get clean successfully. They spend thousands of dollars (or taxpayer dollars) taking these drugs (which, quite frankly, are even worse than heroin itself in some ways) for years before finally going back out and getting high again.  Each and every one of them falls off the bandwagon-- they can't afford to continue treatment, they aren't tapered off correctly by shady doctors....but with kratom, that just doesn't happen.  It's incredibly cheap. It's very effective. It doesn't get them high.  They don't get cravings and they don't go back out into the streets looking to score.

I'm sorry that I can't provide anything more than anecdotal evidence for my claims.  However, seeing the people around me that I love being able to be freed from their awful addictions is all the evidence I'll ever need to believe that kratom needs to be researched thoroughly and made widely available.  The DEA wants to place it under Schedule I, making research extremely difficult.  Even if it is only for a few years, how many more people will die in the streets that could have been saved for $50? The DEA should be protecting people from things like heroin and promoting kratom as a way to get back on your feet and get your life together.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

November 23, 2016

Kratom contains small amounts of the opioid alkaloids mitrogynine and 7-hydroxymitrogynine that could be placed on Schedule 1; however, the kratom leaf is not equivalent to pure opioid alkaloids. We do not know, as you state, that these are the main psychoactive constituents of kratom. In order for this statement to be correct, all components of kratom must be isolated and tested separately and in various combinations; which has not been done.  The leaf contains a unique mixture of compounds that could have important medical value for the following reasons:

1)	The leaf appears to have efficacy in ameliorating opioid withdrawal. There must be other compounds in the leaf, not yet identified, that participate in this effect otherwise we could simply mix the 2 opioids therein and produce the same effects on withdrawal. This has never been done.
2)	A neuroscience colleague of mine takes the leaf for depression; a very difficult disease to manage. Studies are needed to explore the role of the leaf in depression as it is unlikely that the alkaloids themselves are producing this effect.
3)	I have an anxiety disorder and tried the leaf to see if it would be of value for me. While I did get a brief feeling of euphoria for a minute or two on the first dose, this has not happened again. It does not appear to control my primary disorder. 
4)	However, what I did find is that it has appetite suppressant value for me. I am at risk for type II diabetes and I take it on weekends when I am most likely to overeat. Along with dietary restrictions of simple sugars and light exercise, in just a month I lost 13 pounds and will take the leaf to drop another 10 pounds so that I am no longer classified obese which is the primary risk factor for type II diabetes.

It is my view that the small amount of alkaloids in kratom leafs do not explain the above noted and many other medically relevant effects reported by others. I should note that my usage level does not produce addiction as I have no withdrawal symptoms when I stop using it. 

I request that you hold off scheduling the alkaloids in kratom for at least 3-5 years so that the full benefits of this leaf can be explored both by users and the scientific community. There appear to be unidentified compounds beyond the opioids that are either independently active or interact with the small amounts of these specific alkaloids to produce valuable mental affects. I for one will soon no longer be at risk for diabetes; a disease that is having devastating effects in the U.K. according to current reports.

documents.commentText:
My name is Galen. I'm a 30 year old, 4th grade school teacher. Since attending middle school, I have lacked the energy to be engaged with other people. There seemed to be a million thoughts in my head, and yet my action-taking-tank was always on E. 
Through my family's financial help, I made it through a great college, graduating with Dean's List honors every semester. I fit right into the nose-to-the-grindstone lifestyle that getting good grades required of me. Following my graduation, I was left feeling more "blah" and seemed prevented from moving toward fulfilling relationships, even casual friendships. This was felt as a tension throughout my face and body,  the kind after you've been trying to hold back from breaking down and crying. Tears seemed to prick at my eyes just from passing too close to strangers. 
Fast forward to today. I am lucid as if I've just woken from my best sleep. I've come back from my school. I wake up at 4AM these days, even on weekends. I start with a 20 minute meditation, before waking up with a cold shower. I'm then caught between renovating the bottom floor of my house to rent on AirBnB, and preparing lesson plans for my beloved students. 
I would not have gotten here without Kratom. I was deeply discouraged with my overwhelming tension with other humans. I read a book called "The Mood Cure" and thereafter began taking amino acids that started helping for a short while. I then searched the internet for long term paths to living comfortably in my own skin. I began taking Kratom after seeing its reviews for making people feel "like themselves" without feeling "high."
Taking Kratom for the first few times allowed me to go grocery shopping wearing my real face without a scowl. It was like discovering that I had been walking through my whole life with thumbtacks in my shoes that I could now simply remove whenever I needed. 
Knowing that I can use Kratom in a pinch, I feel nourished, and safe, and eager to connect with my students, new friends, and even go on dates. Monday through Friday I experience hundreds of children wriggle by me, and I'm smiling just thinking about them now. I'm getting shout-outs for caring about the students from parents and admin. This is an attribute that I never would have possessed before discovering there was a supplement that existed like Kratom.
Kratom clears my mind and makes the daily routine become infused with a sense of curiosity. I've gone months without it. It does not make me want more. It's just great knowing that if I am facing a class of 20 special-needs children, I can be myself no matter what (literally) hits me. It is like a 4 hour sense of "I can't wait to try what comes next!" 
I've shared this Kratom with other teachers. The responses have been so positive, always something along the lines of, "I've had anxiety all my life. I really felt like this helped." 
Please consider allowing Kratom to continue retaining its current status. The banning of Kratom would be a wound to so many of us moving forward in wellness.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...
Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.
Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6
About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...
The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?
As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText: I see the pictures of parents overdosed with their kids in the back of the car or in the shopping cart; horrifying photos of people and their families being destroyed by opioid addiction.  Kratom offers a way to help with pain so that people don't get addicted in the first place.  It also eases withdrawal from other drugs so that people can recover and go back to a normal life.  Studies show that kratom's side-effects are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are minor when compared to those of opioid withdrawal.  Banning kratom  will doom thousands, perhaps millions, to suffering with pain or addiction and overdose. The costs to our society will be tremendous.  Please don't ban this drug.

documents.commentText:
I am presently working at a small retail establishment after spending 6 years on disability for depression. I found that kratom has been instrumental in me being able to rejoin the work force as this leaf of a tree has helped me immensely in dealing with not only my crippling depression and anxiety- but the associated fatigue and also by helping to alleviate the pain associated with a severe back injury I obtained in 2009; without the use of highly addictive, synthetic opiates. 

In fact I used to abuse opiates of all kinds- starting with those produced by big pharma and later heroin. But kratom has assisted me in maintaining my sobriety for almost 3 years now when no other treatment was successful. 

There's a lot of propaganda being spread around, things like 15 deaths associated with kratom in the last couple years. But these deaths were the result of poly-drug use and not a single one through the sole ingestion of kratom. In fact I can assure you that far MORE lives are saved through using this natural substance to rid themselves of their life-destroying addictions to opiates our own government helped to create. It is also claimed there is no known medical benefit when there is clear anecdotal there is, yet the DEA wants to schedule the active alkaloids before even allowing for any proper scientific inquiry in to the topic- something that will be impossible to do with Schedule I rating- this is complete and utter hypocrisy at it's worst.

Not to mention that the DEA is a government agency whom represent the will of the people and the people have clearly spoken here that they do not want this. 

In summary years of life destroying mental and physical ailments that I have suffered are, for the first time in my 30 years on this planet- able to be handled by me on a day to day basis because of an herb that's been used safely for millennia by native peoples of the south pacific. So please don't wantonly schedule something that has provided so much positive benefits to so many people, and yet will only cause increased pain and suffering, and for many death as they return to opiates, do to this blind decision made me politicians who are deeply out of touch with the common citizens of this country. 

For once, restore one's faith in government by doing the compassionate thing and not schedule this plant like you have scheduled so many other compounds that hold immense therapeutic value but are unusable due to the war on drugs and the human greed that drives it.

Hello just wanted to put my view out here, I was 24 when my back pain started off and on. By the age of 30 I was bed ridden for 3 months before my 3 level spinal fusion was approved by our insurance!  After the surgery I was put on oxycodone to deal with the recovery pain, after about a year on those meds it was over they had me hooked!!!!!!! Couldn't do anything without them. So 3 years later I continued on the meds because I still had pain but not as bad  as I thought . Then the downward spiral effect started to take place, I was constantly running out of meds and was looking to get more however I could, this went on for about 2 more years until I have had enough and started to look at options. About 2yrs ago I tried my first dose of kratom 1tsp of red premium bali mixed into some tea, and 45mins later is when I realized I am going to get my old life back!!!!!!!! I stopped the oxys that day and have never looked back!!! I am a father of 2 with a beautiful wife and I almost lost all of them, but thanks to this awesome plant I am back to work full time and a productive member of society! 

Sincerely,

Mike forga

documents.commentText:
To whom this may concern:

     I had been an opiate addict for roughly 8 years before I decided to try Kratom.  Numerous times over that 8 year period I had tried everything from methadone, suboxone, or cold turkey to get off the pills and continuously circled back around, eventually, back to opiates.  It's a miserable life and a miserable way to live but the power of that opiate addiction truly cannot be understood unless you yourself are in those shoes.  I see stories all the time about how bad the heroin problem is getting and about all the people dying or overdosing constantly because of the epidemic and it's a constant reminder to me that it could have been me in that latest article, dead from another overdose.  Just another statistic.  When you are on opiates though none of that matters to you because of the power the addiction brings.  And with it being such a miserable way to live you just tell yourself "if I die then maybe that's a good thing."  I think we both can agree that that's not a normal way of thinking and also is a tragedy that it's how most people who are under the grip of an opiate addiction feel.  

     Now like I said before I had tried everything before to get off opiates and just kept circling back to them like 90%+ of other opiate addicts.  I really believe there was a combination of things that would bring me back around, but what I realize today is that I had to be ready myself to quit first, but also that the medications such as Methadone and Suboxone made me feel horrible.  Plus all those medications did was switch habits for me and they were not any cheaper than opiates.  Every time I tried to get off of those medications the withdraws from those medications were even more unbearable so I would just go back to opiates again.  Now with Kratom I was skeptical that it was going to help me get off opiates but after trying everything else I really had nothing to lose.  Well that skepticism quickly turned into optimism, which then turned into life saving.  HOW I had never heard about Kratom before, for so many years, just befuddles me because of how effective it has been for me and as well as others I have read about.  I cannot stress to you enough about how much of a life saver it has been for me.  I have not taken any opiates for about 2 plus months and what's different about it this time is that I don't have an urge to seek out opiates and kratom has really made me feel like myself again.  I feel like a normal person again and feel like I can contribute to society again like I had always wanted to do.  Another thing is that the kratom does not give me some type of high where I want to take it all day everyday and is now my new monster.  I take it once a day, in the morning, and that's sufficient enough until the next day.  I have more energy now and am not lethargic like I was ALL the time with opiates.  My depression has gone down as well and I'm not having problems sleeping anymore like I had been since I started taking opiates.  

     So to whoever is reading this I urge you to please not only keep kratom legal and available, but to also have some studies done on kratom.  It just blows my mind that rehab centers across the country as well as doctors are not recommending kratom to opiate addicts to quit opiates.  I feel like there is so much more to learn about kratom and that everyone needs to be aware of how effective it can be for opiate addicts like myself and others.  There are way too many people dying in this country from the opiate epidemic and if we are going to be honest about it, the way that our doctors and rehab centers across the country are trying to fight this epidemic has been a losing effort.  Why are 90%+ addicts going back to opiates?  Obviously because the treatment methods being used today are having almost zero effect.  I feel like I really have a chance not only to stay off opiates but to actually live the life I always wanted to live and strived to live all because of kratom.  I've never felt that way since becoming addicted to opiates and I really feel like if kratom was banned I would never feel that way again.  Thanks you for your time.

I have struggled with being addicted to different things for the last 12 years. I had the most difficult time staying away from pills, heroin and meth especially. I would be clean for a little while, but always ended up relapsing. Since I've been taking Kratom, I have been able to stay clean for the past 9 months. I have also been able to maintain a positive attitude, have had steady employment and have had less anxiety and depression. Those are things that ultimately led me back to using in the past. Taking a little bit of Kratom in the morning and at night keeps me in a good state of mind. It also helps me get a little boost in the morning. I've never been so successful in all my life and I know Kratom plays a role in my motivation each day. Could I live without Kratom? If it is banned, I will have to..I don't feel I am dependant on it, but I do believe i owe it some credit for the way I live my life now. I would really hope this matter is closely looked at and banning it is reconsidered. Kratom not only helps me, but it helps others in my life who have depression, chronic pain, PTSD and substance abuse issues. Thank you again for giving this matter a public comment period and hearing our stories. 

Sincerely,

           Tiffany Monson

I had been on narcotic pain medication prior to my surgery in 2005 and 2 months post surgery.  I do not want to take addictive pain medication and searched for an alternative.  I researched Kratom and decided to give it a try.  I am glad I did.  It is a life changer.  I am able to control pain without narcotics and carry on an active Clinical Practice.

documents.commentText:
Hello,
I am writing to advise you that I am vehemently opposed to restricting kratom for adults. Kratom has supplemented my health so that I can perform my duties as a 49 year old mother of 4, wife, business owner and student. I am studying to become an aromatherapist and herbalist because I have experienced benefits derived from the plants and trees that God gave humanity. 

In the past decade, I have taken prescription medicine to prevent migraines (Propranolol), survive daily stressors (Celexa, 2 years) and relieve pain from sciatica, degenerative disc disease and severe spinal stenosis (Neurontin, Norco, Flexeril). I was having side effects like not being able to wake up in the morning and memory deficiencies (including not being able to recall basic words). I did have back surgery that took away pain radiating down my legs but gave me permanent nerve damage which is also painful. For many years, I visited my PCP, specialists, surgeons and followed their directions to a "T", taking the prescriptions as prescribed. I was still miserable. The prescriptions either didn't work (in which case my doctor would try another one that had the same results) or there were unwanted side effects. After much research, I found a product that contains butterbur, vitimin B and ginger to use as a migraine preventative. I found that by using this product, my migraines decreased by 90% which gave me part of my life back. I also found that a mixture of kratom, ginger, turmeric and cayenne pepper enhances my ability to move around and go about my productive day without the need for any of the medicines prescribed for my back issues. My memory has mostly returned and I no longer need at least nine hours of sleep. The changes I made, independent of the physicians I saw for 7 minutes a visit, have improved my life and productivity immensely. 

As an herbalist in training, I have learned that the multitude of components in plants, i.e. the whole plant, work together synergistically with other plants to bring our body back to it's natural, non diseased state, when taken appropriately.  There are usually a small number of components in a plant that can be proven to "work" in some action, but when they are separated and concentrated, they end up having side effects. We NEED the whole plant that includes ALL the components for it to be reasonably safe and effective for our wellness goals. Kratom is a tree that I have found safe for me, without unwanted side effects. I have been using it for 5+ years. I have an annual physical and blood test every year that confirms this. 

Please do not regulate nor schedule kratom for adult use! I have not been able to find any data that this God given tree has killed even a handful of people independent of other drugs. I'm just not seeing the danger that would warrant any type of scheduling. If addiction is a concern, why are cigarettes, alcohol and coffee available? I have not personally had any type of withdrawal symptoms when I didn't ingest kratom. Weaning off Neurontin was much more difficult. In my life, I can choose to have children, buy a gun or travel on every continent but I need permission to drink kratom tea? Is this still the United States of America; the land of the free?  If you want millions of kratom using adults to be productive and pay their taxes, leave kratom alone.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern, 
A few years ago, a dear friend of mine woke up to find she had no feeling in her legs. After rigorous testing, it was determined she had a disease called Transverse Mitalis, and possibly MS. She was told she may never walk again. The medicines her doctors put her on were not only addictive, but the side effects were so terrible that she could not function and be a mother to her 7 children. 
She did some research, and was able to find KRATOM - a very safe and effective natural supplement, which has been the only thing she can take to manage her chronic pain and allow her to function. 
Following this experience, I became a sales rep for a company that sales Kratom. In the three year I have worked for this company I have heard hundreds of stories about people effectively and safely using kratom to manage pain, stop seizures, help with migraines, relax muscles, and possibly the most compelling - to get off harmful addictions from prescription drugs.
Kratom attaches to the same receptors in the brain as opiates, giving a sense of relaxation and pain relief. However, unlike opiates, you cannot overdose on kratom, it is VERY mildly addictive (as opposed to opiates which are incredibly addictive), and there are no serious side effects. In fact, the biggest side effect is nausea - which is a blessing - because it works as a natural regulator. If you take too much kratom for your system, you will simply throw it up. 
I have NEVER heard a story of anyone overdosing, going to the hospital, or dying from kratom use alone (Following the DEA intent to ban I read some reports, but in each case there were other unsafe DRUGS - not herbal supplements - in their system). 
I am not a regular user of kratom, but have tried it and find it to be a safe and effect natural supplement.  I would like to add my voice to the millions of people who use it every day.  This is NOT a dangerous drug. A ban on kratom would cause more harm than good - forcing people to go back to legal yet far more addictive drugs, creating an underground market where anything could be labeled and sold under the kratom name, and I fear ultimately causing hundreds and possibly thousands of deaths. 
I'm asking the DEA to permanently reverse the ban on kratom. In a country where opiates and other prescription drug addictions are at an all-time high, kratom is NOT the problem, it is a solution to the problem.  
Sincerely, 
Emily

documents.commentText:
Greetings,
Kratom should not be banned, for the following reasons:

* Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

* If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

* Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

* Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

* Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

* Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Dear Honorable Citizens of The United States of America and To Whom It May Concern,

Thank you for providing the time and the means for providing my comments regarding Kratom.  I have used Kratom for several years now.  The role of Kratom in my life is of extraordinary importance to me.

During 1983, I began experience unusual agitation in the nerves and muscles of my legs.  It is very difficult to describe, but what I can tell you is that it is an insidious, torturous symptom that makes sleep impossible, and causes me great anxiety and agitation during the day.  Over time, this condition spread to my forearms.  I have worked closely with my physician of 40+ years, and we have yet to find anything that will stop and control the symptoms.  The condition does not have a name and has otherwise remained undiagnosed.

I was introduced to Kratom by a family member who also suffers from similar, random nerve/muscle attacks.  I began to experiment with commercially prepared Kratom strains from a U.S. company.  I prepared teas, tinctures and also tried a teaspoon of the powder with water.

After years of suffering from this quiet torture, I quickly found out that certain strains of Kratom are able to stop my horrible symptoms within 15-20 minutes!   This has been life changing for me.  The other benefit of Kratom as an alternative remedy is that it does not impact my judgment, motor skills or overall mood in any way.  It simply and powerfully mitigates my symptoms.

It is unimaginable to me that anyone would want me to return to a life of physical unrest, agitation and anxiety.  I am a good, productive and law abiding citizen who simply desires to maintain the excellent quality of life that I have because I have access to Kratom.

I would gladly discuss this with you in person, particularly to try to describe the symptoms of my condition without access to Kratom.  Please, please give careful consideration to my story and to the stories of the many other beneficiaries of the properties of Kratom.

Mark Winfield Poulton, age 61
