documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
I am firmly against the scheduling of Kratom.

I am not a drug user.  I am not trying to beat a heroine habit.  I'm a software engineer who suffers from chronic back pain.  I don't like to take acetaminophen because it's very bad for the liver, and I also hate to take ibuprofen because it gives me stomach aches.  A nurse friend of mine recommended that I try an herbal solution - kratom.  I rolled my eyes at the time because I assumed that a plant couldn't offer me any real pain relief.. otherwise I would have heard about it by now, right?  

I take two caplets in the morning and two after lunch, and my back pain is gone.  Incidentally, I also found that it was a more effective stimulant than coffee, which offers much more severe side effects.  I have been living caffeine and pain free since I discovered this supplement and I am truly floored by the idea that we are even considering a ban.

I had no idea that my government could reach into my cupboard and unceremoniously decide for me that I should have to live with liver damage, nausea, or back pain... because.. ?  I'm still not clear on the because part of all this.  Because it might act on the brain in similar ways to opiates?  Is this some horrific sin on its own, when it causes no demonstrable harm?  It was my understanding that the privilege of emergency scheduling was afforded to the DEA in order to combat the rapidly produced synthetic drugs that pose a clear and present danger to our public.  This is not happening right now... public opinion on kratom ranges from "What's that?" to "That literally changed/saved my life."  The number of deaths that are 'linked' to kratom is laughable to anyone with a college-level statistics class.  

I have done nothing wrong by availing myself of this natural form of pain relief.  You are not better than me because you use Advil instead... Or caffeine, for that matter.  The number of people killed by eating dishwasher detergent pods last year is much greater than the number (inconclusively) linked to kratom.  And hey ok.. folks are less likely to want to eat detergent pods so let's get away from the substance itself and talk about usage... You allow us to kill ourselves with alcohol and cigarettes, but you want to forbid us from the mild stimulant/pain reliever offered by kratom.  How in the world can you logically justify this ban?  

I am not a criminal.  Please don't make me one.

documents.commentText:
I am firmly opposed to the planned scheduling of kratom. i have used kratom for several years now for pain relief and have never experienced any negative side effects or anything that I would necessarily designate a characteristic of a recreational drug. It does not create a compulsive desire for consumption. I do not believe it has a high potential for addiction and in fact, has been shown through countless anecdotal reports to help people overcome not just opiate addictions, but also alcoholism.

documents.commentText:
I'm 42 years old, married with no children. I am active in my church and community. I have a 13-year daily practice of yoga and meditation. I am a multilingual editor and translator by day and harpist in hospice in the evenings. As you can imagine, both of those professions require a lot of mental and physical acuity - and working in palliative care also requires a tremendous amount of presence of spirit.
I have had tremendous boosts to my health and well-being since occasionally enjoying kratom for the past decade or so.  
I live with a number of autoimmune conditions for which medicine simply has no solutions. Kratom supports my health and energy and helps me to be the productive member of society that I am.
Kratom is not mind-altering. If it were, I wouldn't be able to ever use it. I need - and want - to be alert and present. It lifts the mood slightly, like coffee but without the jitters. In fact, it a relative of the coffee plant.  It could hardly be described as a drug - the effects are much closer to caffeine and nowhere near even as strong the legal herb kava kava. They do not come anywhere close to anything else in the Schedule 1 Category. This plant with hundreds of years of safe use in its native culture does not produce a "high" or euphoria; anyone looking to kratom for a high will be sorely disappointed. The fact that head shops market it deceptively is not a reason to deprive responsible and productive adults of its benefits.
Kratom is not an opioid - it is THOUGHT to act on opioid receptors - just like chocolate and cheese.
It's also not addictive, and as a former cigarette smoker who battled the addiction for a good seven years before I was finally able to quit all tobacco forever, I have personal knowledge and experience of what is and is not mentally and physically addictive.
There is absolutely no reason this supplement should be scheduled by the DEA. I am a law-abiding citizen who contributes to society and I can't imagine a peaceful person like me being put in jail for the occasional enjoyment of a tea leaf.

I would like to voice my opposition to the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. This would put Kratom, a plant helping

It would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown Kratom to be a safe and effective, regulated dietary ingredient that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose. Kratom is not a drug and is non-addictive.

I am an educated, responsible adult consumer of Kratom. This plant has given me my life back, safely, without risking addiction to dangerous, narcotic prescription pain medications, Anti-Depressants, addictive Anti-Anxiety medications and alcohol. I have not taken ANY pharmaceutical medications or alcohol since March of 2015, when I researched and discovered an amazing plant, Kratom. I quit taking the pharmaceutical medications and then (out of physical and mental desperation) began to self medicate with alcohol. Of course, this did nothing but make things worse and rendered me unable to function... just as the medications did. I eventually went back to the Doctor and got back on the medications... again. It became a vicious cycle... until I found Kratom. I got my life back! I am an active, productive, happy member of society and my family! My business is flourishing and my future has never been brighter!

Kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important medicinal uses and has changed my life. I fear that if Kratom, in it's organic, pure form, is taken away from those of us that depend on it's medicinal value, will only lead to more tragic deaths of victims of the opiate epidemic, maybe even my own. documents.commentText:
I am a 34 year old high functioning Financial Crimes Investigator working for a major bank while simultaneously serving as an Military Intelligence Officer (Reserve). I have 12 years military, with a deployment to Afghanistan 2009-2010. I am a father of 3 young children, am in excellent health and maintain a healthy diet while exercising 5 days per week. I've consumed Kratom daily for 6 years and it has helped my well being to the point I consider it life changing.
Prior to discovering Kratom, I was an alcoholic since my early 20s, made exponentially worse after returning from Afghanistan. My drinking stemmed from a crippling social anxiety that has plagued me since childhood. I was diagnosed with PTSD and depression by the VA and was prescribed several medications, which I often carelessly combined with alcohol. I worked in a meaningless job and my career prospects seemed very limited. When I discovered Kratom, I found it gave me a sense of well being, alertness and increased motivation. I didn't have the heavy urge to drink that I used to, as the well being, alertness and motivation gave me greater confidence in social situations. I drank much less, eventually limiting to 1 or 2 drinks at social functions and finally completely quitting alcohol in 2012. I have not had a drink since then. The motivation I found from Kratom also helped me to be a better employee and a better Officer. I found myself eager to take on more complex projects.
Kratom has helped me live to my full potential. It has not cured anything, I am still and alcoholic and always will be, as it is a disease. I still suffer from social anxiety, but my increased motivation and well being have made my social anxiety much more manageable. I still have PTSD and while it has improved over time, there are events from Afghanistan that will always haunt me. I no longer take medication for PTSD as I feel better and more clear-headed without them. The Kratom has not replaced these medications, but the positive benefits of Kratom have lead to a holistic sense of well being, including diet, exercise, increased focus (leading to greater satisfaction with work and other challenges) and a positive state of mind that has helped me overcome challenges without the aid of medication.
I maintain a very positive mood, strong work ethic and these have helped me immensely at home, at work and while serving. I will outline some of the accomplishments in my life since discovering Kratom to highlight the positive effects and underline the point that these would not be possible for a drug user or an alcoholic.
In my military career, I applied for a Commission as an Officer in the Intelligence Community, which is arguably the most competitive community in the US Military, outside of Special Operations. Not only did I receive a Commission, but I have been a model Officer, have held multiple leadership roles, have consistently been ranked above my peers and have been sought as counsel by many Senior Officers that far outrank me. Much of my work has been in the Counter Terrorism arena and I can say with confidence that I have made positive contributions to National Security. I am known as a top performer in a very elite community and my family and I are proud of my service and the great work I've done.
I made a civilian career change several years ago and I am not only a stronger provider for my family, with a great career and promising future, I truly love what I do. In my day job I write reports on suspicious financial activity, often stemming from potential criminal activity, including Terrorism, Human Trafficking, Narcotics and Fraud, which are used by Law Enforcement. I know with absolute certainty that my work has been helpful to Law Enforcement, including several high profile cases, and that work has been possible because of my increased focus, motivation and positive mood, all of which have been helped by Kratom. My work requires me to be sharp, focused and clear headed; these are attributes that would be difficult for an alcoholic or a drug user. While I can only truly speak of my own experience with Kratom, since 31AUG16, I have met thousands of others (including many fellow Veterans with stories similar to my own) who have benefitted from Kratom and I'm in awe of the high level of motivation, comraderie and general positive attitude of the entire Kratom community.
In addition to the aforementioned, I am a father of 3. I am extremely active in their lives and Kratom has helped immensely. Before discovering Kratom, when my alcoholism and its catastrophic effects had me at my darkest hour, I felt that if I did not make major changes, my only option might be to take my own life. Fortunately, I did make changes and those changes were helped immensely by the positive benefits of Kratom. This was before my children were born, so essentially, their lives got to begin because mine was able to continue. Kratom helps so many, please let it continue to do so.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to voice my opposition over the DEAs attempt to make kratom a schedule I substance.  I am not a kratom user at this time but as a person who regularly uses natural supplements I would like kratom to be a legal option for me in the future. I know people who use it or have used it in the past for pain relief.  They did not become addicted to kratom and did not suffer common side effects that would have come with either over the counter or prescription pain medications.
I am writing about kratom as a person who has studied herbal medicine for over 10 years and uses herbs daily.  One example is red yeast rice which helps control cholesterol instead of using a prescription statin medicine.  Statin medicines were originally derived from natural sources such as red yeast rice.  Aspirin was developed from willow bark, another natural source.  Penicillin was derived from mold.  I could state many more examples off the top of my head but my point is made  many if not most over the counter and prescription medications originated from substances found in nature.  They were then synthesized by pharmaceutical companies to sell at a nice profit.    
I can share a personal anecdote about herbal supplement use, specifically red yeast rice.  I had been taking it for years until my physician told me my cholesterol was in a good range - she told me to stop taking it.  After six months without red yeast rice my cholesterol was back up and the same physician suggested a prescription statin medication.  I reminded her that she was the one who told me to stop taking the natural supplement which had been controlling my cholesterol.   I am back to taking red yeast rice again rather than a prescription, controlling my cholesterol naturally.  I share this personal story as an advocate for herbal supplements; I know they work.  As I stated in the beginning of this letter I would like to see kratom as a non-pharmaceutical option for me if I choose.
Kratom is a plant that should not be regulated any more than coffee should be regulated.   Kratom is not an opioid and is not any more dangerous to consume than coffee.  There are many natural herbal supplements on the market today that work safely and effectively.  People need to be allowed the choice to use a natural substance over a pharmaceutically derived medicine. I deserve that choice.  The American Kratom Association (at www.americankratom.org) lists many facts, success stories and scientific studies that support my position that kratom should not be banned or regulated.

documents.commentText:
My name is Dustin Rohde. I'm 25 years old and I live in Saint Petersburg, Florida working as a software engineer.

I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEA's Intent to Schedule the mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, which would make kratom (Mitgragyna speciosa) a Schedule I controlled substance. This would completely ban the sale, possession, cultivation, and consumption of kratom, a harmless, mildly stimulating plant used for generations as a mild energy booster and mood lifter.

This is an extreme course of action that should only be reserved for substances with a high abuse potential and/or pose a serious threat to public health and safety. There is no evidence that kratom meets either of these criteria.

For most people, kratom is used as a mild mood enhancer -- much like coffee. It's unique, stress-relieving properties also make it a viable replacement for dangerous substances like alcohol and illegal drugs, giving people a safer, healthier way to relax at the end of a stressful work day. It is also effective as a social lubricant, helping people to open up and have fellowship with others. Others use it for its energizing properties, to make the work day go by a little easier -- all without any known harmful side effects. I have personally witnessed all of these phenomena in my own community of over 300 people who all consume kratom regularly.

I discovered kratom on a suggestion from a friend, and began drinking a tea made out of it occasionally. It's relaxing properties made it easier for me to open up to people and socialize, and before long I stopped consuming alcohol and going to bars to escape the stress of my work day. Now I am healthier and happier than I was then, and I've experienced zero side effects.

My story is not unique -- many of my friends and associates have experienced similar, mild benefits from the kratom plant. Putting this substance on the Schedule I list would have a significant, negative impact on the lives of many Americans, without any provable benefits. I strongly encourage you to reconsider.

documents.commentText: I am writing today to ask the DEA to NOT schedule Kratom as a schedule 1 drug. We clearly don't have enough science on the matter. Currently the DEAS has marijuana scheduled as a Schedule 1 drug with "no medicinal value" and this is patently false to the point of being laughable. This is evidenced with the spreading outright rejection of the DEA's current scheduling in the form of more and more laws allowing for the medicinal and recreational use at the state level.  Whereas the opiate addiction epidemic has killed and continues to kill countless americans, including my best friend Carolyn Daley in 2015, Marijuana and kratom do not have such a body count. Even worse there is a growing public consciousness that kratom can help opiate addition recovery. For the DEA to ban this natural plant-based substance at this time without more research and scientific evidence as to its danger except for some anecdotal stories and knee-slap reaction with equating it to far more dangerous synthetic drugs sold in head shops would be a tremendous disservice to the american public. Even worse, it risks sending the message that the DEA is increasingly irrelevant and ineffective when they seek to waste resources to suppress the use of beneficial drugs instead of focusing on drugs that really can kill and are widely accepted as dangerous. Kratom is not one of these drugs. Dont make the same mistake as you did with marijuana and set the country backwards. The information on kratom will only continue to spread in this day and age and eventually the benefitial evidence of this substance will outweigh its danger in a majority of the public's consciousness and the scheduling will be reversed and the DEA will be mocked for having scheduled it as dangerous in the first place. Let's be smart and not go down this road again. Get the research done and until then, sit on your hands and don't interfere with a good thing.

documents.commentText: While I believe that it is good that the DEA has been given the ability to deal with dangerous drugs in an expedited fashion, I also believe that in order to exercise that power it must provide a fairly high level of proof/persuasion that said drugs should be placed into Schedule 1 (even if temporarily). I don't believe that the DEA has met this level of proof. In regard to "no accepted medical use", there have been synthetic drugs produced from these alkaloids. Please refer to https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18550129, jpet.aspetjournals.org/content/348/3/383.full, and https://www.google.com/patents/US20100209542. And in regard to "high potential for abuse", I see no evidence for this produced by the DEA. One confirmed death attributed solely to kratom use should not constitute an imminent hazard. Even the misstatement in the notice of intent that the alkaloids in kratom are opioids reveals a need for additional persuasive proof for scheduling by the DEA.

documents.commentText:
To whom it concerns,
I am a 35 year old male who is disabled and currently taking opiate medication to treat chronic pain as a result of a spinal injury.  I just wanted to submit my comment that I believe that to put yet another plant under scheduling, when it is already known to help people, and while there has been a serious lack of research done on this plant to discover all of it's medicinal properties, is a big mistake.   

While I haven't used the plant myself yet, I am urging my government to please reconsider placing it under any schedule, because there are many people, who are disabled, who have found that Kratom is helpful in treating pain safely and effectively.  

Instead of forcing people to be slaves to the pharmaceutical industry, We the People, ought to be able to decide for ourselves what is effective in treating certain maladies.  

Why should people be forced to take Opiate medication, when in many cases, using Kratom has been shown to be as effective and not habit-forming?  If you would argue that this question is incorrect in my assumption that Kratom is helpful to fight pain while being non habit-forming,  I would argue that the necessary research has not been done on this plant to make assumptions about whether it is or is not as habit forming as opiate pain medications, or whether it is habit forming at all; and to schedule this Kratom plant before the evidence has been properly and thoroughly studied, is to do a great disservice to the American people, and specifically to those who would get benefit from this plant.

I sincerely hope that my government, will do what is proper in this case, and not step in the way of our unalienable rights to the pursuit of happiness.  To those who suffer from pain, for whatever reason, they deserve the right to try to take whatever steps are necessary to help themselves, and not have the DEA, or any other agency which serves the People of the United States of America, come between their ability to pursue pain relief.  Especially when it is my belief that happiness is much harder to pursue while in a state of suffering.  

Alternatively, it should be up to each State to decide it's laws through the process of State Government being elected by the people, and should not be decided by the Federal Government or any of it's agencies.

I appreciate this opportunity to submit my comment.

documents.commentText:
I would like to write in opposition of placing the herb kratom (Mitragyna Speciosa) on the list of controlled substances as a Schedule I. I believe that this would have a devastating impact on the lives of hundreds of thousands or even millions of Americans who have been using this herb effectively to treat medical conditions. As I'm sure you are aware, a Whitehouse.gov petition was created in opposition to a kratom ban and it generated over 145,000 signatures from concerned Americans. I believe this number is really just the tip of the iceberg, there are certainly many more people in the kratom community who didn't sign the petition. 

Kratom has been sucessfully and responsibly used by many Americans in the treatment of various health conditions. To name a few: the treatment of pain, including chronic pain, the treatment of anxiety, the treatment of depression and for opioid addiction therapy. For many it is a safer alternative to the dangerous opioid pain-killers that would otherwise be needed to provide adequate pain-relief. These prescriptions commonly damage the liver, stomach and kidneys as well can lead to miserable withdrawal symptoms and have a significant risk of respiratory depression. Kratom on the other hand has not been tied to organ damage, has mild to no withdrawal symptoms and has a low risk of causing respiratory depression. 

Kratom's safety record is objectively better than that of prescription opioids as well. In cases where kratom was found in the body of the deceased, it was not ruled as the cause of death in any of them and in almost all cases there were multiple drugs present. By contrast, over 20,000 people die from prescription opioid drug use every year in the United States. Also, in a 5 year period between 2010 and 2015 only 600 kratom related calls were made to poison control centers in the United States, a very small number. To put that into perspective about 50,000 calls were made to poison control centers concerning laundry detergent packets during that same period of time and over 55,000 calls concerning prescription opioid drugs have already been made to poison control centers just during this year alone. www.aapcc.org/alerts/opioids/

It is my belief that banning kratom will lead to nothing but suffering, misery and even suicide as people who suffer from chronic medical conditions are forced to stop using an herb that has helped keep their health stable, for years in some cases. This will also doom many former opioid addicts who have managed to stay clean from heroin or other similar drugs with the help of kratom.  I believe that all people want here is to be allowed a choice in their own healthcare. Most people in the kratom community are not opposed to an age restriction (like 18 or 21 and up) or the ban of products that mix kratom and other substances together but kratom should remain legal to sell in products containing only kratom to adult consumers. Thank you for your consideration of this matter.

My name is Michael Walden. Im a 9 year user of kratom (mitragyna speciosa) I would like to bring to attention two specific conditions I have. One: At age 9 I was struck by a car in windsor missouri, this is on public record and if need be I can validate all my injuries without any problem. I was struck by a vehicle going 45 miles an hour (a 1970's model cadallac ironically the mayors wife of the town I lived in is the one that hit me.) From this I gained serious problems with my back that required extensive surgery in my younger years. This bred me into the realm of opiate drugs particularly hydrocodone for the first few years of pain management and treatment. 

That and the muscle relaxers they had me on eventually led to me developing heavy mental problems and heavy depression. When depression began creeping in I was 15-16, and it was directly due to the amount of medications I was on even by my doctors own admission he said I had been switched around too much so they stuck me on an analogue (or at the time a brand new approved analogue known as norco's.) 

Thats where I drew the line the medications ALL the medications they had me on didn't work. Nothing worked my depression increased due to the anti-depressants and anti-anxiety medications they put me on and the pain killers didn't even touch my pain not even in the same realm of possibility as what kratom has done for me. 

I wanted to die when I was on pills, I felt like a leper- someone who needed to avoid other people because if I had been around them I did not trust myself to be around people without snapping. This is when I began developing a hereditary condition I have known as Lynchen simplex chronicus. During my depression it heightened my anxiety majorly and caused a dormant condition to awaken in my genetics, an incurable genetic condition known as Lynchen Simplex Chronicus. My particular brand was associated directly to my anxiety. 

My skin torn, my body aching and in insurmountable pain I made a decision that I would rather die than live like this and if I couldn't find a solution- that was exactly what I was going to do. True misery is something I lived in for years and after I lived in misery for those years the fear of death truly became nothing to my mind. I had a mental breakdown at my brothers house the year I made that decision during thanksgiving, i'll never forget I just lost it, hit the ground and started crying, writhing in pain and anger I truly was in a dark place.

My brother in law brought me to a 200 dollar walk in clinic the next day, he paid for me to get looked at and I spoke with an older doctor, she had a very sweet nature, turns out the condition I have (lynchen simplex chronicus) is very well known in south east asia where this doctor was from. She stated to me that there isn't much that can be done about the skin condition except get on a regiment of anxiety and depression medications and hope for the best.

That is when I told her everything I have said in this post so far and she looked at me knowing where I was at and how close I was at the end of my rope and she went on a limb and took pity on me and informed me of kratom. That was the moment that changed my life, the moment I didn't feel frustration any longer I remember thinking "an herb that will stop my pain and depression and anxiety? That's preposterous. Modern medicine couldn't even help me how will this?" 

Well.. After scratching my skin to the muscle, after dealing with the "thousand year itch" for so long for the first time once the kratom passed my lips within 2 days and ONLY 2 days my rash was completely gone, I didn't even have that bad of scars from it. I felt for the first time since I was 9 years old what I would deem "normal" not "high" that is what I was trying to escape, that feeling of dread and being forced to supplement your daily existence to even walk by taking opium based pain killers is no life to live. 

I have taken kratom for 9 years and haven't touched even so much as an ibuprofen. Kratom is dangerous? That's an outright preposterous statement. I have taken enough that I "would have definitely died if it were dangerous in any lethal capacity." I have never experienced any of the supposed side effects (hallucinogens, Close eyed visuals auditory hallucination/ respiratory depression) The side effects aren't real- completely made up.

I want it to be clear by banning kratom you will be greatly reducing my quality of life and millions of others. By allowing this ban you are forcing people to "ignore their pain and anxiety" instead of deal with it, because that's what pills do, they allow you to ignore the problem- a temporary band-aid. Kratom is a solution to many problems and if you go by other research done in other continents that DEFINITELY have fully researched it- you would realize exactly how good it is and how much it could change the way our medical system works. http://ensobotanicals.com/kratom/

documents.commentText:
Nov 29, 2016

Our Story,
15 years ago I married the love of my life,  We had 2 children together and soon I realized the hold alcohol had on him.  We had together enjoyed the recreational use of drugs and alcohol but as time went on and we became parents I noticed that as he loved us alcohol was his first real love. It was something that needed to be considered before groceries, in any travel plans or daily activities.  It had taken the front seat to our lives.  I tried many times to be bold and leave but love kept drawing us back together. He has always had an amazing heart but as time went on and the alcoholism got worse our lives became more and more unpredictable.  

After 13 years of marriage, 2 children, 3 attempts at treatment and 4 separations  he was up to a liter of vodka every day.  He had suffered at least one seizure and unable to go beyond 20 mins without a shot to keep from triggering the start of detox symptoms. 
Uncountable attempts to clean up on his own were continuously unsuccessful. Many of these included spending time in a hospital or detox center so as not to risk the danger of such a significant detox on his own. 

A year and a half ago he chose treatment once again to get his family and more importantly his life back.
He completed it successfully and came out with a new perspective.  Unfortunately he continued to struggle with Migraines, Anxiety and insomnia.  Many of these he would have previously treated with a drink but he tried so desperately to avoid that road again.  
He found himself taking up to 10 doses of Excedrin migrane every day to control the pain and struggled to feel comfortable out in the world among his peers.  

After about 9 months the drink got a hold of him again and it was insane to see how quickly the alcoholic reverts.  It didnt take much to get him completely intoxicated and after only one drink it was almost impossible for him to leave the house without the pull for the bar.  
They say that no matter how long the alcoholic is sober they start right back to where they left off.  One drink would lead right into the detox phase of shaking, vomiting, fevers and tremors.  This was like a nightmare everyday, not knowing what to expect coming home to and the most painful part was watching him struggle not wanting to walk that path but having every cell in his body drawing him down it.

I am very much a naturalist and know how his previous life of using pharmaceuticals recreationally could lead to additional problems. However something needed to change.  
He was preparing to go to another psychologist and get some form of medication to assist in the cravings when he stumbled across Kratom. In doing research to avoid the psychosis that the previous medication caused he found that many others were having relief from cravings, pain and anxiety with this natural substance.  

We found it available at our local herb shop and immediately noticed a difference.  There was the light back in his eyes.  He even suggested we go play tennis!  
It has now been 6 months of using Kratom and I wouldnt go back for anything.  Of course I still worry if some major life crisis will lead back to the bottle but I really think that even if he were tempted just to try his dramatic past life keeps him from even testing his strength.  

I was concerned with him taking another substance, especially after hearing about the DEA issues. However after seeing him on Kratom is like seeing a NORMAL PERSON in my husbands skin.  I have a man now that has compassion and patience,  Vision and follow-through and most importantly fairly predictable in mood.  I am no longer afraid of the dr Jeckyl/Mr Hyde factor and our kids have their father back.  

I understand that many are concerned with a substance that they can't control the chemistry, however when using a natural substance we often suffer less from side effects because the body gets the complete chemical makeup that is presented naturally.  Especially with a product that is as unadulterated as the Kratom herb.
 
I hope that the struggles that we have gone through as a family will help others find peace in their own lives.

documents.commentText: Hi - While this plant can be made in extracted forms and is mildly addictive, and no one expects this failed drug war to end and a successful Portugal model to be adopted, it would make more sense for this fully natural plant to be sold in somewhere like CVS regulated like Dayquil/Nyquil. Note that in Alabama, opiate deaths doubled once Kratom became illegal. Also note that Kratom has never killed a human by itself (as far as it's known). With public pressure to deal with the PHARMACEUTICAL and never-ending ILLEGAL opiate problem mounts, a reaction to ban a tool to help people FIX that problem is the most childish reaction imaginable. There's absolutely no logic to that kind of behavior and it makes people want to leave the "land of the free". There may be subtext that the government is in the pockets of big pharma which is a clear and correct narrative, but you would be further cementing distrust and hate toward the government by doing this. With no research and the current context of the country in mind, I can add my personal story. The tremendous cost of going to a psychiatrist+chologist against searching for anything illegal or alcohol will naturally lead someone with depression/anxiety to the least costly and embarrassing alternatives. To put this up front, I took Kratom for 5 straight years, with no breaks. Getting bloodwork done once every couple years out of worry led to NO negative impacts that were observed. One thing to consider is: there is actually a ceiling to how "high" a person can get. You will start throwing up quicker than you will kill yourself by ODing. It is plant matter, not an extremely potent synthesized powder. You would have to search out harder drugs, which most people wouldn't do if this is available easily to sooth the body and mind. During this period, I held a steady job, got promoted, became management, never showed up late, held a girlfriend the entire time. Before this, none of the above. Of course, more research the better. I understand some interests want to prevent that. Think of what making this plant illegal does for people like me. When my health insurance bill is about to go from $375 to $430/month at the beginning of the year, those of us who are non-lobbyists, non-hedge-funders, non-tax-payer-paid civilians have to make real life decisions about how to cope with whatever we are born with mentally, physically, or what have you. No, I don't game the system. No, I don't have kids. No, I have not done something terrible warranting some political stigma. I am a relatively well off white male. I will stop here so this is actually readable. Feel free to use this as an example in public discourse. This plant saved my life. Apologies for bitterness.

I'm writing in regard to the possible prohibition of kratom:
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

To: Mr. Chuck Rosenberg
Acting Administrator, DEA


I am writing to express my opposition to the proposed scheduling of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, constituents of Mitragyna Speciosa (Kratom.) I oppose the scheduling of these alkaloids for three distinct reasons: my personal experience with Kratom, accessibility of this plant for research purposes, and the overall goal of reducing harm. 


I work as a landscaper as well as a caretaker for my parents' home and two rental properties. I suffer from chronic back pain due to a genetic misalignment of my L5 and S1 vertabrae. I also suffer from negative thinking patterns and anxiety. I have found that Kratom helps reduce physical pain and concomitant negative thinking, as well as reducing feelings of anxiousness throughout the day. Since beginning Kratom use I have been able to work outdoors in variable conditions without pain while maintaining a clear head and cogent thinking. My productivity and positive thinking have both increased. My doses of Kratom are extremely small (1/4 tsp.) and I have noticed no deleterious effects or withdrawal symptoms if I cease my Kratom use for any length of time. 


The best way to encourage research into the medical properties and potential benefits of Kratom is to keep it legal and accessible. Scheduling mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine will only reduce accessibility to research institutions tasked with unlocking the potential medical benefits of this plant. It is in society's best interest to encourage as much research into these alkaloids as possible. Research institutions seeking to study the medical benefits of cannabis are severely restricted by way of the Schedule 1 status of that plant. I urge the DEA not to repeat this decades-long prorogation of scientific research by scheduling mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine. Current research seems to confirm my personal experience with Kratom as a safe botanical supplement with far, far less danger to society than legal substances like alcohol and tobacco products. 


I appreciate the Drug-Enforcement Agency as an organization tasked with reducing harm. No doubt this has been accomplished with the banning of many destructive synthetic compounds that are extremely, immediately harmful to users and their families. I urge the DEA to weigh the relatively little harm caused by Kratom as a legal botanical compared to the harm induced by making hundreds of thousands of current American Kratom users felons with the scheduling of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine. I firmly believe that keeping these alkaloids legal is the less harmful path forward. Scheduling them would inevitably lead to the formation of a black market as it has in the case of cannabis. Black markets suffer from lack of quality control, tax evasion, violence, immense expenditures by law enforcement and the justice system, and the fragmentation of families due to drug sentencing laws. 

Thank you for accepting public comments on this issue. I urge the DEA to keep mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine legal. Please do not make felons out of hundreds of thousands of otherwise peaceful and nonviolent citizens, including many veterans of our Armed Forces, seeking the relief Kratom provides.  


Sincerely, 

Colin Richardson

I urge you to please reconsider listing Kratom, or its constituent chemical components, as a Schedule I Drug. I have suffered chronic pain and fatigue since contracting a Hospital Acquired MRSA infection during rotator cuff surgery in October of 2014. I was initially being treated with an opioid for the chronic pain, but it was about at this same time that information was surfacing about the extent of opioid abuse and overdosing. Because of concerns related to the opioid "epidemic" I began looking for a safe, effective, legal and preferably natural alternative. I spent days online researching this and the consensus kept coming up that Kratom was the right alternative. 

I tried a small quantity at first, and was pleasantly surprised at its effectiveness. It eased my pain considerably, but probably just as importantly it relieved the fatigue that is so often associated with chronic pain. I was able to take part in most of the activities that I had enjoyed prior to the unfortunate MRSA experience. I have now been enjoying Kratom for nearly two (2) years and have not experienced any adverse effects. On days when my pain is mild, I simply forego the Kratom, and then on days of more severe pain I am able to get the relief and energy that I need to enjoy my life.

I would like to see more research done with Kratom, and in the meantime would experience a significant reduction in my quality of life it is Classified as a Schedule I Drug, so please allow those of us who get so much benefit from this natural supplement to continue to do so.

documents.commentText:
I am an addiction medicine physician.  I hate to post anonymously, but I just don't feel comfortable using my name.
I do not see Kratom as a significantly risky drug of abuse.  It certainly does not pose the risk that heroin/fentanyl poses and it is very likely less dangerous than either alcohol or marijuana.  

Although there have been reported deaths in people who have kratom in their system, the important question is what else was the person using and what was the actual cause of death.  Given the grass roots support for its use, and therefore the likely high incidence of kratom use, it seems unlikely that it poses a danger of overdose and death given the small number of deaths that happen to have kratom on toxicology.

I think it would be helpful if further research were done on it's risks as well as its possible benefits, which would be more difficult if it were classified CI.  The same issue occurred with marijuana and now we have the bogus concept of "medical" marijuana  without the benefit of good research done on its components, such as cannabidiol.  I'd hate to see this happen to kratom also when it may truly have some benefit.

I've never had a patient see me for addiction treatment who described kratom use, so I suspect it's not a major player as an addictive drug.  I'm concerned that those who seem to benefit from it will continue to seek it if it is reclassified, and the risk exists that what they find will be something unknown and possibly more dangerous since they will have to resort to illegal sources.  Additionally, it raises the issue of law enforcement and punishment of illegal kratom users, should it be reclassified.

documents.commentText:
The world of drugs is shrouded in many half truths and mysteries. None so much as Kratom, I've found over the last four years of taking it. Despite the fact that it has been consumed by humans regularly in southeast Asia where it is endemic to for several hundreds of years; very few people I have found know about it.

Laying in my bed, a victim of strep throat from smoking too much hookah with strangers (my bad), I simply could not afford to go to the doctor. I tried to tough it out and go to class with tylenol, but, this simply was not working and was dangerous because the streptococcus was getting worse. I eventually had to leave and go back to my hometown, where I could not eat anything solid anymore and even swallowing liquids was a pain. My mom had been taking this ... thing, called Kratom, for a year or two. Ever since, she had a lot more energy, a lot less pain, was much less depressed and generally was just a better person to be around at all times. When she didn't have it, I didn't really notice a difference like withdrawals. She'd go back to being much more negative, and being around her was simply unpleasant before she started taking Kratom.

My turn, I guess. I could barely swallow anything and my mom entered my bedroom, as I was burning up with a fever of 103F four years ago, and gave me water, tylenol for the fever and... what? I had to ask her what they were, and after initially refusing, the pain became so agonizing that I somehow managed to force down six gelatin capsules containing Kratom.

An hour and a half later, my fever went rocketing down and the amount of pain in my throat went from a 9/10 to a 3/10 and I was comfortable to sleep. I was amazed, truly, absolutely amazed. I went from feeling like I was dying to my throat pain going away. I was also mentally stimulated, and talkative. But I found myself able to pick which way I wanted to go: stay awake and do something productive if I needed to like fix a meal, or go to sleep without anxiety and pain. It was quite perfect. 

At first, it was a bit of a "buzz", but, fairly quickly over time it simply has turned into a feeling of wellbeing, clarity, no anxiety or depression, and positive thoughts. It is the only way I can properly function and communicate in a hectic, loud workspace while having severe PTSD and other disorders. Technically, this plant falls under the category of "opioid" which is an alarm signal for many people, however, it is extremely unique in its functions with different bonding sites in the brain, while also being generally considered far less addictive.

What is its medicinal uses though? Why did the DEA try to ban it? Well, when combined with alcohol, drugs or research chemicals in the past, only a few (single digits) people have died in the U.S., and none of them from strictly non-extract Kratom-use only. What are the benefits? Besides the positives listed, I have personally seen it do the following:

Cure addiction to methadone and heroin by using Kratom to wean off of the substances.
Temporarily cured my father's alcohol problem. He didn't drink for over two years, which is incredible for my father, a lifetime alcoholic.
I was drinking quite heavily before I started taking Kratom on and off four years ago; now, it's become only socially.
Beneficial for agoraphobia and many other anxiety and depressive conditions, including my PTSD
Helped my step-mother quit abusing her percocet, while providing pain relief for arthritis and fibromyalgia
I personally detoxed from months of Oxycodone/Vicodin post-surgery using Kratom. Result: no withdrawal symptoms from sudden discontinuation of my painkillers when I "weaned off" with Kratom. It is quite a safe substance. The worst I've ever seen with Kratom is a person vomiting once, and then they are fine. Kratom. Is. NOT. A. Problem. Please, stop policing our private lives. It does not impair you whatsoever.

documents.commentText:
Thank you for allowing this period of public comment regarding Kratom

Following knee surgery in July 2012, I began to experience extreme pain and swelling in both of my legs. I was given several diagnoses, treatments, and medications with no effect. It wasnt until March 2013 that I was properly diagnosed with CRPS (chronic regional pain disorder). Again, I was given a slew of treatments and medications to try and treat the severe pain.  Among this list is methocarbamol, topiramate, cymbalta, lyrica, a series of nerve blocks in my back, and a 2 week ketamine IV treatment. As a consequence of my disability, I also developed depression and anxiety. Having my life turned upside down, losing my job, feeling self conscious, loss of self worth and zero control over my life were also taking a toll on me. Not only were the medications ineffective for my pain, anxiety, and depression, but the side effects of drowsiness, dizziness, apathy, and confusion only added to my issues. 

I cant begin to describe the level of misery in my life during this time. A life with CRPS can a life of constant pain and suffering. It has affected every aspect of my life. While my prescribed medications offered some minor relief, they were unfortunately not enough to improve my quality of life to a bearable level. I was desperate to find further relief.  I began researching organic natural alternative to prescription medicines.  In doing so, I found Kratom. I found scores of people whos lives were positively changes by this supplement, from depression, pain, anxiety, help to safely get them off opiates, and many more benefits. I have been so grateful that I found Kratom.  It has been a significant factor in helping to manage my chronic pain anxiety, and depression. Together with a spinal stimulator, a moderate dose of gabapentin, wellbutrin, and responsible use of and Kratom, I have been able to regain a quality of life I had not had before. It is an essential part of my ability to sleep better, walk with less discomfort, periodically leave my home, and have a healthier state of mind in dealing with my disability. A life without Kratom for me would most certainly mean a return to a life of pure misery. I prospect I find terrifying. 

In summation, I believe evidence shows Kratom is a safe alternative/addition to pharmaceutical drugs. It has been wrongfully categorized as a harmful and addictive substance. Kratom has been used for its many benefits for a very, very long time. When compared to legal substances like alcohol, tobacco and opiates, which pose a clear and significant threat to humans, Kratoms history demonstrates a far superior record. 

I implore you to please support a responsible compromise of a 21+ age requirement on this supplement and keep kratom legal. The consequences to those of us that depend on this supplement will be devastated and therefore the quality of life, will be deeply harmed. Thank you for your time and service to our nation. 


Sincerely, 

Bill Leigh
To take the drastic actions of making Kratom a controlled schedule 1 medication is drastic and will hurt so many people in so many ways. Those formally addicted to opiates will return to them, those on pain may have to turn to opiates, those depressed or have anxiety could turn to dangerous substances. Sensible age restrictions, marketing regulations, and possible quality oversight are reasonable actions to protect both people and this suppliment. I respectfully implore the DEA to not make Kratom illegal without much more research and input from both proponents and opponents of Kratom. The unintended consequences of making Kratom illegal will be catatrophic for many people. I ask the DEA to please slow down in their actions. 
Thank you for alllwing me to voice my concerns and share my story.

It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
In reference to:  Docket No. DEA-442W .  The proposed ban on Kratom.

In my experience, I have rarely come across a natural plant product that can do so much good and, as far as I have seen, be safe for people to use.  Kratom was and is the only substance that helped me to stop taking narcotics for pain.  I have had numerous surgeries and suffer chronic pain in my neck, back, hip, and shoulder.  My neck and lower back are fused due to severe herniation of disks.
After many years of pain management with a doctor, I found that narcotics did not work any longer and I was only taking them to keep from getting sick (withdrawal).  The doctor tried many treatments and stimulator implants combined with prescription pain killers.  The doses only kept going up and my personal life suffered.  I was always depressed and 'distant' according to my spouse, family, and friends.  I made up my mind that I had had enough and was getting off the pain medicine cycle of destruction.
My doctor helped me slowly decrease my doses, put me on Suboxone and gradually weaned me down to nothing.  I found that I still had withdrawal symptoms and a high level of pain.  I refused to return to narcotics and heard from an acquaintance that Kratom had helped many people in my situation.
I researched it and read all I could find regarding it's use, effects, and how it worked.  Since the compounds mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine occupy the same receptor sites as opiates, but had little effect compared to opiates, I could see how Kratom could help.
I used 2 tsps powdered Kratom with a cup of juice a couple of times a day and found the withdrawal symptoms totally disappeared and the pain level I experience constantly, decreased to a tolerable level.
Since then (about a year and half), I continue to use Kratom and have seen no adverse effects.  In fact, my body fat content decreased, my labs improved to all within normal limits, and my blood pressure was much lower than before.  My friends and family welcomed me back to the 'real' world.  My head was clearer than it had been in years and I was able to communicate intelligently with friends and family again.
As far as the substances being addictive, I have not found that to be the case.  I have gone without Kratom and suffered no ill effects other than an increased pain level.

I hope and pray Kratom will be left alone and available to adults who need it.  It is very comparable to strong coffee, which, as we know has pain relieving effects from caffeine.  It is far safer than any of the street drugs out there.  Please don't put it in the same category.  Please keep it legal.  

Sincerely,
E.J.B.

documents.commentText:
My name is Alexis Turner, a 35-year old daughter, sister, and mother living in Texas, and I'd like to voice my concern about the threat of placement of Mytragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, components of Kratom, into Schedule I as a Controlled Substance:

After suffering from declining health over the past 10 years, I was diagnosed with adenomyosis and ovarian cysts in 2014, which lead to a hysterectomy to remove the problem areas, as opposed to continuing birth control and pain medication prescriptions. My symptoms included pain 25 out of 30 days every month, with at least a week of that in tears, due to the amount of pain. Within two months after surgery, I was then diagnosed with Hashimotos Hypothyroidism, due to a high thyroid stimulating hormone blood analysis number along with an extremely high thyroid peroxidase antibody number, meaning that I would be on thyroid replacement therapy for the rest of my life. Symptoms include memory lapses, extreme exhaustion, hair loss, and difficulty of losing weight. Within a few months, my teeth started falling apart, and not one dentist or doctor could explain it, or would even take the time to help me figure out the cause. This does cause a great deal of pain at times, and restricts what I can eat. Just this year, August of 2016, I was officially diagnosed with Fibromyalgia and bursitis of the hips. My doctor prescribed cyclobenzaprine, a muscle relaxant, along with Tramadol, which is an opioid analgesic. Cyclobenzaprine has many drug interaction warnings, along with a scary list of side effects, including confusion, fainting, hallucinations, and seizures. Tramadol also has many drug interaction warnings, one of which is a muscle relaxant like cyclobenzaprine, is addictive, and can be overdosed on easily. Tramadol also has side effects similar to cyclobenzaprine, and personally, it gives me major migraines when I take it.

After I received the diagnosis for Fibromyalgia, a friend Ive known for years introduced me to the natural plant called Kratom. I did a lot of research on this plant, as many natural herbs and supplements dont affect me the same as other people. This friend also added me to a Facebook group for a specific vendor that she uses, full of many knowledgeable and helpful people to help me on my journey of regaining the energy and normalcy that has been missing from my life for years. 

Since I started dosing Kratom, my pain levels have decreased tremendously, and my energy level has increased substantially. While this past fall was our busiest season at work, Ill also be able to attend school again to finish the college degree I started 10 years ago, one that my parents never received, as well as start low-impact exercises in order to keep my weight in control. If Kratom is easily abused, I have not experienced that, as I take extremely low doses (1 to 2 grams per day). The only so-called negative side effect that Ive noticed is an increase in water intake. 

To me, Kratom is just another natural herbal supplement, similar to many others found over the counter, like the Valerian root that I keep in my purse at all times to help with muscle pain, or the herbal teas I drink to help me sleep or keep allergies at bay. 

In short, natural Kratom is helping me to overcome low energy and memory issues due to my body literally attacking itself, and allowing me to live a normal life. I urge you to keep Kratom off of the Schedule I Controlled Substance List. Without this natural plant, my only options are minutes, hours, days, weeks, and years of pain, or the possibility of my body being damaged further by synthetic drugs.

My name is William Johnson and Im submitting this comment in reference to Docket No. DEA-442W.  I am 65 years old and currently not working.  

I oppose the DEA putting kratom on the list of Schedule 1 controlled substances.  I do not use kratom now and do not intend to use kratom in the near future.  

A friend of mine had major back surgery in 2013.  She had her spine fused with metal rods and screws.  Since the surgery in 2013, she has been in constant pain.  She started taking kratom in June of 2015.  Since then, I have seen a noticeable change.  Her pain seems to be tolerable and she can function at her job and doing household chores.  For her kratom has been a lifesaver.

Before taking kratom she did her research.  She has shared a number of the kratom articles she found with me. The most informative article/research paper that is current, is titled Update on the Pharmacology and Legal Status of Kratom by Walter C. Prozialeck, PhD. I have attached that document to my comment here.  Anyone who has not read the article should read it, because it is well worth the time.  Most, if not all of the articles that she shared with me fall in line with what Walter C. Prozialeck, PhD wrote.

As stated in the article there have been a limited amount of issues with kratom.  From what he wrote it is unclear whether kratom is 100% at fault with these health issues.  By looking at the big picture, the negative issues are a very small percentage of the people that are actually helped.

As I stated at the beginning of this letter, I do not use kratom now and do not plan to in the near future.  Good health is not a given.  Each and every one of us could lose our health at anytime and end up living a life in pain. It is because of this that I feel kratom should remain available.

In conclusion, I am asking that the DEA NOT put kratom on the list of Schedule 1 controlled substances, as the positive results far outweigh the negative results.

I am a 40 year old responsible adult consumer of Kratom. I do not support the scheduling this herbal supplement. I have suffered from back pain issues since I started working at a automotive components factory at 19 years old. In 2006 I was diagnosed with Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy. I suffer from pain & weakness caused by this, bulging discs, degenerative disc disease & sciatic nerve pain. I was prescribed dangerous pharmaceutical pain medication. It wasn't long before I had to start taking other pharmaceuticals to combat the side effects of the pain medications. This caused a vicious cycle that caused more harm than help. I was sick everyday. I tried but couldn't succeed at getting myself off these medications. The several times I tried, I ended up in the ER with horrible withdrawal symptoms. Being sick & not being able to move around has caused my muscles to deteriorate much faster. I felt hopeless in this situation. Then one day I saw a post in my chronic pain support group on Facebook. The member claimed she was able to get off all her dangerous pain medications & return to a productive life with the help of a plant leaf called Kratom. I was intrigued. I did some research & placed an order. I have been taking Kratom for over a year & a half. I have been able to get off all my pain, depression & anxiety medications. I have been able to do more in the past year & a half then the previous 10 years in a dark haze of pharmaceuticals. Kratom gave me back quality of life. Kratom is not addictive on its own. People with addictive personalities can become addicted to anything. I was on a dark & lonely path to death before Kratom. Now I'm back in the light.

Adult Americans do not need to be mothered by an unelected government agency. I believe we have a Constitutional right to take a natural plant we believe helps us have a quality of life. It boggles my mind that alcohol & tobacco, both of which have no medical value & high potential for abuse are legal, & this agency is trying to ban a plant leaf. Is nothing sacred?

documents.commentText: From the age of 16 on I've been a poly substance abuser. I've entered rehab twice under my own volition to help deal with the problem. While I have experienced short periods of success, long-term I was never able to achieve complete sobriety. In 2008 I became addicted to Oxycontin and battled that off and on for 3 years. I finally decided I wanted to quit and attempted to reclaim my life with use of Suboxone. Let me tell you from experience Suboxone is one of the most difficult drugs to quit. Due to the long half-life and the strength of The Binding affinity of the opioid in Suboxone, withdrawals are extremely intense and last for weeks. It can oftentimes take several months to feel anywhere near normal. I can honestly say it was the most miserable experience in my life. After a few attempts I finally discovered kratom which I purchased on the internet. I slowly weaned my usage down and after a few months I quit cold turkey. I was semi miserable for 3 days but it was nowhere near the trauma that I went through trying to quit regular opioids and Suboxone. Literally within 4 days I was back at work and feeling pretty good. I remained clean and sober for about 6 months when I decided that my quality of life was better using a reasonable amount of Kratom rather than trying to white-knuckle my way through life. In just four short years I rebuilt my life. I've repaid much of my debts. I've improved my credit score to the point where I could buy a house should I choose. Restarted my career and I'm currently a director of online marketing for a large company. I have a 401k. I have a beautiful three-year-old son. And come Thursday it will be exactly two years since I've taken my last drink. On top of that it's been 4 years since I've taken an illegal drug. I know that your mandate is to protect the public from dangerous substances. But I truly believe with all my heart that Kratom does more good than harm. With more education and more research this wonderful plant could be the key to ending the nasty opioid epidemic that has claimed so many lives before their time. It pains me to think of all the people who are on the edge of Destruction and have discovered Kratom only recently. I'll be fine. I have medical insurance. I can go down and get Suboxone any day I want. But the people who are not economically advantaged have a very tough choice. And unfortunately many of those same people will make the wrong choice. They will end up back on prescription opioids, or worse. Some of them will end up in the hospital, and some of them will end up dead, never to reach their full potential.

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be labeled a schedule 1 drug. 
Kratom has helped thousands of people in the US kick opioid dependency. Opioids killed 500,000 people last year.  Kratom has not been identified as causing a single, sole-source death. Any association with a kratom induced death was attributed to other drugs in the persons system. Kratom has helped many people kick opioid habits. Kratom has been used in Asian for thousands of years as a natural pain reliever. Hundreds of thousands of people use kratom as a natural pain reliever. Banning kratom will turn these individuals into criminals. If kratom is banned, it will cause chronic pain sufferers to go back to Opioids, where almost a thousand people die per day worldwide, even though they are legally prescribed. Banning kratom, a harmless drug and categorizing it like heroine is ridiculous, and will do more harm than good. 
There is medical evidence that supports kratom as a natural pain reliever,  and a ban will nearly halt any efforts to prove it's effictiveness.

documents.commentText: I believe that Kratom should remain unscheduled because it is a natural remedy to help with opiate and alcohol addiction withdrawal, and can be an incredible tool to help so many Americans who are suffering. There should certainly be more research done to determine it's safety, but to classify Kratom as a schedule I narcotic and deem it to have medicinal value would be a huge disservice to the citizens of the United States. If the DEA would really like to serve the American people, they should seriously consider actually fighting the opiate epidemic in this country instead of creating more legislature to fuel it. On a more personal level, as someone who loves and relies on an addict - I beg that the DEA will take the initiative to do right by those of us affected by this terrible disease by letting this safe and natural plant stay legal for use by people who may never otherwise have a shot of making it out alive. Please give us the opportunity to have our loved ones back.

documents.commentText:
Nov 8, 2016

Thank you for providing this opportunity to express my views on this issue.

I am a 64 year old male and have been drinking kratom as a tea for about one year. I purchase it from a local kratom/kava bar in Gulfport, Florida. I consume it 1-3 times per week with no more than 12 oz during a 24-hour period.

Kratom helps me in the following ways:

1. It relieves severe headache/sinus pain to a remarkable degree. My pain is caused by recurring and sometimes severe sinus infections. 

2. It is a mild mood enhancer.

3. It reduces general anxiety, which I experience at various intervals.

I've never experienced an undesirable side effect from kratom. There was never a loss of equilibrium. My only caveat is that drinking it on an empty stomach may cause some mild nausea, although vomiting never occurred.

When kratom became unavailable to me due to the temporary ban, I did not experience withdrawal, either physically or psychologically. I did miss it, however, because I was at times experiencing the sinus/head pain as well as anxiety. But I never felt an overwhelming desire for kratom.

Of course, various medications are available for alleviating pain and anxiety. But I would much rather use a natural herb for relief as opposed to potentially harmful or toxic medications created by the pharmaceutical companies.

I fully support the legalization of kratom, except the minimum age for its use should be 18.  

Finally, I applaud the DEA for reversing its decision to ban kratom at this time, and sincerely hope that the lifting of the ban becomes permanent.

Best regards,
David Yelenchic

documents.commentText: To say that kratom has no valid medical use is just not acceptable as truth. I found this book listed on Amazon.com: Kratom and Other Mitragynines: The Chemistry and Pharmacology of Opioids from a Non-Opium Source by Robert B. Raffa (Editor) Opioids such as morphine, codeine, and oxycodone are extracts or analogs isolated from a single source: the opium poppy. For a long time, it was believed to be natures only source of opioids. But it now appears that biological diversity has evolved an alternative source of opioid compoundsthose derived from the plant Mitragyna speciosa. This plant, known as Kratom in Thailand or Biak-Biak in Malaysia, has long been used locally as treatment for pain, fever reduction, diarrhea, and even depression. Kratom and Other Mitragynines: The Chemistry and Pharmacology of Opioids from a Non-Opium Sourcepresents an introduction to the chemical and biological properties of alkaloids isolated from M. speciosa as well as their synthetic analogs. The book covers various topics including phytochemistry, medicinal chemistry, and pharmacology. Current research, analgesic effects, and addiction potential are also discussed. As the first extensive text on the basic science and clinical use of Kratom, the book provides readers with a concise yet comprehensive introduction to natures "other opioid." About the Author Robert B. Raffa is a professor of pharmacology in the Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences at Temple University School of Pharmacy as well as a research professor in the Department of Pharmacology at Temple University School of Medicine. He has bachelors degrees in chemical engineering and in physiological psychology, masters degrees in biomedical engineering and toxicology, and a doctorate in pharmacology. Dr. Raffa was co-leader for analgesics discovery at Johnson & Johnson and was pivotal in the elucidation of the mechanism of action and development of the analgesic drug tramadol (Ultram). He is the co-holder of several patents, including the combination of tramadol plus acetaminophen (Ultracet). He has published more than 280 scientific articles in peer-reviewd journals and is the co-author or editor of several books. --- Kratom is being used by many people for chronic pain relief, for anxiety and to lessen withdrawal of dangerous drug addiction. To say it has no medical value is plain propaganda. I'm not sure why the DEA or any other government office would want to remove a helpful herbal supplement from public use when so many people are getting tremendous health benefits from it. I strongly disagree that kratom is so dangerous to the public that it should be made illegal.

documents.commentText: Several years ago I suffered a back injury at work that required a fusion and work comp case. In result of that injury and case I was also given a disability rating which would have qualified me to start drawing that disability. Unsatisfied with that idea, and the continuing chronic pain over the last several years, i chose to rely on opiate pain medication to help me continue to work and try to lead an active lifestyle, in spite of my injury. Over the years I of course developed a physical dependency to opiates, which I was fine with if thats what it took. But over those years there were several times when i would have problems getting my prescriptions due to a variety of factors, leaving me in withdrawal which is like dying, but not bieng allowed to die.  Finally, after some years, my doctor of several years retired, causing me to have to find new doctors in the new town i moved to. Due to the growing crisis and stigma attached to the perscribing of opiate pain killers, i was left in pain, and in withdrawal, trying to fight through a mountain of red tape to get the care I needed. Often I feel that skepticism os a tool ised to deter addicts, which is ungodly frustrating , even infuriating, to those of us with legitimate medical cases. My job and my personal life, my very security was greatly impacted and at ris without those meds , and as a father with responsibilities i was so fearful...how was i going to protect us when i couldnt muster the strength to deal with all that was happening with me mentally and physically? Thats when I discovered Kratom. Not only has kratom helped me through the withdrawal process, but through the anxiety and depression that can and may linger for months and even years. Kratom isnt as effective at providing the pain relief that opiates did, but it does help...and thanks to this miracle plant Im able to go to work, and ve active outside of work as well...my personal life is better for it as well as Im able to be more social and interact with others, as im not held back by mental and physical pain to the point of not being able to. I hope that eventually, with the right care and physical conditioning, i may not need anything at all. The chances are slim, but i feel optimistic, perhaps the best side effect i could tout from this wonderful discovery! Theres no high involved either. In the beginning I was taking pretty hefty doses...and never once did i feel high in the least..just ok again, just ABLE, again .so it doesnt effecr my judgement or performance negatively, at home nor in the workplace. Please...this plant is literally changing lives...SAVING lives..maybe even my own! Please...KEEP KRATOM LEGAL!!!!

documents.commentText:
KHere is my story. I am a 65 yr old woman. The only grandmother to 9 wonderful grandchildren. WThis is my story. I hope it will help you to understand why I feel it is an unjust move by the DEA to put Kratom under schedule 1. 
I am a 65 yr old woman. The only Grandmother to 9 wonderful grandchildren.
I have Lyme Disease that took 8 months to diagnose, which means I have late stage Lyme and though I have been through treatment I have been left with chronic diffuse bone and muscle pain and crippling fatigue. I also have bone spurs and stenosis in my cervical spine which causes a condition called Occipital Neuralgia. Occipital Neuralgia causes intense pressure headaches, shooting nerve pain and extreme muscle spasms in neck and shoulders. I tell you this morbid story so you will understand what Kratom means for me. It means a real life. I have always been a very active person. I have worked all of my life, eaten well and exercised. My jobs ranged from catering, working in greenhouses, owning my own store and territory manager for a high end gift and decor company. That was 8 yrs ago. For the last 8 yrs I have lived with pain and fatigue as my constant companions. I have missed family gatherings, gone on family vacations at the beach where I stayed in bed the whole time, missed my grandchildren's school events and more. I was on pain management with opioids for 6 of those yrs. my pain was made sometimes bearable and I either felt manic and not like myself or fatigued and  fuzzy brained. It  left me with limited freedom for living. Every 4 hrs the withdraw set in and I would feel horrible.  It was a life chained to a heavy weight that would jerk me back into increased pain throughout the day. 18 months ago I tried Kratom and have the joy of getting busier each week since then. I am out of bed everyday and have the energy to babysit my grandchildren, go to school activities and family celebrations. I swam in the ocean this summer and taught my granddaughter how  to dive through waves. To say it felt glorious is an understatement. I still have bad days and flare up's from my illnesses but they are less often. I am exercising and active between them.   
 Kratom has done this for me, not only helping me with my pain but giving me a release from the overwhelming fatigue. I ask you to please stop this action from the DEA not only for me but for my grandchildren who now have a grandmother who is an active and loving part of their lives. To make my wellness into a felony is beyond my comprehension. I have never felt high from Kratom just normal. That is all an ill person wants to feel is normal and that is how I want to feel. Not sick, not in pain, not fuzzy headed and  not exhausted just normal. Please take into consideration the multitudes of people getting help from this plant and help stop the DEA from scheduling this leaf that has helped so many.
       Thank you for your time, Karen Mattison
