documents.commentText:
Regarding Docket No. DEA-442W

I am a 28 year old counselor in a mental health residential apartment program. I see people struggle with addiction day in and day out, and it's no way to live. 
I was diagnosed with Rheumatoid Arthritis at 16, an inflammatory chronic bladder condition Interstitial Cystitis at 20 (had symptoms previously), and more recently Inflammatory Bowel Disease. I have T 11-12 disc ruptured in my back, and chronic nerve pain from the back issues and from Lyme Disease. I am a recovering Anorexic, and have been diagnosed with Anxiety and Bipolar Disorder. 
I can't remember the last time I felt okay before kratom. Having had lost most of a will to live, and struggling with daily chronic pain in various parts of the body, mentally and physically. I would fantasize about being hit by a car head on so i wouldn't have to deal with it anymore. Lying awake all night from racing thoughts, nightmares or pain. An awful way to live.
I first learned about Kratom in 2013. I was researching botanicals and stumbled upon it. I did a lot of research before ordering, and found Kratom that worked well for me.
Kratom gave me a life I couldn't remember ever having. My low moods stopped being nearly as low. I wasn't terrified as much to leave the house and didn't feel afraid out in public. Racing thoughts calmed down and I could catch up with myself and not be in an ongoing manic cycle. I could sit or stand for longer than a few minutes without starting to experience a burning pain. I could sleep through the night without having to use the bathroom 6-8 times. Usually if I slept through using the bathroom i would wake up with terrible pressure on my bladder and burning pain in the urethra because of Interstitial Cystitis. This doesn't happen nearly as often with Kratom.
I feel like, I don't even know how to describe. Not the empty dead shell I always thought I was supposed to feel like. Too tired and exhausted to take care of the dog or myself. Too depressed to want to wake up the next day. Fear of becoming addicted to pain medications for my conditions. I turned down opiates so often, and would push through the pain to not risk the addiction. I almost threw it all out, contemplating to just take the pain pills and eventually let them run their course and take me. But something in me didn't really want that. 
Kratom helped me find my true self, the self that didn't want the devastation of being dependent on pain pills, and eventually addicted to them. After a bladder procedure in 2011 i had to be on oxycodone for weeks, and it was awful. I couldn't go to work, was sick all day from the pills and felt so out of it and awful. 
I can't imagine a world where people recovering from opiate addiction, treating PTSD, chronic pain or mental illnesses would be denied their lifeline. Kratom is our lifeline. I know I wouldn't be here today if it weren't for Kratom. I've been able to get my life back, and be able to do things that I couldn't before due to my chronic illnesses. I am forever grateful for this plant, and thrilled to see how many people it really helps. Please, save Kratom and save lives.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Jennifer Keswick-Caballero. I am 46 years of age and work as a lab technician in Denver Colorado. I consider myself to be a mature, intelligent, and responsible adult who uses kratom on a regular basis to alleviate depression, help with focus, and boost my energy as needed. My husband uses kratom to help with chronic back pain in lieu of other addictive and damaging pain medications such as opiate drugs or NSAIDs. We have been using kratom in it's powdered form for over 5 years. Neither of us has experienced any negative side-effects due to our kratom use. In fact, I went to the doctor's office for a health check-up last spring, had blood work done, and received a perfectly clean bill of health.

I am writing to you to voice my strong opposition to the DEA's plans to classify mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as schedule one substances. This classification would stall scientific research of kratom's potential medical benefits and force many Americans to turn to other forms of harmful prescription drugs in order to combat pain, depression, and other health issues. This would exacerbate the opioid epidemic that has taken hold in the United States and be a great disservice to the many Americans that rely on kratom to relieve a myriad of health issues.

As you are aware, there have been 15 kratom-related deaths reported between 2014 and 2016. None of these deaths can be attributed to kratom use alone. In fact, 14 of the 15 deaths involved other substances and the 15th was due to severe hypoxic encephelopathy, which has not been reported as a known side-effect of kratom use. https://www.regulations.gov/document?D=DEA-2016-0015-0004  15 kratom related deaths is nothing compared to the number deaths that occurred due to accidental acetaminophen overdose during that same time period.

In closing, I urge you to reconsider your plans to classify mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as schedule one substances. There is no "imminent hazard to public safety" as has been claimed by the DEA. Restricting access of mature adults to kratom only benefits the pharmaceutical companies that sell opiate drugs and NSAIDs. Please do right by the American public and allow scientific research on the effects of kratom to continue without the unnecessary constraints that are placed on substances in the schedule one category.

Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
Dear

Please help keep, Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) and/or its constituents Mitragynine and 7-hydroxy-mitragynine, legal in your state. I implore you to make an informed decision by educating yourself on the relative safety of this plant compared to coffee, alcohol, tobacco, and prescription drugs, and I urge you to research the medicinal potential that this plant has ALREADY displayed. Please re-consider placing this plant in the most severe scheduling category and consider reasonable legislation that would restrict its use to 18+ like other states are already considering. The following are pertinent facts for your consideration:

* Kratom is a plant, NOT a synthetic chemical or Street Drug

* Kratom is in the same family as the coffee tree (Rubiaceae)

* Kratom is no more habit forming than coffee see recent article by the cato institute, www.cato.org/blog/addiction-problem-case-kartom

* Kratom has been safely used for thousands of years as a medicine

* No one has ever died from taking Kratom alone.

* It is impossible to overdose on Kratom

* Tens of thousands of Americans can attest to the beneficial properties of Kratom

* The state of WI may reverse their ruling to ban kratom see https://www.botanicallegaldefense.org/wisconsin-kratom-community-looking-to-deschedule-kratom/

Furthermore, Kratom and its 30+ active alkaloids show tremendous dietary supplement potential. The legislation, as it currently reads, would place Kratom and its alkaloids in the most severe scheduling category, schedule I. Making this plant and its constituents schedule I, effectively makes it impossible for legitimate researchers to discover and develop valuable medicines from Kratom that could benefit the lives of millions! This is not a sensible approach to regulating this plant.

Current peer reviewed studies on Kratom and its constituents have shown that Kratom has no acute toxicity1, displays powerful antioxidant and antibacterial properties2, assists with drug and alcohol withdrawal symptoms3, contains several oxindole alkaloids which have exhibited potent immunomodulation properties, and even contains constituents that have exhibited anti-cancer properties!4 A brief search in any scholarly database will present hundreds of peer reviewed studies andclinical trials that can attest to the medical potential of this plant.

A few more facts for you to consider when making your informed decision:

* According to the CDC, cigarette smoking causes 440,000 deaths in the United States every year; about one of every five deaths in this country are caused by cigarettes!

* Alcohol causes more than 1.2 million emergency room visits and 2.7 million physician office visits due to excessive drinking each year!5

* Pharmaceutical drugs are one of the leading causes of death in this country, killing one American every 19 minutes! 6

* Prescription opiate pain killers account for more than 475,000 emergency room visits annually.7

* Over the counter pain relievers such as Tylenol send over 56,000 people to the emergency room each year with liver related complications.8

* The Mayo Clinic has reported a 28% increase in overall mortality in people who drink 4 cups of coffee per day.9

In summary, the current proposed legislation places the medicinal herb Kratom and its constituents in the Schedule I category which is reserved for highly dangerous, addictive drugs that have NO medical value. The medical literature has proven Kratom and its constituents to be quite the contrary; a useful, safe, medicinal plant that has been used for thousands of years without incident. Kratom does not present a significant threat to human health or safety, when compared to legal substances such as alcohol, tobacco, Rx medications, Tylenol, or even coffee! Scheduling this plant would prohibit any future research and criminalize tax paying, productive citizens in your state as drug users, who are simply benefiting from the use of this plant.

I first tried kratom in 2004 after two unsuccessful attempts to quit OxyContin.  While I was not successful in completely quitting right away, the kratom helped me cut back gradually until I was taking only one tablet per day.  Withdrawals made it impossible to stay off opiates but kratom made them bearable.  There were no methadone clinics in my rural town and Suboxone was not available to me either.  It was cold turkey or kratom.  

Today, I still use kratom for back and shoulder pain caused by scoliosis & injuries sustained in a car accident.  It is an occasional thing along with my other herbal supplements (valerian root, ginseng & passionflower).  Losing kratom would leave me without an option for moderate to severe pain, putting me at risk for reigniting my opiate addiction.  I cannot take that risk.  

I'm currently employed full-time and considering going back to school next Spring.  I am an asset to society.  If I were to fall into addiction again, I'd be a liability to society.  I used to steal and pander to support my habit.  Now I work, vote, pay taxes and live a quiet but full life.  I have a wife and son who need me to be sober and present for them.  

I know kratom is not a magic cure for everyone, but adults must be trusted to make decisions regarding our own health.  The risks of kratom are far fewer than those of heavy narcotics or even alcohol.  We know that because it's been used for millennia in Asia with very few adverse effects.  

Please don't make kratom unavailable to people like me.  

Thank you

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

The War on Drugs has had a catastrophic impact on the trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. We need to restore that trust, and allowing for research and regulation of drugs like kratom will be a significant step

documents.commentText:
Hello,
   I am writing to help prevent Kratom from becoming a schedule 1drug. I would like to start off by talking about my past and why I use Kratom to help me. Starting at a very young age my siblings and I were taken away from our mother by CPS and put into foster care due to Real drugs like Meth. We then stayed at the children's home for a few months until a family was able to foster us. We got lucky to be able to stay with each other ( all of my siblings- two brothers and a sister). Unfortunately we were placed into a home that had more problems we could imagine. The father was using kids in the foster system for the check he received. He had about two more foster kids plus two of his own. He was an alcoholic that was very abusive to his foster kids. there were times we had to eat popcorn for breakfast, lunch and dinner while his family had real food. I can remember standing against the wall for 10 hours a day for doing nothing wrong. He ended up abusing my brother extremely bad. He had seven heart attacks then he was in a coma for three months. He is paralyzed and has brain damage. That was a very difficult time for all of my family. My mom was in jail at the time. We were placed into a better homes. We were broken up for about five months then back to our mother. We stayed with her for a while then the real drugs consumed her yet again. We were back to child protective services while my mother went back to jail. We were broken up for a while then we made it back to the old mother again. The time we got to spend with my mother was the best time of my life at that time. Unfortunately she could not stay off drugs. We went from motel to motel time after time. When she would leave us in the room and go do her thing it was heart breaking to watch her leave. I felt like a dog being left at home that cries by the window. We once again got taken away. We were put into a nice family a speech therapist fell in love with my brother when she worked with him. I could tell you about a million other horror stories in between all of that to try to show you I know what life can do to you and that I have seen the worst in life and in people. I have done very well for myself but have also had my own struggles. I was prescribed Vicodin for a period of time and was addicted. I was not out of control but I knew I had an issue. I heard about Kratom and how it can help with withdrawals. I decided to try it. And thank the lord because this Kratom stuff was actually working. It made me feel normal and calm. I was so thankful something was going to finally help me. I was able to quit immediately without even missing an ounce of sleep or work. If you know about withdrawals you know that what I'm saying is amazing. I did not have any side affects that ever made me worry or feel bad. All I had to do was mix it with milk. I quit taking Kratom for about a year and started back up for my anxiety and stress. It helps tremendously with my anxiety and I am so thankful for that. I do not have to take something even more addictive then Vicodin like a benzodiazepine. I have overcome so much in my life, I have a great job an amazing wife and dogs. This world has a tremendous amount of opportunity but it can also take everything you have. I have been able to experience both sides. I know a lot about addiction and Kratom is not addicting if anything it has the power to help people overcome their challenges in life. This plant helps me so much with anxiety and stress from things I had to grow up with. this plant is amazing please do not take this away from the public let the FDA do their research so we can figure out the real power of this plant and help change the world for the better as so many pharmaceutical drugs have a strong hold on many of our people and family. Kratom can help. 


Jon

documents.commentText:
Reference: Docket No. DEA-442W.

Ny name is Keith Pascucci. I live in Scarsdale New York. I am a 44 year old Catholic school teacher for the Archdiocese of New York City. I have been an educator, and the Director of Technology for the Archdiocese since 1996.

Since the decision to potentially make Kratom a schedule one controlled substance, myself, and the people of the Kratom community, are suffering a massive wave of depression, anxiety, panic, and emotional stress. Those of us that use Kratom to manage our various ailments are absolutely terrified that our beloved leaf is on the chopping block. This whole situation is causing me unimaginable mental agony.

I use Kratom tea daily for my various spinal cord problems. I was diagnosed with Spinal Stenosis, Scoliosis, and Degenerative Disk Disease in 2000. I suffered in agony until 2011 when I finally found Kratom. This gentle herb works amazingly well to bring my pain level from a 10+, to a 1-2, without the use of prescription, or over the counter pain relievers. I also found that it offers a gentle mood boost and provides me with mental clarity and focus. A cup of Kratom tea has replaced my morning cup of coffee. I have never been an opiate user, so I really cannot make claims about opiates. I do know that if I were to take opiates, I would not be able to drive my car to work. Opiates are mind altering, and people cannot function normally while on them.

I also would not be able to teach. I teach in an elementary school setting, and in order to do my job, I must be awake, motivated, creative, and patient. Kratom assists in managing my pain perfectly, without the dangers of addiction, possible DUI, and all the other toxic side effects that come from using synthetic pharmaceutical medications. My decade long use of Tylenol, Advil, and Aleve did extensive damage to my liver, kidneys, and stomach. I have documentation proving all of the aforementioned organ damage. I have suffered acute renal failure and acute kidney failure as well as decreased liver function due to Tylenol and Advil. I also suffered a lot of pain, and numerous bleeding ulcers, as a direct result of Naproxen Sodium, the active ingredient in Aleve. Since finding Kratom, all of these conditions have been reversed, and thankfully my body was able to heal. I still have multiple spinal problems, that would be causing me debilitating pain if it were not for Kratom.

This potential ban is certainly not about safety or health. Prescription drugs, tobacco, and alcohol kill hundreds of thousands of people each year, but they are still legal and approved by the FDA. The pharmaceutical industry wants to control every medication in this country, limiting the options for holistic medicine. They want us to believe that their chemicals are the only answer. I am a well educated Kratom user, and can see right through what is happening here. This potential ban could destroy the lives of thousands of Americans under the guise of an agency that is supposed to be here to protect us. The DEA will be creating felony criminals that they will then attempt to arrest, flooding our courts and prisons with good, law abiding people that are Veterans, nurses, teachers, doctors, lawyers, priests, nuns, parents, grandparents, uncles, aunts, and every other walk of life you can imagine. This could potentially be a huge mistake, and as a result, the overdoses, suicides, and addiction rates will skyrocket. Alabama has already proven this. The overdose death rate has risen 140% since they hastily banned Kratom in their state. Prohibition does not work. The war on drugs is a losing battle that has cost American taxpayers trillions of dollars.

I am asking you to take my story into consideration, and I ask that the DEA does not schedule what could be the answer to this country's massive and exponentially growing opiate addiction epidemic. An age restriction of 18+ would be the perfect compromise. The Kratom community has safety regulations in place that have worked quite well yo this point. The 15 alleged Kratom related deaths have all shown multiple substances in the toxicology reports. The FDA is now doing research and studies to show how safe Kratom really is, and I hope their findings prove what I already know, and have experienced first hand.

Thank you for your time,

Keith Pascucci
11 Jackson Avenue
Unit 72
Scarsdale, NY 10583
Cell: (914)-497-2571

The list of things I've done in this life is respectable,  I love people and I always do the best I can to help people when ever I can.  I hope by now you have a feel for me and my motivation in life.. I'm always busy!  2012 I had a minor accident at work that led to low back problems 2 herniated discs.  We're unsure if it's 100% from work or the years of Bmx/motocross/snowboarding,  I was put on pain Meds something I was new to. Just under a year later I was in an accident and narrowly avoided a head on collision.  Still totaled my brand new car and well two more herniated discs in my neck.  Pain Meds went up.. it lasted for about 3 years then I begin to hate how they robbed my soul.   May I add I also have knee and shoulder issues from ridding bike and motorcycles over the years.. to keep things short and effective, to get to the point I was feed up with the feeling pain Meds gave me.. the physical addiction that comes without warning.. it's something that is unavoidable when on a daily routine of pain Meds just to live out your daily life.. then I decided to do the best I could to make a change., I had heard of Kratom from online forums and I decided to give it try.. it was the best things I've done for myself in my life period! I've been off pain Meds for over a year and I haven't looked back.  I take Kratom 2 times a day sometimes 3 depending on pain. I sleep amazingly! It helps stabilize my mood when in pain and tired from work and overwhelmed.. it helps me with energy to get me through the day.  I could go on.. it's changed my life.  I have no physical addiction.  I can go days without it but I have difficult sleeping without it due to muscle spasms and severe cramping in neck and back.  All of which used to be controlled by hard pain Meds and muscle relaxers.. now I need none of them.  I can't express enough how it's helped me deal with my unfortunate circumstances.  I ask you kindly to listen to us and do what's right.  Please do not ban Kratom.  I'm severely panicking now because of this potential ban.  I understand your role in keeping the people safe however please look further and you will find that this is beneficial.. better than so many legal substances on the market today widely available to people. Ban pain Meds! They ruin lives! People don't need them.  This is all we need.  I'm trying to be as upfront as honest as I can be.  I'm sorry if this comment isn't structured properly and or jumps around.  This is what is coming strait from my thoughts and emotions right now.  This is more important than trying to prepare a perfect comment for you to read because this is real. This is my life! My daughters life! My fapmily's life! Please do what's right. Please! Thank you for your time!

Lucas McElroy

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

I strongly oppose the scheduling of Kratom tea.

I am not a consumer of this herbal supplement but my sister is and it has allowed her to resume a normal life after a serious spinal injury, followed by dependence on opiate pain medications that completely changed her personality.   She tried to do the right thing.  She checked into a rehab center and came off the pain medication but her pain returned worse than before.   She couldnt attend family functions or play with her dogs.  She couldnt do much of anything but suffer until an older gentleman from the senior center told her about Kratom tea.

Ive watched her fight for years to regain something resembling a normal life.   And shes been able to manage that with this herbal supplement.    She still has a lot of pain but she says the tea helps her enough and shes happy.   Shes back to being the active, goofy person that I love. And you want to take that away from her?  From her family?     Youll destroy her.  And how many others?   Please think about this.   Peoples lives are in your hands now.   

Additionally I met a young lady who overheard me discussing the Kratom issue at the market.  She said she is currently drinking Kratom tea to try and help her through heroin recovery.   Shes been sober for only 3 weeks and she claims this tea helps her overcome her cravings.   Considering Ohio is averaging 8 deaths a week from heroin overdoses i would think anything that helps kids to get off that poison would be welcomed by our government.  Even a simple herbal supplement.

Id personally feel better if you focused on fighting the heroin problem we have in this country.  Or alcohol.   Have you read the statistics on alchohol related deaths?    Both of these things are killing people.   Kratom is doing just the opposite.  Its helping.  I find it shameful this harmless supplement has been put on the chopping block like some worthless street drug.  Especially since it's not a mind altering supplement.

Thank you in advance for taking the time to read this.

Sincerely,

Candace M. Jackson

documents.commentText:
DEA & whomever this may concern,

I have just recently heard about this ban on kratom.  I am a 45 year old male dealing with  chronic pain and have 2 herniated discs at L4-L5 and L5-S1 areas of my spine.  I used to be prescribed Morphine + Oxycodone.  I first heard about kratom online, and decided to try it out.  That was 2 years ago and I have completely stopped the expensive, dependent nature of the pharmaceutical drugs.  It's worked wonders for my back and even though I still feel pain, it's much less of an issue.  Even while on low doses of the drugs mentioned above, I would have some sort of awful side effect, but most of the time I had a lethargic lack of energy and was constantly numb.  I had no emotion.  That is what those drugs do to a person, at least it did for me.

I'm not saying those drugs don't have their place, but unlike kratom, those drugs are not only damaging to the user (easily overdose), but damaging to the friends and family of the person taking them.  It changes a person's personality and not for the better.  I lost a lot of friends because of my mood swings and all I cared about was taking my next pill.  I am completely fine with limiting Kratom to someone who is 21, if teenage use is an issue, but I personally never have had the bad withdrawals like I did from the harder prescribed opiates.  You also cannot overdose on Kratom, at least not to be life threatening, which is a huge benefit.   I hear it's also good for those folks with anxiety and depression, and it truly has saved my life and made me into a more productive person.  I can speak from experience that it helped me get off the harder drugs (which was still not easy), because I did my research on ways of quitting and this was the best option rather then go on another opiate (methadone), so I asked my doctor and showed him what I found. My DOCTOR gave me the "okay" to give it a try since it was legal and he was aware of reports of people getting off the hard stuff, which was extremely helpful.  This simple plant has been a life saver for me and I'm sure many others..

If the DEA does indeed ban Kratom, I and others like myself who have fought hard to live a good and reasonable life and to deal with the hand God has given me, would be in a very difficult position.  I don't want to go back on the hard drugs, but unfortunately that would be my only option as the pain can be so unbearable at times without my current kratom regimen.
 
Finally, I just wanted to talk about the scheduling it on the same level as HEROIN is being considered.  It's nothing like heroin (although I haven't tried that) but I have read about the effects and watch the news.  I don't want to be considered a criminal simply because I am trying to live my life and the last 3-4 years I've taken kratom without issue.  This all just doesn't make any sense, I don't know where it's coming from, and I really hope you understand that enforcing this will cause immense suffering to people like myself.  I have always respected the laws of our country and have fought to protect them, however this is the one that I can't stand behind right now since it will affect me personally at a level that others without chronic pain can't comprehend.  Where is the compassion?  I don't even know why or how this became an issue, since it's been legal for a very long time and I really don't want to go back to finding a doctor and living that old life again.  I'll also have a very hard time destroying the kratom I already have if it becomes illegal because of the benefit it provides, and I'll be stuck between the law and my well-being, because I have nothing else for the pain!  My wife is very worried about this as well, and found this site for me to make a post.  I'm not sure if anyone will read this, but it seems so outrageous.

Please reconsider adding this to the scheduled "drugs".  I have served my country and I believe this is an excessive use of force in applying these severe restrictions to something so small.  That's all I have to say.

documents.commentText:
Please consider keeping mytragina Speciosa (kratom) a legal herbal supplement.  I baffled behind the proposal to place it into the same legal category as such terrible drugs as heroin etc.  It's a plant in the coffee family, and about as dangerous as coffee or tea. Kratom is not an intoxicant!  It does not make a person high or "stoned" in any way!  And it's been used safely by many health-conscious citizens in this country for many many years (and for hundreds years more in S.E.Asia).

Kratom offers its users several benefits.  It is a non-opioid, and has been used by many Americans to withdraw from actual opiates such as heroin. Think of the irony of classifying kratom as a Schedule 1 substance when it helps people get *off* such terrible drugs!  It has been used by many to withdraw from--and stay off of--alcohol addiction.  It also offers pain relief for muscle strain or minor surgery.

I'm 64 years old, and a retired librarian.  I was diagnosed with clinical depression not long ago, and my doctors have put me on three or four different anti-depressant medications.  I read about kratom online, and tried it as a tea.  In a most remarkable way, a single cup of kratom tea, twice a day (one in the morning, one in late afternoon), helped me stay more clear and depression-free than any prescribed drug I tried!  And with no side-effects whatsoever! To this day, if I'm feeling a little down, every now and then, a cup in the morning really helps me start my day.  This plant has been a real boon to me, and an enormous ally in my fight against depression.  I beseech you not to take this away from the people like me, and the thousands of others who have found it so helpful in their lives.

Good afternoon,

I am a 39 year program coordinator for a local college, and I'm commenting in hopes to have my voice and story heard with why I strongly feel that kratom should not be banned, nor classified as Schedule 1.

I have been struggling with severe depression and anxiety for most of my adult life, but was made far worse when my father took his own life 3 years ago. Around that time, my depression and anxiety became highly debilitating and seemingly insurmountable. I had trouble sleeping, connecting with my family and loved ones, socializing, and holding a job. At one point I considered suicide. 

After researching herbal and healthier alternatives to prescription medication, I discovered kratom. Kratom has helped me manage my depression and anxiety, helped me regain focus and motivation, and helped me get my life back. In the three years I have incorporated kratom into my life I have never felt impaired or under the influence. I have never gotten sick or felt unwell because of it. Kratom has helped me in the same sense that chamomile tea has helped me rest, caffeine has helped me wake up, or St. John's Wort has helped me balance my mood. I see no reason why kratom should be banned or classified under the same scheduling as heroin. The effort to do so has been a waste of resources and money.

I implore the DEA to not ban kratom (mitragyna speciosa). Please do not make kratom a Schedule 1.

Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText: I am a concerned citizen that wants to give an opinion towards the intent to make kratom a schedule 1 controlled substance. I feel it will make things worse in a society that is plagued with drug addiction, it will make life difficult for those trying to manage pain without taking addictive prescription pills, and I feel it will cause a new problem with illegal drugs sales by forcing kratom to sit on  the black market. At this time we have been inundated with a large amount of heroin throughout our country, We have many individuals with pill habits that were stifled by concerned doctors that over prescribed addictive pain killers only to find those patients made even worse decisions by switching to a cheaper, even more addictive substance on the street. There are many individuals that curb their pain issues with kratom. I know some of these people. There are also many people in this country that have had a hard time quitting taking pain meds but found kratom and realized it is weak enough to stop using without withdrawal and strong enough to give themselves a false yet manageable feeling of pain relief while they ween themselves off of the pills they were addicted to. I know two individuals that have done this and have found many stories like theirs that relate. I feel by making kratom illegal it will still be consumed, but illegally. It would still be sold...but illegally. Many people will risk being caught just like with marijuana, drug dealers will manipulate the substance in ways to make more money and possibly making kratom more addictive by lacing it. I am all for regulation, I am all for leaving it be the way it is, but to ban it completely makes way to a waste of time for our criminal justice system and forces people to rely on even harder drugs to curb their addictions. documents.commentText:
I'm Jeff Sehorn, and I'm a high school teacher, and I've been using kratom for about three years. When I was a teenager, I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder. I was on psychiatric medication my entire adult life, but the medications still failed to entirely manage my symptoms. I was a straight A student in high school, but by the time I was in college, the symptoms of bipolar had gotten so severe, I barely managed to graduate college, and it took me six years. 

I've been a teacher for ten years now, and my symptoms became manageable enough that I can function at my job, but I was still plagued with breakthrough mood episodes, plus unpleasant side effects from the medication I was taking. About three years ago, when I was having a particularly bad day, a friend of mine offered me an herb that she said helps her. I was skeptical, as I view most herbal supplements as placebos at best, but I tried it anyway. I immediately felt normal in a way I had not felt in fifteen years. I began taking kratom regularly, and it has managed my bipolar symptoms entirely. 

At one point, I was taking 9 different medications for bipolar disorder. Several of them were just to control the side effects of other medications I was taking. I've been taking kratom alone for three years now, and these have been the best three years of my life, as far as having the symptoms of bipolar disorder under control. Also, as an interesting side effect, I also have irritable bowel syndrome, and kratom has completely put an end to those symptoms as well. When I noticed that it helped with that also, I did a little research online and found that there are people who take it specifically for that purpose. That wasn't something I had expected, and it was a pleasant surprise. 

Kratom has significantly improved my quality of life. I know there is discussion about whether it is addictive or not. I have noticed that if I go too long without taking any kratom, I start to feel some mildly uncomfortable side effects (yawning, eyes watering, slight restlessness), so I guess it may be addictive in that way, but it's less uncomfortable than what would happen if I would miss a dose of some of the prescription psychiatric medications I was taking, and it's not addictive the way other drugs of abuse, such as tobacco, are. When I quit smoking a few years ago, I definitely craved cigarettes, but I never crave kratom in that way if I am late in taking my next dose. I do experience a mild "discontinuation syndrome" from missing a dose of kratom, but I experienced much worse withdrawal symptoms from missing a dose of medications which were prescribed to me for bipolar disorder. 

My life is better from taking kratom, and I have come to absolutely no harm from it. It truly frightens me to think of having to live without it, and I know there are many people who feel the same. I hope that you make an informed, compassionate decision regarding kratom. There are many people who trust it to take care of our legitimate medical needs.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern, I would like to voice my opinion on the legal status of Kratom.  I am a middle-aged businessman, self employed for the last twenty years.  And just to be clear, I have never sold Kratom, or profited from the sale of Kratom in any way.  The following story is taken entirely from my own personal experience with Kratom.  

I have had the great misfortune of experiencing chronic pain as the result of an accident that occurred when I was very young.  For my entire life, I preached to my friends and family against the evils of prescription drugs use, but as the years passed, and my aches and pains began to surface with age, I fell prey to the allure of prescription opioids, which helped me make it through my hectic days.  I have always accepted my responsibilities as an American citizen, and continued to function as a contributing member of society, paying my taxes, employing others in my retail business, and voting at every possible opportunity.  But a relatively innocent year or two of prescription painkiller use soon turned into ten or eleven years, and my habit continued to grow until I eventually came to realize that I was a fully functional slave to my addiction.  I had progressively graduated to the strongest of opiates, and I was very addicted.  

I heard about Kratom from a friend, and decided to give it a try to belay some of the more serious side-effects I knew I would experience while attempting to quit painkillers.  I stopped all intake of opiates 'cold-turkey', and contrary to all of the television commercials that insist that you can't do it on your own, I was able to eliminate all prescription opioids from my life.  The process of withdrawal was intense, but I was determined to succeed.  I credit Kratom for playing an important role in helping to ease the symptoms of withdrawal and greatly contribute to my success.  I did my homework, and followed online suggestions for the dosage of Kratom I should take.  And after about two months of moderate Kratom use through this period of very serious opiate withdrawal, when I felt the time was right, I was able to completely discontinue the use of Kratom without any noticeable withdrawal or side-effects whatsoever.  I've been free of opiates for over a year now, without any outside influence or support groups or alternative prescription drugs.  

Kratom played an important role in releasing me from my addiction.  As we all read in the news every day, opiate addiction by Americans is an evil plague that sorely needs to be addressed on a large scale.  Normal people like myself can succumb to it's ease of availability and the temporary relief that it provides, but quitting opiates is near impossible for most people.  Kratom is new and relatively unknown in America.  If I hadn't heard of it from a friend, I probably never would have realized it's incredible benefits.  I feel that Kratom should remain legal as one possible option for Americans to treat their own addiction without help from society.  The financial drain of opiate addiction on our system is immeasurable, and any harmless tool that can be offered to help people deal with their addiction on their own should remain legal and readily available.  Kratom is not dangerous.  It's not addictive.  And it's continued availability may actually help ease the financial burden of dealing with opioid addiction in our society.  

It is my opinion that Kratom is similar to any natural source of caffeine or possibly an 'herbal tea', and it should be considered as such by the DEA and left as a legal uncontrolled herbal supplement to be used freely for any intended purpose by all Americans. 

Sincerely, 
Jay Lawrence

documents.commentText: I wanted to report my experience with Kratom to the DEA because I believe I suffered a problem because of it. I had never used it before. I ordered from a reputable online source and tried various strains at low amounts (1/8-3/4 teaspoons) mixed into yogurt or made into a tea. I wanted to try it to ease anxiety and bipolar symptoms. I had been taking 1/2 of a low dose Norco (rarely) and it made me feel better but I new those were bad to take so I did a seach to find something that would give me a similar effect. I must say that I can see where Kratom would help a person addicted to pain pills because i no longer wanted the Norco but the Kratom replaced it quite well and relieved some pain. BUT, I could tell you it seemed to me that after only a couple of doses I found myself mildly obsessed about it, wanting to take some everyday- like a mental addiction, not physical. The most important thing I want to report is that I become hypo thyroid after 2 months of using those small doses of Kratom (3-4X a week). Prior to using, a TSH test showed me at 4.6. I had noticed feeling very fatigued and went to the doctor and took a TSH blood test. My TSH was over 8.0-having doubled and meaning I was hypothyroid. I did some research on the internet and found 2 instances of this happening to others. One case citing severe hypothyroidism linked to Kratom addiction. And other small instance I cannot recall now. I am not sure the Kratom caused my thyroid problem but I suspect so. I had no other changes, diet, med, or otherwise that could have caused it. The Kratom was the only new substance I was putting into my body. Needless to say, I threw the stuff out and don't think that is safe for everyone and that it really needs more testing before people use it on a regular basis.. Thank you. Jeannie Reid

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern: 

I recently earned a B.S. in Psychology. I graduated with High Honors in the top 10% of my class, from an institution that enrolls over 30,000 students. I have never been accused of being a drug addict, a drug-seeker, or of being high. In one letter sent as a graduate program recommendation, a former professor described my research on the impact of comorbid post traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury in U.S. combat veterans as, "the most brilliant scientific content I have ever witnessed from an undergraduate student."

 I am a responsible, reasonable, and hard-working citizen of America, like many in the Kratom community. It is not reasonable or responsible to add Kratom to the list of scheduled drugs, therefore making myself and many other decent folks into felons. The short and long term consequences of making Kratom illegal will be so overwhelming it is impossible to estimate the damage that will be done to the overall good of society if law-abiding Americans are convicted and sentenced to harsh drug punishments for possessing what is simply an herbal dietary supplement. 

I find it is imperative to remind you that throughout the course of our history and the history of the world, we have paid immeasurable costs for decisions made against something, whether it be an idea, a race of people, or a plant, simply because it is relatively unknown, and therefore misunderstood. When we find ourselves in these unavoidable dilemmas, we must air on the side of rationality, patience, and objective thinking. Specifically with regards to Kratom, we must air on the side of scientific peer-reviewed, empirical research, and also distinguish between studies that are valid and reliable. Research from scientists who are paid by groups that have a financial investment in banning the plant are neither valid nor reliable, but instead produce skewed data due to biases and failures to isolate confounding variables. The limited amount of research to date on the benefits of ingesting the plant matter of Kratom suggests a world hope for some people who desperately need it. The answer is not allowing Pharmaceutical companies to monopolize the alkaloids and make them much more powerful and potent. This has been the guideline with other substances in the past, and this is why America is in the midst of suffering the biggest opiate crisis in the history of the world. 

Prescription opioids, whether they're obtained legally or illegally, have caused the deaths of hundreds of thousands of Americans by causing respiratory depression. I do not foresee history being kind to the administration that chooses to ban a non-opioid plant that shows promise as an opiate replacement, without the risk of death of respiratory depression, addiction, or death, as is the case with FDA approved substances. 

Although there will be naive people who will believe the lie that Kratom has killed 15 Americans, at least 14 of these Americans had other drugs in their system. Any high school student can tell you that these other variables in these people's systems are called confounding variables. You cannot link Kratom to death, essentially proving cause and effect, without eliminating these confounding variables (prescription drugs). 

I have been drinking Kratom tea for over 6 years, because it improves my quality of life. Just as regular exercise, a healthy diet, drinking water, and adding tumeric alongside my daily dose of magnesium has improved my quality of life. I am a better human being because of it, and I do not believe that banning Kratom is the right decision. It is not the right moral decision, nor is it the right scientific decision.

To  whom it may concern;
 
   My name is Beth Helton and this is my personal experience with Kratom and how it has affected my life.
 I personally am not a kratom user however my life has been greatly impacted by the effects of Kratom. 
My fianc is a user of Kratom. Back 5 years ago he was suffering from chronic pain in his hip which was making everyday activities and being a floor installer  a lot harder on him. He went to a doctor who took X-rays and diagnosed him with perthes a degenerative cartlidge disease. The X-ray revealed that his hip bone was in the shape of an ice pick and he no longer had any cartridge left son it was straight bone on bone grinding. It was causing tons of pain and was effecting his sciatic nerve and would leave him in tears after a long day of work and being a father to two little girls his life revolves around being up and moving, piggy back rides, and dancing with daddy. But he was in so much pain he couldn't do those things. His doctor who he was seeing at that time referred him to s specialists who decided his best relie for pain was painkillers. Instant relief he said. He was put on tramadol and after 2 weeks he had gone through a whole prescription which should of lasted a month. He went to his doctor and said they weren't strong enough and he had to take doubt to feel relief. His doctor then prescribed him something stronger loratabs. He asked his specialist what can they do long term to help maybe a hip replacement is something to look into and the specialist said, " no you are to young." He advised him to get with a primary doctor who would help manage his pain pills and surgery will be something to consider later down the road for now this will be a bandaid. What a nightmare that would become. We found a primary doctor who was happy to help feed him more pills. Never asking why or giving advise on new pain management treatments or any  physical therapy options. The next 3 years of our family's life had become a living nightmare. The man, the father, the son, the husband to be was gone. Our family was torn to pieces and hurting bad. During those 3 years I as a mother had to fight to protect my children from this lunatic and mad man he had become. My children where hurting and scared of their daddy most days. He was distant, cold, and heartless.  He no longer had time to spend with his children his time was occupied being in a comatose state after a long day of work and he had begun eating 12 to 14 pills a day of loratabs. He would spend his time in search of anything to feel again. He began trying new drugs just looking for that high again and drinking extremely heavy (a whole handle of tequila in a night). He was mixing his pills with other drugs and is was a roller coaster ride of highs and lows. From one day to the next it was a guessing game of how the day would go. He over dosed a few times. He would pass out in mid sentence, he would ramble on and make no since of what he was saying. He would become withdrawn and sketchy. And into the last year he began being abusive mentally, emotionally, and physically. We tried on several occasions to get him help and sober. We tried getting him off the pills but the withdrawals were unbearable for him. He had lost weigh and become very sickly looking. He was killing himself and there was no getting through to him.  After 3 years and many attempts I finally gave him the only option left he gets clean and off the pills no matter how hard the pain would be and find a docto to do the surgery or a new treatment that was safer or I would leave him and take the kids and never come back. He swor he'd get sober and didn't wanna lose his family. We began looking into new treatments. After many attempts he finally found what saved his life. KRATOM!  The last 2 years he has been completely clean and hasn't turned back. Kratom gave him his life back. He no longer drinks alcohol like he did before or has urges to get high on drugs. He has become a better man then before. He works hard to give his family everything they need and is happy and content. He no longer has to deal with pain the way he did before. Kratom has helped manage his longer term issues with his hip and as well got his through the with drawls after getting off the pain killers 2 years ago. He swears by Kratom and has even been able to reach out to others who have suffered drug problems, pain killer addictions and alcoholism and have changed their life's for the good since taking Kratom. I may not be a Kratom user myself but I've seen the benefits of Kratom as an outsider. My children and I have gotten back the man we love and are proud of the man he has become. Kratom saved his and our life's.

My name is Jillian, I am 28 years old from the Chicago area and have been using Kratom for the past six months. In 2014 I was diagnosed with AML (Actute Myeloid Leukemia) from which I developed deep cysts in my legs as well as permanent  neuropathy.  I am happy to announce I am currently in remission, but the devastating effects from my leukemia has left me with an abundance of symptoms. During my months in the hospital I was on a constant morphine drip, stopping the pain meds was probably what I looked forward to the most once I was told I was in remission, as I was vomiting at least twice a day for a solid year. I had no idea what I was in for. I can't describe the hell on Earth I experienced when I stopped taking my medicines. Not to mention that I had no options other than opioids for my constant leg pain. I went 6 months without leaving my house because I never slept. I could have gone back on my morphine but had to keep reminding myself staying off it was best for my overall health. I didn't work, I didn't go out to see friends, not even on holidays. I was in such a dark place (I also had lost my two brothers in a car accident years before) that many times I sat in my bathroom talking myself out of taking my life. Then my sister mentioned to me she had read an article on Kratom. Obviously I didn't want to go back on any actually traditional "medicine" but after reading the article and doing research I figured things can't get much worse so I'll give it a go. The first night I took a teaspoon I slept for EIGHT HOURS! I cried to my mom the next morning from sheer happiness. This has been my miracle. My daily headaches and shooting pains were almost non exsistant. I had energy back and felt human for the first time in years. Kratom has no weird effects on me, it's actually the only thing in this world that makes me feel normal, before I felt like I was on drugs naturally because I was so deeply depressed. Everything was wonderful for those few months, I even got a brand new job at a hospital. I am not taking any other prescribed drug. Then right as I was feeling my dark cloud going away, I read that Kratom was being banned. I had this flash of heat and dread creep over my body. I am begging whoever reads this please don't take this miracle away from people who are using it responsibly over a fear that doesn't exist. I don't want to go back to where I was, please do not ban Kratom. It truly saved my life. I never once felt unsafe fearful of side effects. I don't want to be on opioids anymore, or anti depressants. This is a real heartfelt plea. Thank you for reading my story.
Jillian Warner

documents.commentText:
I am a PhD candidate in Biomedical Sciences studying novel treatments for PTSD, Depression and other Psychiactric disorders including Addiction. Kratom is a very important plant. The alkaloids contained within it have an incredible capacity to partially modulate the opiod receptors without causing respiratory depression or other adverse side effects in most people. The side effect profile seems to be on par with or much milder than many over the counter or prescription drugs. It is not a dangerous plant and should be classified with similar status to caffeine. Due to this very mild partial opiod agonist activity, it has the capacity to modulate opiod withdrawal without the user becoming substantially effected by the drug. The legal, prescription alternative, Buprenorphine does not have this capacity. Although a partial agonist, Buprenorphine is extremely potent and has very obvious drug effects. The effects of Kratom do not very much exceed that of caffeine for most users. What if a heroine addict could feel normal with not much more than a cup of coffee and they could grow that plant at their home? It would be a massive improvement over suboxone and subutex which both can be abused no matter what big pharma wants you to think. Again, Buprenorphine is a VERY powerful and very addicting drug.. If Kratom is scheduled and not immediately available for prescription or over the counter purchase, thousands of users will be forced to turn back to much more dangerous drugs either from the pharmacy, the street or the internet (research chemical opiods)... 

 Kratom is also currently being used as an anxiolytic for those with PTSD, depression and anxiety. It has great success in some treatment resistant patients and again is far less addicting and dangerous than the typical prescriptions of SSRI's or Benzodiazepines. Those currently using it for affective disorders will also have to turn to more dangerous and addicting drugs in the case of its ban.

In small doses, I have personally used it as a substitute for caffeine and it offers a very clean-motivated state of mind without jitters like caffeine or the euphoria and side effects of amphetamines typically used for attention deficit disorder. I also spent 13 years of my life in blue collar labor cutting down trees and have severe back pain at times. I have previously been prescribed prescription pain medication and medium doses of Kratom are far superior to prescription opiods and Tramadol and do not have the side effects associated with these substances. I chose to use Kratom instead when I required medication and the plant itself was perfect. I had no need to turn to more powerful extracts and my tolerance actually went down over my use. It seems that when used responsibly, the user can actually be sensitized to the plant and may require less rather than more like prescription opiods.

Kratom should be available for those over 18 as should caffeine as both are similarly addicting. I realize that regulating caffeine at this point would be very difficult, but ideally, they should be treated with similar respect. The plant should not be classified as a dangerous drug. It is only a benefit to our society. I do however have concerns about its extracts and potential analogues. Any extracts of the plant or analogues of its constituents should be regulated, but the plant itself is nearly harmless and should be available to adults.

documents.commentText: If the DEA were to add Kratom to the list of schedule 1 narcotics, it would be a tone-deaf mistake which would cause me to question whether or not the organization is acting in good faith to protect the health of Americans. I have not used Kratom, but from what I understand there are several important facts regarding the substance. First, it is a naturally occurring plant. Second, it seems to be far safer than both other schedule 1 drugs and other legal substances (e.g., alcohol and tobacco). Third and perhaps most important, there is some evidence that it is helpful for people trying to overcome opiate addiction. The pharmaceutical industry and government regulating bodies are partly responsible for this epidemic. This makes it particularly egregious that they are considering a course of action which would limit individual freedom (something we value in this country) and prevent people who are struggling with addiction from helping themselves out of the hole they are in. We have already seen that those in charge of narcotics scheduling are unwilling to deal honestly with the American people, sidelining an initiative to remove marijuana from the schedule 1 list. This should have been an incredibly easy decision as marijuana meets almost none of the criteria put forward for schedule 1 status and no informed individual can honestly say it belongs on the list. And now the DEA is considering an overly aggressive action to add Kratom to this list without offering sufficient justification. This is utterly tone-deaf and would be a step in the wrong direction for drug regulation in this country.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has been a godsend to me since I discovered it a few years ago. I've had to deal with anxiety all of my life and have been put on every type of anti-depressant to try and alleviate what I have suffered for so long. Nothing quite seemed to work and the side effects of some of these medications were unbearable. Try titrating off Effexor while going to work and simply performing the necessities of life, I've never felt worse.

I finally got my anxiety somewhat under control with Citalopram and Xanax but as a result I was emotionally and mentally flatlined. It was not a life at all. I was just a shell of a person with zero desires as a result. This situation unto itself lead to depression and all that comes with it. I had IBS, my thoughts were that of a nihilist who was just hung up on life as a whole. The thought of living this way for the rest of my life consumed every minute of my life. Something had to change.

I came across Kratom from a military vet that I met at our local dog park. He used it for pain and he also alluded to it helping with what I assume was PTSD. He didn't really want to relive his past and how he got to using Kratom but he was pretty emphatic on how Kratom had helped him.

I sort of brushed it off but said I would give it a try. The following day he gave me a little bit and I told him I would try it. I took the pills that he had given me and about 30 minutes later I felt the effects. My inner dialogue that was always so negative seemed to have quieted for the moment. That alone was a relief. If anyone here has anxiety or depression you know what your inner dialogue / voice can do to you mentally.

What Kratom did was essentially alleviate all my negative thoughts for the moment. And within that moment I felt like my head was cleared and I felt optimistic. It wasn't euphoria, it was finally just a different mindset that none of the medication I had been on ever offered. At that moment I just cried, I felt something different which hadn't happened in a long time. I was just so happy to feel something other than my flatline self.

Since that day I have been using Kratom every other day. I got off all my other meds over the course of two months and that alone should be a reason for Kratom to be legal. I know it helps people with opiod withdrawal but I'm here to state that it helps with the ever-so-cumbersome withdrawal from anti-depressants and controlled substances like Xanax.

That is essentially my story and how Kratom has given me life again in some respect. My anxiety isn't completely gone by any means, but I'm managing it in a different and natural way. I gained 15 pounds while on anti-depressants and that is gone as well. Depression can also lead to IBS which I had and as a side benefit Kratom helped me with that affliction as well.

To ban Kratom is to hand some users back to the medicines that didn't work or made them feel "better" by completely blunting our emotions and personality. That is a road I never wish to go down again. The fact of the matter is that I have an imbalance that is anxiety for whatever reason. This is how I'm wired and it is something I have to deal with for the rest of my life. I didn't choose to have anxiety. I wish I was a med-free functioning soul but it has never been in the cards for me. I've been afflicted with anxiety since I can remember a child.

I should be able to use Kratom as I have so that I do not have to go back to what I was on. This should be my choice and my choice only. Please do not take this option away from me and hand me back to the mental health industry that has given me the million dollar work up only to let me down. I can't go back to such a life.

I would like to let you be aware of my opinions regarding Kratom; not only as a herb but as an alternative to METHADONE, SUBOXONE and other anti-opiate pharmaceuticals. documents.commentText:
My name is Marcy. I am 22 and a junior at the University of Texas at Austin, on my way to obtaining my Bachelor of Science in Computer Science. I've worked for a small business doing systems administration for 3 years now. I am financially independent of my parents, paying for university in part myself and in part through federal funding. I am sober, thanks to kratom.

One year ago, I was technically homeless after having been kicked out of where I lived because of an addiction. I was not in school, for I had dropped all of my classes six months before, because of a different addiction. Although I held the same job I do now, I struggled to manage even part time hours. I have struggled with addiction since my early teens, mainly with alcoholism. I kept it together reasonably well in high school and part of college, excelling academically and managing to hide the issue from everyone around me, but such a facade cannot last forever, and it didn't.

About 6 months ago, I attempted for the umpteenth to quit, but this time I used kratom tea to do it. Although it was still an ordeal weening myself off of alcohol, kratom made it possible.

Let me be clear: kratom tea did not replace alcohol. Kratom allowed me to adjust to the psychological impact of sobriety because it is so mild. I regained my ability to have fun while sober by drinking kratom tea in the interim. I could not treat kratom tea like alcohol because drinking more than a small amount makes my stomach hurt. I cannot properly express how grateful I am that such a thing exists.

I am not opposed to all legislation, I understand many are concerned about various long-term effects it may have. I am opposed to keeping kratom out of the hands of people who really need it by making it Schedule I. I am opposed to treating kratom like heroin without regard to the consequences. I implore you to research it, find out scientifically its benefits, but also listen to the comments submitted to you and do the right thing.

Thank you very much for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am commenting to voice my opposition to Kratom being placed on the Schedule of Controlled Substances.  Kratom is an organic botanical that's been safely used for centuries to help people cope with many different chronic pain conditions without the use of opioid pain medications. 

Considering the current opiate abuse epidemic our nation is experiencing, banning or restricting an herbal supplement that helps people avoid using prescription opiates by classifying Kratom as a controlled substance would cause irreparable harm to thousands of American citizens.  Kratom's potential for abuse is also extremely low.  According to Walter C. Prozialeck, a professor of pharmacology at Midwestern University who has studied Kratom extensively, [T]he amount [of kratom] that a person has to take in to get any severe effects is ridiculously high. Youre talking 10 to 15 grams of raw leaf. Most people who are using kratom for pain management dont take that much. Most people cant take that much. (Nick Wing, Some Say Kratom Is A Solution to Opioid Addiction. Not If Drug Warriors Ban It First, Huffington Post, updated Sept. 7, 2016, 8:38 am, www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/kratom-ban-drug-policy_us_56c38a87e4b0c3c55052ee3f).

Despite some sensational media reports to the contrary, Kratom's safety is clear when compared to coffee, alcohol, tobacco, and prescription drugs.  DEA's emergency scheduling NOI cited 660 Kratom-related calls to poison control over a six-year period ending December 2015, but the NOI failed to put that number into perspective.  For example, in the past six years, poison control has received 23,203 calls for caffeine, 66,300 for essential oils, 1,464 for Echinacea, 681 for Ginkgo Biloba, and 1,173 for St. John's Wort.

Many people have been using Kratom for years with no ill effects, and Kratom's support of their health and well being helps them to continue to be productive, tax-paying, voting members of their communities.  Please do not compound our country's health and addiction problems by banning or restricting a supplement that so many people are using safely and responsibly.  

Sincerely,
Robin Martin-Emerson

documents.commentText:
Thank you for allowing me to have the opportunity to comment on the DEA intent to schedule mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine (Kratom).

  My name is Derrick Edwards and I am 39 years old. I live in north Florida and I am currently employed as a Deputy Sheriff at my local Sheriff's Office and have been employed there for 18 years. Approximately two years ago, I was suffering from lower back pains caused by spinal stenosis and spondylolisthesis. I was prescribed hydrocodone by my doctor to help deal with the pain. I am aware of the addiction that comes with taking hydrocodone and the damage it will cause to my body and I did not want to be in that situation. After 8 to 10 months of taking the prescription, I started looking for an alternative and natural ways to deal with the pain. I have never heard of kratom before until I came across it in my research and decided to give it a try. I have been taking kratom now for almost a year and it has been wonderful. My pain is minimal and it does not make me drowsy like the pain meds did. Kratom is not a drug and it does not impair my judgement or vision.  I stopped taking kratom for a few days to see if there were any side effects including withdraws and I was fine, other than my pain level increasing. I introduced kratom to a family member of mine who was an alcoholic to see it kratom would maybe help him. He has been taking kratom now for about six months and has not had a drink since. Kratom has helped me so much and possibly saved my family members' life from alcohol abuse. Scheduling kratom would be devastating and cause me to go back to these harmful medications and my family member back to alcohol. It makes sense to allow adults to have the decision to take kratom to help them in life. I see good hard working Americans taking kratom to help them in their lives. I would also like to add that as a deputy for many years, I have never responded to someone's house because of kratom. As a deputy, I have never spoke with an individual who was looking for help because of kratom. Please do not schedule this natural plant. Thank you for your time.

   D. Edwards

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern:

My name is Marla Hernandez. I am 28 years old and though I hold a degree in human development, I cannot work in my field because I am disabled due to complications from Cystic Fibrosis. I am writing to let you know that I respectfully opposed the DEA's proposal to make the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine schedule 1 substances.

I have been using kratom for 3 years as an herbal supplement that helps reduce my symptoms of anxiety, akathisia, and pain from chronic inflammation in my body-especially my lungs and joints. Before I knew about kratom, I was bed ridden with pain and at the same time tormented with the inner restlessness caused by akathisia which I developed from the use of antidepressants and anti-anxiety medications. It seemed I could only function if I took narcotic pain medicine. I was frustrated and felt trapped in my situation and decided to look for alternatives. I researched online for natural forms of pain relief and came across the mention of Kratom. I was skeptical in trying it because nothing had helped me up to that point. But I was looking for anything so that I could have some quality of life returned to me. Once I began to supplement with Kratom, I noticed a huge improvement. I was able to use less and less narcotic pain medicine until I didn't need it at all anymore. Also, Kratom helped to calm the intense restlessness and pain I felt from the akathisia. Since then, I have been able to return to exercising, I can do chores around me house, something I couldn't do before, and I actually feel happy. I used to pray for either healing or death because I could not fathom existing any more in the state I was in. I believe God answered my prayers by guiding me to find Kratom. 

If you make this natural herb illegal, please consider that you will be crippling many people who like me, suffer from pretty serious disabilities and you'll be sentencing them to a very poor quality life. Please do not take the people's right to use a supplement that helps them have a more normal life. I do not know what I will do if I have to go back to depending on narcotics that after a while have no effect and back to living with the agony that is the restlessness of akathisia. The thought is unbearable. 

Thank you for reading my story and considering it as you make your decision.

documents.commentText:
Good Morning, 
My name is McKenzie and I am both a full time university student and full time assistant manager at my neighborhood's favorite cafe. I am strongly requesting that you please reconsider placing kratom on the list of Schedule 1 Controlled Substances. I have been using kratom on and off for about two years now, generally a couple of times a week at most. I was first introduced to kratom by a coworker of mine when we were discussing methods of reducing and controlling anxiety and I am infinitely glad I listened to their advice. I struggle with fairly severe generalized and social anxiety and moderate depression. Combined that often resulted in me having panic attacks while on campus and having to hide in a school bathroom until they passed, missing class, or being physically unable to force myself out of bed in the mornings to go to class because I felt like I could hardly breathe and was too nauseous to move without  potentially throwing up. As much as I wanted to succeed in my classes I was struggling  with the possibility of academic suspension simply from the number of classes I physically could not attend. Even though I knew I needed help I was terrified to go to doctor and be stuck taking prescribed drugs indefinitely especially based on all the terrible experiences many of my friends have had taking that route which only worsened their problems. When I began taking kratom, for the first time perhaps since middle school, I felt normal being at school. I felt like I could fully focus on the professor and subject matter without my head swirling in a thousand different directions and constant state of apprehension and fear for no real reason. Just being able to raise my hand in class if I have a question or answer to the professor's question like any other student felt so freeing and completely new to me. Despite the fact that I have been using kratom fairly regularly for the past two years and found it extremely helpful, I have never found it to be addictive in anyway. To put kratom in the same schedule as such highly addictive, dangerous, and damaging drugs like heroin feel extremely  wrong to me as it has none of those properties. It is simply a harmless dietary supplement that many people find very helpful in their lives, often when nothing else has worked for them. Taking this option away from people before scientists can even fully discover all of it's medical benefits feels like a greatly missed opportunity when it could potentially improve the quality of life of thousands of Americans. I would like to strongly urge you to  reconsider scheduling kratom as such, and also to thank you for taking the time to read this. I think allowing this open discussion where people can share their stories and experiences  is a very smart way to  decide on a topic such as this.

documents.commentText:
The proposition of the DEA to schedule mitragyna speciosa and it's active alkaloids (mitragynine and 7-OH-Mitragynine) is an absolutely ludicrous overreach with no scientific or social backing whatsoever. 

First off, how can a compound with similar molecular activity as our most useful pain killing agents, and that has been used for hundreds of years by natives of South East Asia, and for decades in the USA, without having a clear and acute correlation to health problems, be deemed as not having any medical value?

Second, the unique properties of mitragynine include a molecular mechanism for slowing down opioid tolerance (thus opioid addiction) and a lack of respiratory depression (the fatal property of every other opioid).

If this plan, and its active compound, is made illegal, American researchers will not be able to take part in studying this very unique compound, which may very well hold the key to creating a new generation of less addictive and less deadly pain killers.

Let me repeat myself, because this is a crucially important point that you must understand. While mitragynine has opioid pain killing properties, it has been found to not only be less addictive, but when derivatives are co-administered with morphine, even decreases the addictive properties of morphine itself. Most importantly, THERE IS NO EVIDENCE THAT MITRAGYNINE CAUSES RESPIRATORY DEPRESSION, which is the reason that addicts overdose on traditional opiates.

This study found reduced potential for opioid addiction when a mitragynine derivative is co-administered with morphine: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18550129

These studies found no respiratory depression in kratom users, or -arrestin-2 recruiting, the enzyme pathway responsible for traditional opiate side effects like respiratory depression (remember, respiratory depression is the reason so many are dying from opiates in this country): https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4425236/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27556704

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jmedchem.6b00748?source=cen&

Apart from the research that needs to be allowed to continue, apart from the potential billions of dollars you'd be cheating the USA out of with the development of mitragynine-based next generation pain killers, you need to realize that there are many people out there who had been hopelessly addicted to strong opiates (which could kill them at any time by being slightly too strong), but were able to get off of them by using a leaf that is all but impossible to overdose on (you refuses to release details on the 15 overdoses that you claim took place over three years , and regardless, 150 people overdose on Acetaminophen PER YEAR, but the DEA isn't banning Tylenol).

By using small amounts of this leaf, some have been able to get their lives back without having to resort to the stupefying effects of expensive pharmaceuticals like suboxone (which still hold the risk of death by respiratory depression). All the DEA will accomplish with this measure, is ensure that such people get thrown back into the gutter, while simultaneously banning the most promising next gen pain killing compound to date. This ban is a totally baseless overreach by the DEA that will only serve to make things worse for addicts, researchers, and the general public. This ban cannot be allowed to go through, the DEA cannot be allowed to cut next gen opioid research off at the knees, while simultaneously ensuring that we will see an increase in opiate deaths, an epidemic you claim to be trying to alleviate.

Going forward with this mitragynine ban is socially irresponsible, morally deplorable, and scientifically unwarranted. Please make the right decision, stand with the public, and withdrawal any intention to ban mitragyna speciosa and its active alkaloids. Thank you for your time and consideration.

Joe Moore.

documents.commentText: I help with local substance abuse recovery groups and it is clear that Kratom is not the benign panacea it is purported to be.  It is associated with tolerance, dose escalation, compulsive use, addiction and then severe (dose and duration of use dependent) and often protracted withdrawal.  Most  medical facilities have Kratom withdrawal protocols in place and they largely mimic those used for classic opioids.  What we see in the recovery groups is that people develop tolerance over time, escalate dose or frequency of dosing, and then get into trouble. Whether or not the plant should be legal is up for public debate, but what is certain is that many people are being misled.  The plant comes with many of the liabilities associated with classic opioids, to deny this is ignorant and very likely criminal.
