documents.commentText:
Although Kratom has potential benefits in the medical community, it absolutely should not not be a legal substance. I started taking Kratom in mid-august for back pain, depression, and anxiety. Although it works very well for those issues- it ABSOLUTELY is an addictive band-aid. 

Kratom and it's alkaloids attach to the MU receptor, which sends a release of dopamine and endorphins. Kratom also has a profound effect on serotonin in the brain.  Of course that is going to help anyone who is in a depressive state or anxious- BUT anything that activates the MU receptor like that absolutely causes an immediate tolerance and physical dependence on the substance.

I see others say they had "no withdrawls", and are touting it as a magical substance- all incorrect. 

Over the course of a few months I had gotten myself up to a "high dose" of Kratom, and got food poisoning, which disallowed me from eating it one day. I went straight into withdrawals.

Skin crawling, sweating, writhing in bed, hallucinations, and suicidal ideations. It was a fucking living nightmare. I absolutely turned on the plant when it revealed it's dark side. 

Most people are loving Kratom- because it works so damn effectively. Just like other drugs of abuse! Kratom addiction is very similar to a Tramadol addiction and withdrawl. Maybe not heroin, but absolutely kiddie heroin.

In the end I spent 8 days in the hospital due to Kratom. The doctors had seen it before. Intense Kratom withdrawals.

I urge all who take this plant daily to realize that it does cause addiction in those prone to it, and it absolutely causes physical dependency.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to you in regard to the upcoming scheduling of m. Speciosa (kratom), a relative of the coffee plant.  I wish to share the impact this herbal medicine has had on me, and my mother.

First of all, my mother takes it exclusively to stem the gastrointestinal side effect of a prescribed ssri, Cymbalta.  Without her one teaspoon of kratom daily, she would have constant, unpredictable diarrhea.  After decades of trial and error, Cymbalta is the only medication she has had that helped issues of PTSD and depression, and kratom is the only medication (counting prescriptions) that has allowed her to leave the house.  Now, she can travel to visit friends in her town, go grocery shopping, and even travel out-of-state to see her only grandchild.  Kratom vastly improved the quality of my mother's life, and she has taken it for years underneath the supervision of her primary care physician.  She does not drink alcohol, and does not use any illegal substances.  Kratom is not a recreational drug for her, and her dosage has never increased.

I, like my mother, have suffered the alienating and frightening effects of PTSD and major depression since adolescence.  My effects originated in different circumstances, but like her, after years of unpleasant psychiatric medication roulette, diligent cognitive behavioral therapy, traditional psychoanalysis, EMDR, I have found a medication that works.  Again, I deal with the side effects of an ssri that diminish my productivity and ability as a parent and citizen, has harmed my promising career, and has left me basically housebound.  Paroxetine reduces my symptoms to a more manageable level, but leaves me with extreme fatigue.  Prescribed pharmaceutical remedies have failed me. Coffee leaves me overstimulated, and amplifies my startle reflex and anxiety.  Kratom, on the other hand, I can take as needed, without becoming agitated.  It helps relieve my fatigue and my social anxieties, so much so that I have volunteered with an elementary school reading program, have taken on leadership positions in wilderness guidance for the Girl Scouts, and can travel without my husband. For the first time in my adult life, since my sexual assault, and its subsequent trauma, I can wear a bathing suit to the beach or pool.

My family life, my parenting abilities, my marriage, and my community have all benefitted from the gentle benefits that kratom has provided to me.

I was prescribed Xanax as an adjunct to my ssri.  Cautious due to a family history of addiction, I did not continue that prescription.  I have stopped my use of kratom for weeks at a time, just to make sure I was able.  Kratom has more manageable dosing, as its effects are subtle.

Perhaps instead of scheduling an ancient herbal medicine that has killed no one, and also helped to combat the scourge of prescription opiate deaths and addiction, m. Speciosa should be regulated.  Adding a new phantom in the failed War on Drugs will not put the United States of the right side of history: think about how destructive marijuana scheduling has been to families, communities, snd society.  Maybe a better use of American medical research funding would be to study our broken mental healthcare, addictive drug rehabilitation, and pain management structures. 

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Hello,  
 
My name is Laura Stevens; I am a yoga teacher, and a paralegal. I have used Kratom multiple times since 2010, with no negative effects. Kratom is a simple herb, with side effects similar to coffee. The plant itself is in the coffee family (Rubiaceae). Kratom is a leaf from a tree. The leaves of the tree can be crushed and made into tea (preferred method). The effects of Kratom are gentle mood boost (like coffee), and a mitigation of pain. Although Kratom interacts with opiod receptors, like cheese and chocolate) it is not an opiate.  
Depressed breathing is the cause of death via opiate consumption. Kratom does not cause depressed breathing. 
 
There is an opiate epidemic in the United States. In 2014 over 14,000 humans died in the United States from prescription opiates. The profit-seeking-system that caused this epidemic, needs to be quelled. Kratom is a save, natural alternative to the dangers of doctor prescribed opiates. In September I lost a close friend from an overdose (depressed breathing). Hes gone forever, and every day I think about how I could have saved him by introducing him to Kratom to get him off of the opiates.

Please consider us, as Americans and our constitutional right to the pursuit of pain-free happiness by not scheduling this wonderful plant.  
 
Thank you for your time,  
 
Laura Stevens

documents.commentText:
I am submitting 14,196 petition signatures from U.S. citizens urging the DEA not to schedule kratom as a schedule I substance and to leave the drug unscheduled.

These signatures were collected via an online Care2 petition, the entirety of which you can view here: http://www.care2.com/go/z/kratom 

The petition has gathered over 39,500 total signatures - I have included signatures only from signers with a verified United States mailing address and email address here. Please contact me if you have questions. The 14,196 of us who have signed the petition endorse the following comment (some signers have adding additional, personal comments, viewable in the PDF):

We the undersigned urge the DEA not to make kratom a Schedule I substance, which would criminalize all those who use it and designate it as having no known medical use. Many Americans use kratom to handle chronic pain, beat opioid addiction, wean off alcohol, fight depression, and relax. 

Farmers and indigenous people have used kratom for hundreds of years. Veterans coping with PTSD, recovering alcoholics, and people with fibromyalgia are all among those who say they have benefited from the drug.

It is misguided and draconian to make these people into criminals if they try to use the drug.

The DEA must stop profiting from banning natural medicines like marijuana and now, kratom. The DEA continually demonstrates zero regard for the fact that these substances help people to relax, get off side effect-laden pharmaceuticals, handle chronic pain, battle depression and anxiety, and more. The government must respect its citizens' bodily autonomy and the option to choose natural medicines over pharmaceuticals.

Do NOT make Kratom a Schedule I substance!

Thank you,
Julie Mastrine
Activism Marketing and Social Media Manager
Care2.com

documents.commentText:
I am 35 years old & have struggled with depression, alcoholism & substance abuse for just under 2 decades.  I am what some might call a functioning addict although towards the end of my drinking & pill popping career things began to spin out of control as I took pills all day (every day) & was spending lots & lots of money  money that should have been used to support my family or put away.  My attitude was erratic & I would suffer high highs & low lows  all of this held me back at work & caused rifts in my personal relationships.
I sought help from a psychiatrist who specialized in addiction & went on Suboxine, which did help me somewhat for about 2 years ... it would also keep me up at night & made me feel horrible in the morning.  I found that Suboxine was pretty addictive as well & I would need to take it every few hours in order to function.  When I eventually came off of Suboxine, the withdrawals were an absolute nightmare  even worse than pills like Vicodin & Percocet.  I then found myself in an anxious & depressed state long after the drug had cleared my system.  Fearing that I would have to go back on Suboxine (or worse) I found Kratom.  
Kratom is a natural, reasonably priced substance with effects that are less intense than the drugs mentioned above & since I began taking Kratom, I have gotten my life back to full form both professionally & personally.  I work for a major media company & have been promoted at work since I began taking Kratom ...  my wife & I just purchased a new home & our relationship is stronger than ever ... friends & family consider me a person that they go to for support & stability whereas I used to just bring chaos into their lives & often times violence  these are tough things to admit, but they are the truth.  I also just want to add that physically, I am in the best shape Ive been in since I was a teenager.
Kratom helps me with my anxiety, depression & substance abuse.  It has been 4 years since I had a drink, 4  without a pill & 2  years without Suboxine.  Kratom is not heroin or LSD.  Kratom is not K2 or Bath Salts.  if Kratom is taken off of the market, it will impact my life & most likely not for the better & I know that there are others out there like me, so please keep that in mind before making a decision on banning this substance.

documents.commentText: My name is Erik Wymer. First off I am very relieved about the open comments. I am 21 year old and am a recovering opiate/heroin addict. I also suffer from Bipolar disorder, Severe anxiety, and depression. I would like to start by saying, I would not be where I am in life today without Kratom. I discovered the plant about 2 maybe 3 years ago. At that point, I was homeless, Jobless, carless, and stealing. When I couldn't afford to get my fix anymore I got to the point where I just wanted to take my life. So I got help. Ive been in and out of rehabs put on a numerous amount of medications that only made me feel more dead inside, or as if I was being lied to. Methadone, Sub, ect. all those things made me feel like I wasn't actually getting clean. I stopped treatment. eventually fell back into the same habbits. I remember when I was debating on whether I should end my life or give treatment another shot, an old friend of mine who currently works at a head shop got ahold of me. He said something along the lines of "Hey man, You don't look so good, I know whats been going on, come into my shop tomorrow I need to talk to you about something, please". So I pondered what he was talking about. I went into the store the next day and he told me about "Kratom" It sounded farfetched and too good to be true, but at that point I was willing to give anything a shot.II had bought a 14 gram bag of a strain called, "Bali" When I got home, feeling anxious, I mixed about 3 grams into a glass of water and chugged. Uncertainty started to rise as I felt nothing. It did nothing, I was left in disapointment. I thought maybe ill just do this cold turkey. After day 2 of quitting the withdrawls were way to intense I was sweating, Puking, not eating and on the toilet what felt like every living moment of the day. So I tried kratom again in hopes that it would do something.. I waited... waited.. nothing.. So I ran into my room searching for something sharp to slit my wrists.. then I felt lighter. My symptoms were slowly being relieved. I stopped and sat there. everything I had anticipated was coming true. It was like a miracle. No a gift from God. I had found the answer to all my questions. I have been clean from heroin for almost 2 years now.. I have been able to get off 10mg of Klonopin A day, 60mg of Prozac a day, and off 50mg of seroquel a day. I went from being all these things, To working 2 full time jobs, I own a car, I have my own place, Im off drugs and medications, I'm even off Kratom at this point and have went "straight edge" Kratom saved my life, and has gave me the strength to believe I can do anything I want. This PLANT that isn't even chemically altered has saved many lives other than mine. It is a safe alternative to Pharmaceutical opiates that have been killing people for years. This ban has disgusted me. Alcohol a substance that offers NOTHING BUT RECREATIONAL USE is legal and has killed more people than things deemed illegal. Kratom, does offer recreational use but It also offers people a chance at getting their life back.. More safe than alcohol. Our voices need to be heard Kratom should remain legal and not scheduled.

documents.commentText: Kratom is not a cure-all medicine, a perfect high, or a crucified god-send. It is, however, an alternative. An alternative to the alcoholic who just can't seem to sleep without a few drinks. An alternative to the pill addict who can't stop swiping from his mom's medicine cabinet. An alternative to the man or woman who can't even go to work because of crippling anxiety. There are thousands of people like this who cannot find their way out, no matter how easy it seems. What they need is something to replace these self-destructive habits that does not deleteriously impact their life. Kratom can, and does, supply this in spades. Yes, it has psychoactive effects, and people can use it to get "high", but how many substances are legal and readily available that cause so much worse than kratom? It is a plant, and has aided thousands of people around the world to combat a variety of ailments and/or mental disorders. To deny the public an effective form of treatment such as this is to take a step backward in society. Please consider what is truly right.

documents.commentText:
My name is Chris Pizzino, an 11 yr Army Vet.   I fought in the Iraq's Sunni Triangle in 2004, Iskandariya, Iraq  06-08, And Afghanistan 09-10.  As you can imagine it changes you,  you lose something that you can never get back.    The Army tried filling that void with multiple combinations of anti depressants, anti-anxiety , antipsychotics etc.  That made me worse,  I got divorced and lost my kids.  I tried percocets and got addicted, I found what I lost, a sense of happiness (or so I thought).  I got out of the Army and graduated to heroin.  I spent $8,000.00 in 2 months. 

    Either I  was going to die or do something unthinkable to maintain my habit.  I tried getting into rehab but for the $16,000.00 price tag it was impossible.  I luckily found a cash only Suboxone prescriber.    I was taking 24mg a day for one year.  I asked how long I have to be on this,  he said minimum 5 years.  Suboxone is worse than heroin in my opinion.  I started to ween myself off.  Over the course of 1year, I successfully weaned down to 1/16th of one pill.   Against his guidance.  I tried to quit, but I couldn't take that final step,  I didn't want to get high, so I maintained the 1/16th dose until I heard of Kratom.  I read that kratom could help with withdrawals.  So I purchased the ground leaf.  It did little,  so I ordered the potent extracts which did effectively help.  And yes there was a high with the extracts, but I was tired of being out of it all the time and needed to get my life back so I could fight for custody of my kids.  


     I slowly switched from extracts to lower doses (2 TBS) of powdered leaf three times a day.  Over the course of 1 year I am now down to  TSP 2-3 times a day.  Since getting off of suboxone I look 10 years younger, I've gained my weight back, I am a  functioning member of society again, I am winning this custody battle, and in a wonderful relationship.  Oh and I have not gotten sick since starting kratom,  I do not get flu shots,  so I know for a fact there is medical properties in this wonderful plant.   It healed me, and its a plant.  So basic, yet so effective.     

     So in my experience a simple plant did more than years of trying the myriad of FDA approved medications, even heroin.    Please take this into consideration before labeling me a felon drug addict.  





Sincerely, Chris Pizzino

documents.commentText:
Thank you for this RFC.  

Living in Oklahoma has taught me how dangerous our War on Drugs is to a local economy and its citizens.  We lead in opiod abuse across in all age groups, and local research has shown we consume 9.2 kgs of morphine equivalent per 100,000 residents.  Oklahoma has traditionally been incredibly stringent on drugs, and it is causing severe damage to our society.  And while Narcan is now carried by some emergency services groups, only one pharmacy location in our capital city of 3.5mln people even carries it.  Additionally, local policies against drug paraphernalia cause individuals to resort to dangerous options (such as re-using needles), spreading disease and misery through HIV and HEP C at levels which devastate lives, as well as create churn in our over burdened medical systems through increased costs in our broken pharmaceutical system and CDC resources.  Policies like what was being proposed are the reason why Oklahoma jails are filling up (1.3% of our population is incarcerated) and there is no evidence that increasing this number will do anything short of bankrupt our already financially burdened state.  

Clearly, our approach to drug scheduling and raising the barrier to entry to drugs is not a viable solution.  I believe fully that any government policy which places policy over the physical welfare of it's citizens is dangerous, misguided, and morally corrupt.  

Kratom is one herbal solution, and while not perfect, solutions which decrease overall social misery is what we need to focus on as a nation if we are to better our way of life, solve our criminal justice system, and remove dependency on dangerous drugs.  Our life spans are shrinking despite research in advanced medicine and a virtually unlimited amount of money being spent through public and private initiatives.  

Anecdotally, I have several friends who routinely use various herbal remedies for various purposes (bodybuilding, pain relief, sleep aids, etc), and kratom is such an example of one.  No harm has come to them, and to place this drug as CDS seems to be reactionary and without scientific basis. 

I am looking forward to the day when we can treat chemistry and medical science in a methodical way which prioritizes drugs on a spectrum of harm to individuals and society, instead of the out-dated FDA's definition of "abuse potential".  Getting the right chemicals to the right individuals is a task that goes well beyond the DEA - it belongs to FDA, our doctors, police, court systems, our drug companies, farmers, substance abuse counselors, and individual patients.  Only a holistic view with public health as a concern is our hope to end the death and misery the war on drugs caused.  

Our current system places drugs such as anabolic steroids on par with morphine, where the former is medically as safe as horseback riding and the latter more akin to russian roulette.  We have depression medication handed out en masse in a nation where suicide is the 10th most likely cause of death, but these are largely considered a legend drug.  The scheduling of drugs makes no sense in a world where data driving analysis is the norm and people are willing to relocate to new states and countries to pursue individual health. 

Perhaps the closest analog to kratom's ban was the Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2014, which placed Pro hormones (chemicals which convert to anabolic steroids) as CDS III.  Bodybuilders and casual gym enthusiasts want quality results from their time in the gym, but with anabolic steroids being banned, they were forced to resort to more dangerous drugs (prohormones), which are known to be highly liver toxic and dangerous for users.  As individual chemicals kept getting added to the list, more and more dangerous versions (sometimes multi-stage derivatives to standard steroids) are being used.  

Similarly, krocodile made it to the scene as heroin was cracked down by law enforcement... and before heroin, morphine and opium.  The average lifespan of a krocodile user is only 3 years, all of which are perhaps the most brutal one can imagine.  With every addition to the list, we are producing another set of addicts, another set of drugs, and another set of problems for our society. 

Let's be fully clear - adding kratom to the controlled substance list does not save lives.  It will destroy them.  

I look forward to working with the DEA, FDA, and the Congress in any capacity I can which will help prioritize and schedule drugs based upon risk, benefits to the patient, cost to the individual, and cost to society as a whole.  

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
I am a 37 year old nurse.  I work for a large provider of mental health services with a state mental health program.  I suffer a chronic inflammatory condition that affects my joints, skin, and muscles and have been prescribed various types of pain management.  One of the hallmark symptoms of my condition is chronic pain.  I've tried several anti-inflammatory medications available by prescription and OTC, which ultimately led to severe stomach ulcerations.  I cannot use anti-inflammatory medications without having nosebleeds and worsening stomach ulcerations.  I used opioid pain medications under the care of a doctor with great success at times.  However, this came with many side effects.  And despite the negative effects, my body (and my mind) required more.  The therapeutic value decreases as the need for more increases.  I was eventually prescribed a very strong medication that caused severe and constant migraines, complete loss of appetite, severe and unrelenting depression. I was ready to end my life.  I finally destroyed the rest of my prescription because I was so sick of the constant migraines and the dysphoria.  I had missed multiple days of work during the course of my treatment related to pain and the depression that follows.  I had used my short term disability already through Prudential and was planning the application process for Social Security Disability with the help of an attorney.  I spent months reading and digging for answers on suppression of inflammation, pain reduction methods, and alternative treatments.  I read about kratom and decided to give it a shot.  I was happy with the results after a few days of supplementing with kratom.  It didn't kill all of the pain like prescription pain killers did.  But I didn't expect that.  All I wanted was a tolerable level of pain without the brain fog, without the drowsiness and depression.  Kratom gave me just that.  I started eating again, as my GI tract returned to normal motility. Kratom seemed to reduce the symptoms associated with GI inflammation.  I was able to think clearly again.  I was able to have emotions again.  I started lifting weights and walking, then slowly worked my way to jogging.  When I returned to work, my work life was much more stable.  I was finally able to work 1 year with no call ins.  I made some major improvements in my life.  Kratom kept me out of the disability system.  It kept me out of the roulette wheel of pain management meds, addiction, and possibly darker paths.  I use this as a supplement just as I would any of the other herbal supplements I take daily.  
I lift weights when I can and I do cardio.  I work a full time job and work overtime.  I have state employee benefits and a state retirement.  I have a savings account that climbs steadily.  I have worked and paid taxes since I was 16 years old.  For 21 years I have been a hard working tax paying citizen.  My life does not fit the profile of an abuser of controlled substances.  I have never been arrested or in any kind of trouble.  It is unreasonable to make kratom a controlled substance!  There are thousands of people just like me who do not want to be on narcotic pain killers.  There are thousands of people who have multiple adverse reactions to anti-inflammatories and simply cannot take them.  It is economically sensible to leave kratom as a legal herbal supplement.  Please do not take away our option that allows us to work and continue to be part of the economic infrastructure.  Please do not take away our option that allows us to avoid prescription narcotics that you've fought to keep off the streets.  Please do not take away our option and deny us the basic right to comfort.  Please do not make this a substance that people would get arrested for just because they want to better themselves

I want her to grow up with an active, engaging mother (myself). For years, I suffered from arthritis pain, anxiety, major depression, lack of energy and a host of other problems related to my health. I was given prescriptions by my doctor, but while the problems were overall not as severe, they definitely were still present and cast a huge shadow over our household. A friend suggested that I read up on kratom, so I did some research and found it to be considered safe, having been used for thousands of years in Asia. 

I first purchased some in early 2014, from a vendor online. I was quite skeptical that a plant could help improve my life, but I gave it a shot...I figured at that point, I didn't have much to lose. Almost immediately, my health improved. I was able to play with my daughter, and truly enjoy life. Instead of being stuck in bed most days, I started becoming active and was able to lose weight and gain back energy I hadn't felt in years. I now volunteer for a pediatric cancer foundation in my spare time, chase my daughter around, and am active in her school. 

I owe so much to kratom. I have absolutely zero negative effects from kratom. Unlike with many prescriptions, I don't feel dizzy, foggy-headed or "drugged"...kratom is myself, only better. I dread what my life will become if kratom is taken away and made illegal. My daughter will lose a huge part of her childhood...my husband will lose his best friend...and I will lose my ability to be an active part of society. Please consider the lives that will be affected...not just the people like me, but the people like my daughter and husband. Kratom is safe and effective, it should continue to be available to the American public as it is in no way a threat to public safety. I truly do not understand how horrific things like tobacco and alcohol can be kept legal, yet kratom not. 

Thank you for your consideration on this matter.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

   I am a Retired Veteran that served 24 years in the Armed Forces.  I have been on two deployments to Iraq, plus too many field exercises to count, and I live with chronic pain everyday of my life.  In January 2010 in Iraq is when my chronic pain started and for about four years no one knew what was causing my pain.  I started taking 5/325mg of  Percocet twice a day in October 2010 when I returned from Iraq because from the beginning till this time the pain progressively got worse.  I left and went to my next duty station and the pain continued.  In July 2011 I was sent to the Pain Clinic, and the doctor was giving me all kind of shots in my back, but had absolutely no clue as to what was causing my pain.  He started me on 10/325mg of Percocet three times which didn't not take the pain away, it only helped make it tolerable.  The year 2012 rolls around and I am in the same physical state I was in initially when I went to see the pain doctor, and absolutely nothing was helping.  The shots were doing nothing and by this time I built-up a tolerance to the Percocet.  Next he puts me on 60mgs of MS Contin three times a day, I am going from a total of 30mg of Percocet a day, to 180mg of MS Contin a day, this was a huge leap in narcotics.  I was on this for over a year and was not living life, as the ms contin was making me so exhausted it is amazing I was able to function.  I would go in to physical training so exhausted, I could barely keep my eyes open. I would be in bed by 7:30 p.m. and  on the weekend I would not get-up till 2 p.m. If I needed to run errands on a weekend that was a chore, as I would not leave the house till 4 p.m.and only be out for a couple of hours, and as soon as I got home I was back in the bed.  I stopped running, going to the gym, or doing any extracurricular activities because between the pain and exhaustion, it was just too much.  Finally in January 2014 I got off of the ms contin, and was not taking anything for a couple of months, till I just could not handle the pain.  By this time I had a new pain clinic doctor and she realized I have sacroiliac joint dysfunction,  which also causes my hip to hurt, and I have pain that runs down my leg.  I started taking Tramadol in  March 2014 because the pain was just intolerable, then back to Percocet because Tramadol did not help.  In December 2014 I was out of Percocet and did not have an appointment anytime soon to see my pain doctor.  I started looking something holistically that would help me to live with my pain, and not having to take narcotics for the rest of my life.  I found Kratom which does not only help with my pain, but it also helps me deal with my PTSD, anxiety, and insomnia.  I am able to run, do distance walking, siting or standing for long periods of time because of Kratom.  I am able to do my chores around the house without being in excruciating pain while doing chores, or even when I am done.  I have been able to paint rooms in my house.  As for as the addictive quality of Kratom that some insist it has, I have not experienced it, and I have been taking it for two years now.  I will drink one 8.5 ozs  container and sip on that all throughout the day if I need it.  I will have one 12 oz container in the late evening, but I never finish it as I don't need to.  I will have 8 oz left by the morning. In each of these containers I only use 1 1/2 to 2 teaspoons per container.  I don't have any withdrawals the next day, if I only drank 4 ounces the night before.  Kratom has been a lifesaver for me. I don't want to ever have to go back to taking a narcotic especially for the rest of my life,  because I have already been told I will have chronic pain for the rest of my life.  I served my country for 24 years, and I did all that the military asked of me, and now in the end I have to suffer with the pain, and the many other ailments that came with serving.  Now a big organization that has no idea what life is like for  many of us Veterans that live with many physical problems, but still want to be a productive part of society, are being told once again, what we cannot do for our pain.  I understand if it does need to be regulated because of the abuser that are out there, but if that is the case regulate coffee, cigarettes, and alcohol, just to name a few.  Every last one of these maintains an addictive quality, to include the drugs that are prescribed by providers such as Oxycodone, Hydrocodone, and Fentanyl, again just to name a few.  Coming after a leaf that helps and has helped many for years without first coming for those drugs that are legal and cause deathly harm is cowardly.  It is like attacking a defenseless child, but letting a killer get away.  Thank you for the opportunity comment, and also thank you for taking the time to read this. Hope you have a wonderful pain and ailment free life. Take care.

documents.commentText:
I am a 56-year-old college Humanities teacher. Teaching is my vocation, and it is central to my life; but I do not work full time, because I cant. My entire adult life has been marked by severe anhedonic depression, which has profoundly affected my professional prospects and my personal relationships. Anhedonic is not just another way of saying depressed; it is a terrifying, seemingly progressive characteristic of depression as I experience it: the loss of the capacity to feel pleasure. And pleasure doesnt just mean laughter and joy and frivolity, things that might seem luxuries; it also means the emotional buffer that allows resilience in response to stress, conflict, and trauma. To lose that buffer is crippling, especially when the situation is compounded by anxiety. Meanwhile, sleep, even brief naps, sleep that should knit up the raveled sleeve of care, routinely precipitates me into a state of bleakness and terror from which I must recover on waking. Depression has been part of my life since I was a teenager; anhedonia gets more devastating every year.

Over the past 35 years, I have been prescribed over thirty medications as treatment for my conditionmany for years. I have been through tricyclics and lithium, SSRIs, MAOIs, atypicals, anti-psychotics, thyroid hormones, benzodiazepines, amphetamines, opiates, and OTC supplements. I have undergone a wide range of tests in the hope of finding aggravating medical conditions related to my symptoms. I have had years of therapy, which taught me some valuable things even as it ultimately confirmed my belief that my problem was fundamentally physical. One doctor was convinced that I suffered from an endogenous opioid deficiency. That may be true. Heartbreakingly, despite years of hope, work, and frustration, no combination of those strategies has proved entirely adequate. I have been forced to accept that treatment-resistant depression is a lifelong condition, and I have lost too much life already. I cannot afford to keep investing my hope in best practice treatments that do me more harm than good, even if they worked for the wide center of the bell distribution. Instead, I do what I can to live with my depression, to hold on to the few people I am still close to, to keep on teaching, and to sustain whatever creative work I can manage.

I discovered kratom three years ago when I was researching the relation of endogenous opioids to depression. It proved to be a godsend. While kratom doesnt cure my depression and anhedonia, it is a profound help in surviving them. Kratom has also helped me to rid my life of both benzodiazepines and pharmaceutical opiates, neither of which had cured or adequately treated my condition more than transiently despite a decade of doctor-prescribed regular use. 

I am a doctors son. I read a lot about kratom and its alkaloids before I actually tried it. What I found out convinced me it was worth trying, and to my amazement, it was. But it does not make me high. Kratom is a mildly psychoactive herb that is as amenable to sane and responsible use as coffee or tea. It also has mild mood-elevating and analgesic properties coffee and tea do not; but I can say, emphatically and from experience, that kratom is nonetheless that kind of thing, not some kind of herbal heroin. What it feels like, to me, is having access to my normal self again. It helps me turn toward the love and work that are the only genuine anchors for a rich, worthwhile life in the world. 

The DEA announcement this fall treated kratom as a drug of abuse and kratom users, categorically, as abusers. But the misguided people who have sought out kratom as a poor excuse for a legal high are vastly outnumbered by the large community for whom kratom has been an invaluable support to productive, socially responsible lives. We are not abusers seeking a furtive, dangerous, antisocial thrill; we can't even recognize ourselves in the DEA's portrait of this supposed public health crisis.

You will have heard from many former addicts who credit their sobriety to this benign herb, and from countless chronic pain sufferers, many of them middle-aged or elderly, including not a few disabled veterans, who are grateful for having found it. But I can speak from direct personal experience only for people like me, sufferers from treatment-resistant depression, crippling anxiety, or post-traumatic stress disorder. It is no exaggeration to say that kratom has helped many of us save our own lives. If the sheer size of the kratom-using community has been invisible until now, that is precisely because we are NOT a lurking threat either to society or to ourselves.

For me, this is about the pursuit of happinesslove and worknot some recreational high. 

It's about the dignity of being allowed to manage my own private life and turn toward what matters.

Please keep kratom legal, with whatever regulatory process is appropriate to keep it unadulterated and safe. Please listen to us.

documents.commentText:
My name is Alicia McGee Damron,  I'm a 38 year old mother of two and live in rural North Carolina. I was born and raised here.

I attend church every Sunday. I don't drink and I've never used any tobacco product or any illegal drug, including marijuana. I don't even drink soft drinks (I prefer water) and I eat whole, real foods (including fresh eggs from my backyard chickens and vegetables from my garden) and practice yoga in my quest to stay fit and healthy. I mention this to give you an idea of the type of person I am.

For occasional acute pain (such as when I pulled a muscle in my back) I have used kratom to help. It definitely helped my pain and there was no "high" associated with it. I researched this herb before I made the decision to use it. It was NOT an impulse buy. I was happy to have it as an option because it fits with my lifestyle choices.

Although I've only used kratom a handful of times myself, I have three family members who use it on a regular basis to help with chronic pain issues such as rheumatoid arthritis, back pain stemming from an old injury, and knee pain due to degenerative issues. I've seen how much it helps them maintain an active lifestyle and improves their quality of life. This is a big reason why I'm speaking out in favor of kratom. 

I don't have a lot of aches and pains at this stage of my life, but when I think about how I may have chronic pain issues as I get older I'd like for kratom to be available as an option for me if I want it. I do not want this herb to be banned. The American people should have the right to choose this botanical substance, if desired, to help them live their best life possible.

documents.commentText:
Hello and thank you this opportunity to share my experience.

I am a 50 year-old, drug and smoke-free professional in the marketing field. 

I strongly believe placing Kratom in a Schedule 1 classification isn't appropriate and, by doing so, is depriving millions of people from living more productive, drug-free lives, including freedom from, ironically, those in the Schedule 1 category. However there is so much more to this strong belief of mine.

I found Kratom a year ago after a 3 knee surgeries in 3 years and the subsequent prescriptions to pain-killers. The Vicodin made me dizzy, nauseous and lazy.  I did a lot of internet searches along the lines of "natural Vicodin alternative", etc. Up came Kratom and the hundreds of amazing success stories. My curiosity was piqued and I ordered a sample.

In short, not only was I able to toss the prescriptions for my pain, but it has also allowed changed my life with regards to my life-long struggle with severe depression and anxiety. it has absolutely been a "game-changer" for me. I now use it daily and have been doing so for a little over a year. I never "crave" it or "need" it. It doesn't impair me in ANY way. 

Were this plant to become illegal, I would be devastated. My fiancee with severe Lupus has also been able to throw away her Vicodin prescription. We (all Americans) have finally found a natural, non-addictive alternative to pain medication; one of the biggest addiction problems in this country. As if you didn't know that fact. :) But the list of OTHER medical benefits is astounding. 

My depression would resurface and it would lead me back to the fruitless search for more prescriptions that have never worked in 40 years. I feel so good about taking a harmless, non-toxic leaf... 100% natural. It has made me more effective at work, I have been more social, it allows me to actually look forward to the day. I am so grateful to have found Kratom. 

I ask that you read this very short summary of laboratory research on Kratom as an anti-depressant. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20869223

In conclusion, I urge (plead) you to consider my story amidst the hundreds of thousands you will see. There are people if far worse pain than me that have found freedom with Kratom. We are not a community of addicts. We are people that want to contribute more to society in a positive way. Please listen to us.

I sincerely THANK YOU for this opportunity to be heard. It is greatly appreciated.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am a 26 year old woman living in the Southeast US. I work full time as an inside sales representative at a national company, and do a small amount of artistic freelance work as well. I first was introduced to kratom by a friend who has had trouble with depression. He mentioned he'd had some at a local tea place and it had helped with some of the sleepiness (physical) and general hopeless & low feelings (emotional) he was struggling with. I experience moderate depression and moderate to high anxiety, which so far I've treated with regular therapy sessions and a low dose of antianxiety medication (taken on an as-needed basis). 

After having the person working at the tea shop explain to me what to expect & the general properties of kratom tea, I tried it. The experience wasn't quite like any other I've had (I drink alcohol and have tried marijuana a few times, in addition to having had painkillers prescribed to me after various surgeries). I felt physically less sore & stiff from my day at work, and also less "muddled"-- it was noticeably easier to express my thoughts & I felt a bit like I'd had a cup of coffee (but without the heart racing/ other side effects of caffeine). This was accompanied by a calming effect slightly reminiscent of the painkillers, but without slowing my thought processes or physical responses. Overall, it was a very positive experience. 

I've consumed kratom tea (the powder mixed with water and a little milk) maybe 20 times total, spread over the course of a year. It's been particularly helpful to me when my depression kicks up and I'm tempted to drink alcohol (sometimes to excess). Instead of trying to obtain the "escape" from my negative psychological symptoms through drinking, I can dependably find an even better solution that simply helps me function in a calm yet alert way. I can't medically claim kratom has antianxiety or antidepressant effects; but I can assert that using it has allowed me to limit & sometimes eliminate my use of prescription medications to treat those symptoms.

I've only experienced negative effects of drinking kratom tea once, and in that instance it was due to the fact I drank it after not having eaten recently (against the recommendation of both my friend and the tea shop employee). I felt an upset stomach and some nausea, which was alleviated by slowly drinking water & eating a small meal. 

I would add that I carefully observed my motor functions the first few times I drank the tea-- my friend had told me that I should have no trouble driving 20 minutes home, but I wanted to be especially careful since I'd never consumed this before. He was correct-- if anything, I noticed a slight increase in my alertness (comparable to half a cup of coffee). I have never felt impaired by kratom. 

I feel that this naturally occurring substance has noticeably improved my well-being, and has no negative effects that I have noticed. I have had no symptoms of dependency, nor have my acquaintances who consume it. My friend who first introduced me to the drink is a more frequent user (due to his more severe and long-standing depression), and similarly has no symptoms of dependency and consistent relief from his illness. 

I strongly oppose efforts to ban the use of kratom in the United States, especially as there is currently no significant clinical research to support claims of its negative effects. I also know that some of my acquaintances who consume kratom do so to support their efforts at battling addiction to hard drugs (usually opioids) that have been repeatedly proven to be very detrimental to health as well as being physically and psychologically addictive. 

Finally, if kratom were to be made illegal in the US, I would stop consuming it-- but I would worry for those depending on it as a substitute for prescription drugs/ heroin. Those struggling with addiction would likely seek kratom from another source, which would be completely unregulated (since illegal). Either they would risk their health by using this black market kratom, or they would return to using hard drugs. 

I urge you to reconsider this move to make kratom a Schedule 1 Controlled Substance-- or at the very least, postpone it until we have dependable research & large, duplicated studies to establish the benefits, neutral effects, and side effects. Kratom has helped me personally, and I find it extremely hard to believe that it is harmful, and it certainly doesn't seem to belong in the Schedule 1 category of controlled substances. I respect the opinions of medical experts and the data collected in clinical trials, but cannot find there is sufficient evidence at present to merit placing kratom on the controlled substance list.

documents.commentText: Both my partner and I have been active Kratom users for just over three years. We've consumed it in nearly all available forms and strains, including liquids, raw powder, capsules, etc. I can speak on Kratom's behalf as an advanced critical thinker, as a college instructor with a Master's in English Literature, The main and sole reason for consumption in my household is for daily medical, health, and motivational benefits in the same way coffee or lemon water would be used for health and motivational reasons for one's daily functions. The editorials published initially published on Kratom, such as the article in Vice Magazine that compares it to a brainchild of Oxycotin and Adderall, are completely hyperbolic and fictitious. Both prescriptions the article compares Kratom to are controlled substances for good reason. However, Kratom has never elicited anything near the experience of being prescribed an opioid medication nor an amphetamine for ADHD. What I've come to understand from my consumption of Kratom is that the natural substance experienced a brief period of exaggerated media coverage in order to increase consumers awareness and motivate sales when it began making its way on the shelves of smoke shops and online stores across the US. Had Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, the active ingredients in Kratom, resembled any of the main or side effects of the aforementioned controlled substances, it would have been stripped from the shelves years ago when the first wave of concerned citizens investigated the it, largely due to the mixed and promotional nature of the published editorials on Kratom. Kratom is a cousin of the coffee plant, and consuming feels very much like ingesting a more mild, foul tasting version of coffee. Coffee's powerful caffeinated effects far exceeds the physical and mental effects on the body when contrasted to Kratom. Kratom's effects are much more subtle, and much less altering. My partner and I use Kratom as a coffee alternative as its lack of caffeine feels significantly more healthy and relaxing on the body, and doesn't exhibit any of the alter state or feeling of anxiety that coffee offers. The other main reason for consumption is Kratom's known abilities to promote well being and a sense of overall natural happiness rooted in a softening of anxiety. I would compare this effect to St. John's Wart, the popular herbal substance available to help curb daily depression and promote positive feelings of well being. Kratom feels like a mild version of both coffee and St. John's Wart, but remarkably more natural on the body. The misconception that Kratom carries any mind or body altering properties, or that it has any negative or dangerous consequences to one's health is completely fictitious and has never been described or experienced by myself, my partner, or any of our friends or colleagues who use Kratom regularly as a replacement for caffeine or other natural herbal remedies. Kratom's regular use in parts of Asian, primarily Thailand and Indonesia has been documented to show its value in daily use. Kratom leaves are used in the same manner that Americans use coffee. I found Kratom to be an incredibly effective and healthy alternative. Withdrawal to Kratom after extended use resembles the mild symptoms of coffee: a slight headache for a day or two, with no psychological or physical withdrawal symptoms. The literature review that cites Kratom as a concern attempts to place it in the same category as other opioids, which has become a major epidemic in the United States. The use of Kratom couldn't be further from the use of opioids. Although it possesses the abilities to register to the same receptors as some opioids, it does not illicit the same affects. This is common in other substances, as some strains of marijuana can bind to receptors but cannot provide a "high" therefore are not grown or circulated. The comparison of Kratom to opioids is a stretch at best, as they are two completely different plants with two different biochemical effects in the human body. The main concern of opioids, including the attempt to label Kratom as such, is the risk of respiratory failure. This was a concern of mine until I became using Kratom, and found the recent studies on Kratom show there is no risk of respiratory depression in Kratom. All incidents of injury or medical concern involving Kratom have all involved use of another abused substance, such as opioids, alcohol, or cough syrup.

documents.commentText:
I write this comment as a scientist. I am against placing mitragynine, 7-hydroxymitragynine, and kratom plant on Schedule I.  Instead, I suggest that kratom is regulated like alcohol and tobacco (to ensure that suppliers provide unadulterated plant material).

In terms of scientific understanding, the data available so far suggests that the main kratom alkaloids modulate a number of molecular targets, not just the opioid receptors. Further, it appears that these compounds are "mild modulators", meaning that they show low potency and low efficacy. In other words, they are not nearly as powerful as prescription opioids and they affect a wider range of molecular systems. There are also differences in how mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine turn on the opioid receptors (compared to classical opioids), and older literature indicates much better safety profile in terms of respiratory depression of mitragynine in several mammalian species.

Unfortunately, the clinical data available today is only anecdotal (reports by users online and in this public deposition). In my opinion, DEA can not ignore the hundreds of reports from people who benefit from kratom use. The theme I gathered from these reports is that kratom is mild, yet effective at alleviating suffering caused by intractable/chronic pain, depression, anxiety, and drug abuse. 

In terms of the risks, the number of cases of intoxication and death linked to mitragynine/kratom (discussed in the DEA's document) must be put in the broader context. How many deaths are reported as caused by alcohol, tobacco, food allergies, prescribed medicines, etc? This is a question for toxicologists and epidemiologists, but it is essential that the handful of mitragynine poisoning cases are considered in this perspective.

documents.commentText: I use kratom for migraines.  Kratom allows me to go to work as usual, rather than stay home in a darkened room for a few days at a time. Many of us cannot afford treatments offered by the medical industry even with insurance.  I know I can't.  Medical care in Alaska is even more unaffordable than the rest of the nation.  Treatment for migraines by the medical industry is frequently ineffective.  Working class Americans are dealing with a crisis in the medical care system. documents.commentText:
I have used Kratom for over five years now, sometimes each day and other times sparingly maybe once per week.  The effects of Kratom, unlike drugs of abuse in the often-compared opiate class, are mild, and the euphoria of the drug, if experienced at all, is very limited even in first time users.  Additionally consuming excessive amounts leads to nausea and worse feelings; that is, it is a self-limiting substance much like caffeine.  Just like it does not make one feel a cocaine rush to consume 20 cups of coffee in rapid succession, consuming tens of grams of Kratom will not result in an heroin-like high but, on the contrary, nausea and discomfort (not death mind you -- please refer to the scientific literature for overdose characteristics).  As such Kratom needs no additional law enforcement to limit its use in adults because it limits its own consumption, much like coffee.

In addition to the simple fact people enjoy taking Kratom for the clarity of thought and the peaceful feelings it imparts without physical impairment, it can unfortunately be addictive.  I attest to this reality, but the level of addiction and subsequent withdrawals if one stops taking it, are relatively minor for the vast majority of users as compared to hard drugs. There are other ways Kratom can actually even help society.

Opiates, for example, do endanger the lives of people who become addicted to them, and that is sad.  However, even here Kratom has a use: it provides a way for people so entrapped by the cycle of opiate abuse to get off those drugs or greatly reduce their use and, thus, reduce the harm even death they can pose to the abuser.  Kratom does this by helping curb the strong and horrifically painful withdrawals that opiate abusers feel when they are getting off their dope without having to shame or suffering the stigma of getting outside help.  It empowers people to fix themselves while not spending tax dollars or wasting the limited time of our policemen and women doing other jobs, the judicial system's available time, and jail's limited space.

Additionally Kratom can help people, such as the elderly and our vets who bravely served our country so we may enjoy its freedoms, who deal with pain daily by providing a way out of opiate use, thereby reducing the strain our healthcare system must endure for more risky treatments such as opiate prescription, treatments that render the user less mentally acute to enjoy life and work.  

So my experience has shown me the simple truth that Kratom has a medicinal use and overall strongly benefits society, not harms it.

documents.commentText: This is in response to the DEA's intention to make Kratom a Schedule I substance. It includes a great amount of information on what Kratom is and the what will happen if the DEA goes through with the emergency scheduling. Dear DEA, Please remove Mitragynine & 7-hydroxymitragynine which is in Kratom from becoming a Schedule I substance. I am 29 and suffer from a herniated disc, chronic neck pain, TMJ, arthritis in my neck. I support a family of four on a single income. I have been to many doctors with little success for treatment. I have found that Kratom improves my quality of life by being able to work. If I didn't have this herb I would be on disability from pain. It isn't comparable to any drugs, marijuana, alcohol or other stimulants. Kratom helps to improve my quality of life that I suffer with chronic pain. Please don't make this herb illegal. Cervical injections, botox injections, chiropractic care, physical therapy, acupuncture, massage therapy, yoga exercises have not helped with my pain. Kratom is a well-known, well-researched herbal substance drawn from the leaves of trees within the coffee family. The number of cases of documented harm from kratom use is remarkably low, both as an absolute matter and when considered against the extensive history of use of kratom, both inside and outside the United States Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine are two of the primary alkaloids of this plant. These two compounds are not synthetic and should not be lumped together with "bath salts" or "spice". Kratom has been used as a medicine by many people for thousands of years. It is a potent remedy for physical pain, anxiety and depression, and could be used to aid with opiate withdrawal by those who would like to quit using illicit drugs such as heroin. Kratom is NOT a hallucinogen and should not be classified as such. Adding mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as a Schedule I substance is rash and unjustified prohibition, resulting in a foreseeable increase in street drug-related crime, as well as a punishment to those who are currently using it responsibly to treat various ailments. The reason that there are no deaths solely attributed to Kratom is because Kratom does not affect your respiratory capacity. It does not slow down your central nervous system. It's potential to do harm is virtually impossible. Kratom has very limited recreational capacity. The White House petition has over 100,000 signatures for the "Please do not make Kratom a Schedule I Substance." The federal government has invested significant resources to develop alternative pain management strategies. This includes a study funded by the National Institutes of Health in partnership with the University of Massachusetts and the University of Mississippi to investigate the use of Kratom as a remedy for opioid withdrawal. This study led the researchers to apply for a patent identifying the Kratom extract, mitragyinine, as a useful treatment for other addictive drugs besides opiate derivatives. The DEA's decision to place Kratom as a Schedule I substance will put a halt on federally funded research and innovation surrounding the treatment of individuals suffering from opioid and other addictionsa significant public health threat. Remember the DDear Colleague Letters of Senator Hatch and Congressman Mark Pocan. We hope you realize the threat this scheduling causes the people seeking legitimate use of this special plant to improve our quality of life. Attached are testimonies and facts about Kratom along with other facts listed below. Sincerely, Anonymous Florida Department of Law Enforcement Report http://speciosa.org/official-statewide-intelligence-drug-report-kratom-and-the-impact-to-florida/ Hogan-Lovells (legal perspective): Kratom is a natural herb with a long track record in the United States. Kratom does not qualify as 'an imminent hazard to public safety' and is outside of the DEA's emergency scheduling power (Controlled Substances Act, CSA). Extended discussion in Hogan-Lovells letter. http://www.pharmaciststeve.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Hogan-Lovells-Letter-Regarding-Kratom-Scheduling.pdf Univeristy of Mississippi https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=patentimages.storage.googleapis.com%2Fpdfs%2FUS20100209542.pdf United Kratom Association - Study https://www.dropbox.com/s/l3wptg8jabgkznd/Kratom-A-Collecive-Analysis.pdf?dl=0 Study of Kratom on Humans https://www.dovepress.com/pharmacokinetics-of-mitragynine-in-man-peer-reviewed-fulltext-article-DDDT#

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

Five years ago my older brother and I moved in together as roommates after his divorce.  About a year prior he had been in a car wreck and hurt his back and arm.  I knew he had been getting treatment and taking pain medication for it.  When we moved in together he was in good health other than his injuries and being in some pain.  Over the course of the two years we lived together, I watched my older brother who is always been healthy, physically fit, active, and happy slowly deteriorate into a shell of himself.  His pain medication had slowly stopped working as his tolerance grew and he started buying pills off the street and then started buying harder opiates the same way.  This went on until I came home from work one day to my brother in nothing but his boxers laying on the floor in withdrawals.  He went to rehab and got sober.

After being sober he still had to find a way to manage his pain and he found an herbal supplement that worked wonders in kratom.  Over the last three years, my brother has gotten healthy, gotten happy again, is physically fit again, and even started his own business.  A big reason he has been able to do this despite having chronic pain is because of a safe and inexpensive herbal supplement.  I heard about the DEA wanting to make this supplement a Schedule I narcotic which would turn my brother into a felon for possessing it.  Why would you take something that helps countless number of people get off and stay off opiates and live pain free and make it illegal for them?  I thought we were suppose to be trying to fix the opiate crisis, not make it worse.  If it is made illegal and my brother and others can no longer use it, what happens to them?  Are they suppose to resume taking the things that nearly killed them or may kill them?  Who is responsible for my brother and others should they die from taking the strong opiate drugs that are very dangerous?  Because I assure you that if that happens and my brother dies, I will not stop fighting until someone or a group of people is held accountable for his death and I am sure other families feel the same.  When it comes to the opiate crisis, dont be part of the problem, be part of the solution.

documents.commentText: Comment: I do NOT believe Kratom should be scheduled as Schedule 1 Drug. It is a harmless plant that has not only done a lot of good for me, but many other people I know. I am a 43 year old health fanatic and am very cautious about what I put in my body. Also, I run my own business and experience a lot of stress and anxiety in my work day. Kratom is something which I have consumed for the past 2 years and it has been a blessing in reducing stress and anxiety without any negative side effects. I have also never experienced any addiction to it. Whenever I stop drinking coffee for more than 3 days I have terrible withdrawals and headaches. I have never had any withdrawal symptoms like this from Kratom. It has been a blessing in my life. I believe alcohol has 1000 times worse effects on my body than Kratom. Since I began taking Kratom, I have not had to increase the amount I consume to get the desired effects and I have really appreciated that. In the past, I used to reduce stress/anxiety by having a glass or 2 of wine a few times a week...but with alcohol I always experienced negative side effects like depression, increased physical pain in my body, hangovers next day, and even slight addiction to want more. When taking kratom, I have never felt any side effects like this. It has truly been one of the most positive things I have consumed. I barely drink alcohol now. Also, Kratom has been a complete blessing in reducing pain in my body. I herniated my L4-L5 vertebrae in my back over 15 years ago, and the pain can be excruciating some times. In the past, I have been prescribed opiates to help with the pain. Whenever I took them, I pretty much stopped immediately due to the negative side effects: such as nausea, extreme tiredness or lethargy, fogginess in my brain and bad constipation. I was also always concerned with their strong addictive effects, so I stopped taking them immediately. I have seen friends and family members get lost in opiate addictions and ruin their lives. When I started consuming Kratom, it reduced my pain significantly, while also lifting my mood. Its effects were just right, not overpowering, and allowed me to function during my work day both mentally and physically. To summate, it seems ridiculous to make this a schedule 1 drug. It has done wonders for me without any negatives added in my life and body. I am so happy to have found something that eases anxiety, pain, mood, and creates a sense of well being....but most importantly, without any side effects. Thank you for listening ((:

documents.commentText:
I suffer from Lyme Disease and have been freed from opiates (Percocet 10mg 6/day) by kratom use. It controls my pain and fatigue without side effects, allowing me to work, be social, and have a normal life. Before kratom, I was bedridden for two years. PLEASE don't take this away. Regulations that make sure patients know what they're buying would be the ideal end for this assessment period. We need education, not restrictive measures that put kratom with heroin on a list of dangerous drugs and force us to rely on prescription opiates from doctors who are as frightened of the DEA as they are concerned for their patients' health while on long term painkillers. 

I was part of an article with a member of the DEA and a physician on megasite Cracked.com, where I work. I told my story there, and the agent explained his position, as well. Please read it. I can't paste a link here, but you can find the article on Cracked's site if you search for "kratom" and "Marina Reimann." That's me. It explains everything far better than I can here. Thank you for giving us a chance to be heard, a chance to fight for our lives and families. I want to have children one day with my husband, but the thought of being trapped by opiates makes that dream seem distant... and impossible, if kratom becomes illegal. I want to be able to hold my children with my nerve-damaged hands. Please believe that I speak for many when I say that. I introduced a friend with MS to kratom and she cried, because she could move on her own without pain, and she could play with her baby. She will be able to continue this if the right choice is made. Please help us keep our dignity and our hope for a healthy future and a family we can care for to the very best of our abilities. On behalf of my friend, myself, and the millions of Americans tethered to pill bottles, I beg you to hear our pleas and make a positive difference in our lives as protectors of the law, which protects us. If the wrong choice is made, we will all be ruined. Our choice will be to walk on the wrong side of the law or shorten our lives by up to ten years by taking painkillers again from now on.

Mitragyna speciosa is not the kind of substance that you find in the hands of drug-addled, community-devasting addicts. documents.commentText:
My name is Jamie, and am the age of 29, and a stay-at-home mother of two young children. 

Please, please, please do not ban this natural plant, Kratom, that has been consumed safely for decades. Kratom is not a drug, but a regulated dietary ingredient. Kratom does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.

 I was extremely ill for about four days before I went to the ER. I was in so much pain I was unable to walk. My husband had to carry me to and from where I needed to go. We got to the hospital and they decided to run a CT scan on me. The doctor told me I had a cyst on the tail of my pancreas, but he was not worried about it. He treated me for two infections I had and pumped me full of fluids. Four hours later, I was released. I followed-up with my Primary Physician and she urged me to have an Endoscopic Ultrasound done. This doctor took two biopsies from my pancreas, and it turned out I had Pancreatic Cancer. I met with an Oncologist and he performed two surgeries to remove the cancer and also removed my spleen and the tissue surrounding the Pancreas and Spleen. That was exactly four years ago. My daughter was two years old at the time and I never thought I would see her again. Now, I have a one year old son! The kind of Pancreatic Cancer I was diagnosed with was curable! It was a miracle! After all that, I still have a tremendous amount of back pain. The doctors say that might not ever go away. I was on Tramadol and Oxycodone for a year after that and didn't like the side effects I had. I constantly had migraines, the pills made me ill, and was always lethargic. I was always laying in bed. I started to get depressed because my daughter needs her mother and I knew something had to change. My husband heard about Kratom, and did some research on it and bought some. I have been consuming Kratom for three years now. I feel healthy and have so much more energy! A feeling of well-being! Yes, this plant aids in my back pain, but the pain is still there, just faint. I do not feel I need to take Kratom every day. It is not addicting to me. My children have their mother back! I LOVE seeing the big smiles on their faces when I feel good enough to go play with them!

Please... DEA... my family and I beg you, Don't ban this wonderful plant that God has put on this earth for people to consume responsibly. 

Thank you for letting our voices be heard!



Sincerely,

Jamie Z

documents.commentText:
I started using Kratom this year. For the last 15 years, I have dealt with chronic pain including migrating knee caps. The only thing I could get was Tramadol as doctors hate to prescribe Vicodin or Norco. I work over 40 hours a week in retail and so I am on my feet all day. During cold times of the years, by the time I get home I am hunched over and shuffling like a little old lady on her last legs. And even though I visit my doctor regularly and go to physical therapy, when I call for a refill on my Tramadol I am made to feel like a "junkie" or a drug addict when all I want is to be out of enough pain to live my life.

   After I heard about Kratom, I figured I would give it a shot. And it works, it works very very well. Taken in a small enough dose, I can go about my day and be free of pain both nerve, joint and muscle. I don't understand why anyone would take away something that helps me so much, is from nature, and that I don't have to feel dirty every time I ask for more. Not only me, but many of my friends have found relief with Kratom. I have a boss who has migraines so bad that not even shots given into the head can ease his pain but Kratom allows him to sleep and come into work. Another friend has chronic back pain and had turned very reluctantly to marijuana but finds a better option in Kratom so that he can still work.

  I know that the government is only trying to protect the citizens but I would beg for more study because the only thing I can think of as a crime would be to take this herbal remedy from citizens trying to live just a little bit free of pain.

documents.commentText: Kratom is helping Americans break free from opioid dependance caused by heroin and prescription opioid painkillers. The substance has no record of having high abuse potential and no scientifically established link to a statistically relevant number of deaths that can be directly linked to the substance itself versus pre-existing health issues. This is eerily similar to the complete lack of scientific evidence that marijuana is any more dangerous than tobacco. Taking this tool (kratom/mitragynine) away from the hundreds of thousands of Americans fighting opioid addiction and risk of death from opioid overdose is unconscionable. Outlawing kratom will simply create a black market for the substance driven by those desperately seeking to escape or mitigate opioid addiction, which will add to the economic burden the drug war already places upon the American taxpayer, and put American lives at greater risk. There is no supportable argument for spending taxpayer funds waging war on yet another nearly harmless natural substance, especially one that is helping Americans avoid the use of a much more harmful substance.

documents.commentText:
I drank kratom one day at work. It was presented to me as a anti-anxiety botanical. I drank a half a teaspoon in a small cup of hot water with honey. It tasted like yerba mate, the highly-caffeinated south american tea. I didn't really notice anything for the first hour.

After about an hour I mostly felt a little more focused and a little energy boost, but somewhere between green tea and coffee. I don't suffer from chronic pain, but I feel like kratom just felt like another herbal relaxing tea with a little bit of a brain boost. 

Strange that the DEA would want to put something less potent than coffee (in terms of a stimulant) as a schedule 1 drug. If it helps me with my anxiety, and it helps millions of people with chronic pain, the move to ban kratom seems like an absolutely stupid missed opportunity to regulate a very positive, helpful botanical that has about the intensity as coffee or yerba mate.

documents.commentText:
First off I would like to thank your Agency for all the hard and often dangerous work you do around the USA and the world.  Your efforts to curtail illegal drug trafficking actively improve our safety at home and the quality of our current and future society.  Thank you also for this additional time to review Kratom and give it the thorough analysis an alternative medicine requires in order to ensure this is not another toxic element in our society.  
   Who am I?  I am a college educated and full time employee of the US Government.  I am also a veteran of the US Army having served honorably for 7 years.  I barely drink and am physically fit.  I was injured in the Army and had my right knee reconstructed and also had back problems stemming from a training injury.  I've served in dangerous areas on three different continents and need to be 100% coherent and fully present in my day to day duties.  The US Army had a habit of feeding us soldiers pain and anxiety medication in a manner which led to forms of dependency which I found unacceptable.  One day I turned down the medication and decided from then on I would research alternative forms of medicine and physical therapy (acupuncture, suction cupping).  That history and journey is what led me to Kratom, an herbal remedy that provided some joint pain relief and anxiety relief.  
   The point of my letter is to highlight that I am not a criminal, not a degenerate and feel that Kratom has legitimate uses as an alternative medicine and humbly request that my voice add to the others requesting you do not ban or place restrictive policies on how we can legally obtain this remedy for pain and anxiety.  Thank you for your time and consideration.

The DEA needs to stop making plants and other substances illegal based on anecdotal evidence. There needs to be concrete scientific evidence that shows beyond a doubt that a chemical poses a serious health risk to its user or those around them. The problem with making a snap decision is that once something is illegal, it becomes very difficult to legalize it again, even under a landslide of evidence showing that the positive effects hugely outweigh any negative side effects (marijuana currently). These plants can have very impactful medicinal qualities and are completely wasted when people are subjected to prosecution and imprisonment trying to benefit from them.

 Have you watched any of the pharma commercials? Do you hear the disclaimers at the end? A heart burn med can give you diarrhea, migraines, suicidal thoughts, intestinal bleeding, liver failure, etc.  Yeah that's pefectly legal to sell... What about all the lawsuits and recalls on the pharmaceuticals, even after all the clinical trials indicate that they are safe?

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W, regarding mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, found in the plant Mitragyna speciosa, also referred to as kratom.

My name is Beth.  I am a 43 year old mother of 3 children, wife, daughter, sister and aunt.  I have bachelor's degree in psychology.  I have worked with our adolescent/youth population for over 20 years.  Currently I work in an educational organization, with high school students ages 15-20.  I pride myself in providing a safe, non-judgmental and open environment for the youth I work with.  It is also very important to me that I am a positive, healthy role model for them.

 I strongly oppose the proposed scheduling of kratom.  

Personally, I have been drinking kratom tea for 2 years.  I make the tea by brewing the dried and powdered leaves from the kratom tree.  I have never experienced any serious adverse side effects, nor have I ever been concerned about any potential "overdose"/death.  The worst effect (which I only experienced twice, it's unpleasant and I do not wish to repeat it) was vomiting after drinking too much of the tea.  I have read the DEA's claims of 15 deaths in recent years from kratom.  I do not believe that these deaths are attributed to kratom alone.  I believe it is impossible to overdose/die from kratom.  It does not repress breathing, as true opiates do.  Our stomachs will expel kratom if we consume too much. 

Please see the attached document for my full comment.  Thank you.
