documents.commentText:
I was very relieved to learn that the DEA was putting a hold on designating Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug. My daughter has fibromyalgia. Prior to her finding Kratom for her pain and fatigue, she was on several medications in an effort to keep her pain under control. On a bad day, she would have to take so much opioid pain medication that she could hardly function. If she didn't take it, she spent much of her time in bed anyway because her pain was unbearable. She works in the summer in her city's swim program running their special needs program. Without Kratom, she would drive herself to work, take half a pain pill, struggle through the pain as she taught these children, drive home, take a whole pain pill, and often a second and text her husband to let him know she wasn't able to cook that night. I never called her because I didn't know if I'd be waking her, knowing that she probably hadn't slept well or was having to nap because of the fatigue of fibromyalgia or that caused by her medications. She seemed suicidal on more than one occasion. 

The difference Kratom has made in her life has been phenomenal! She is back to her old, talkative, happy self. She has been able to go off the medications with the worst side effects, including opioids. Kratom has given her pain relief well beyond what she was getting before. And it has done it without dulling her other senses. She is able to function again and is looking forward to expanding her city's special needs programs to other sports as well as swimming, which would expand the seasons she is able to work. She could not have even considered this before. She gets her Kratom from a reputable supplier, who does not cut other harmful or addictive substances into it. She does not feel that she is addicted to Kratom. She would be able to go off of it if she had to but doesn't want to because of the pain relief vastly improved over what she was taking before. She was terrified earlier this year at the prospect of not being able to get it legally. Her husband is a police officer so not only did she not want to break any laws but didn't want to put his career in jeopardy. I was terrified that I was going to lose my daughter again as she was forced to go back to the drugs that affected her so terribly.

Initial studies on Kratom have shown that it affects the same pain receptors as opioids with very little affect on the areas that register a "high." My daughter has said that if feeling like getting out of bed every morning is a "high" that's one high that she's happy to have. I have a niece and nephews who have gone through drug addiction and a couple who still struggle with it. I know what that looks like. That is not what I see when I look at my daughter. Not any more. documents.commentText:
Youll hear slightly different testimony from me then you will from the others, I think. I am just an average 38 year old citizen.  I have not done anything super noteworthy, positive or negative. I live pretty much a straight and narrow path. Sure, I have had my fair share of fun times in my teens and 20s. I am a college graduate (The Evergreen State College, 2000), a business owner of 12 years, a wife and mother of an amazing 10 year old girl. I garden, ferment foods, and volunteer at my kids school. I live a natural a life as possible, eat my organic vegetables and buy that small farm coffee.
A couple of years ago I got an itch, I was bored and getting depressed. I needed something in my life. I found roller derby. It was simply amazing. I was using my body in ways in never knew possible. Pushing myself beyond any perceived limitations. I made friends for the first time in a very long time. As you might imagine, broken bones are a thing in derby. In June of last year I broke my leg. No surgery necessary. During my rehab I fell into a very dark hole. Maybe it was the opiates prescribed to me, maybe it was that I was cut off from my friends and the one thing I loved so much, maybe the lack of not being able to do a thing for myself, maybe it was not working, or being able to take care of my family. I got help rather quickly and picked myself up, with the help of a great therapist, and went back to derby. On February 2 I decided to scrimmage for my first time. I was on the sidelines stretching and someone just didnt see me, tripped, landed on my back&.and broke it in 3 places. I couldnt believe it. The hole I had just climbed out of just sucked me in again. Again, I was lucky to not need surgery, just lots of bed rest.
I had joined a few mental health groups on facebook, and while venting someone reached out and told me about Kratom. She told me how it could help the depression and anxiety, as well as possibly my pain. I did my research. I was in shock. How could I not know about this wonder plant? The amount of natural healing books at my house is ridiculous. After all my research, I thought I had nothing to loose so I ordered some from an online botanical company. It REALLY did work. The first time, it worked. It didnt make me instantly happy, but it did ease my back pain, with no mind altering effects. As I continued use, it helped my mood and disposition, it made it easier to move, making it possible for me to work some while injured. I did not need any of the opiates prescribed to me once I had the Kratom. 
I continued using Kratom as a supplement to my healing for about four months on a daily basis. I am stronger now and no longer need daily pain management. I still use Kratom, but only as needed, maybe 4 times a week. I supplement with Kratom when any other adult would supplement with ibuprofen. I take absolutely NO other pain medication, prescribed or otherwise. Dare I say, not so bad after a broken leg and broken back in less than a year!
I am writing this today, not for myself, but for all the people I have watched this plant help. I have joined an amazing community of people whose lives have been changed by this green leaf. My injuries are minor, they will heal, and honestly, my own dang fault. Others are not so lucky. I have seen, first hand, Kratom help friends with chronic pain, fibromyalgia, cancer, PTSD, depression and anxiety. Its not a cure, but it certainly helps. Many people will have only one other choice if this ban goes into effect, opiates. I know many people that have already made their pain clinic appointments in preparation. One more mother, father, caregiver, sister, brother& on opiates. Kratom is non sedative, people can FUNCTION while supplementing with Kratom. 
 This ban will effect literally millions, locally, nationally and GLOBALLY. Indonesian Kratom farms are literally hundreds of years old. These farmers will be out of jobs practically overnight. So many of us will return to living in daily pain. Some of us will turn to opiates. The DEA has over stepped their bounds with this ban. It is a natural non-intoxicating plant.
Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
Salutations,

My name is Brian Ornduff. As you can tell from my address, I live in a state that has one of the worst records for addiction in the United States (West Virginia.)  I personally know 6 people, personally and tangentially, that have died as a result of pill addiction. But, I'm not writing you to talk about them; it's too late for that. I am writing you to talk about the people I've met that are alive and thriving thanks to kratom.

I've studied and worked with kratom for over 5 years now. I've watched it grow online from virtually nothing. I was worried as it continued to help people in my state because I knew the government would be scared, confused, and not understand it, so they'd do what the government tends to do in these situations: ban it. 

I worried about it quite a lot. Why? Because of the people I've met that had their lives literally turned around due to finding this leaf. I've met a young heroin addict who started taking kratom to ease their pain until they no longer took heroin or kratom. I've met a woman in her mid-40s who had knee surgery. She told the doctor "No opioids" and he told her about kratom.

I've benefited. With scoliosis, a little bit of kratom helps me mow several people's yards.

Unfortunately, because of the uncertainty the DEA's caused over the last couple months, out of the over 100 people I've met in my state, about 5 who suffer from chronic pain have went back to opioids. Many of the rest I've met who suffer from chronic pain were almost or were crying because "I don't want to go back to the way things used to be."

This is not a complicated fix.If you want to improve anything, just affect the branding. But, please, don't affect it's market place and ability to get to people. It's doing too much good. While the government was fiddling while our state was burning, kratom has been helping. People have hope again; don't take that away from them. I beg you for that little bit of mercy. And that's what it'd be, mercy.

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
I am a 21 year old female with severe diagnosed PTSD. I suffer from anxiety, depression, ADHD, insomnia, and general lack of motivation as a result. I suffered through a highly traumatic childhood, which involved rape, homelessness, starvation, and abandonment. I lived in over 12 foster homes, and wasn't adopted until I was 10 years old.
When I was born, I tested cocaine-positive. My birth mother recently died of liver cancer as the result of alcoholism, and my doctor believes I am pre-disposed, so I cannot drink. Addiction runs deep in my family, so I cannot in good faith use prescription drugs to treat my symptoms.

Recently, my doctor said I may want to consider getting disability benefits because I find it so difficult to find motivation and stay focused. I don't believe I should be held back from achieving my dreams because of my PTSD, so I've been treating with medical cannabis as often as I can. Unfortunately, it's expensive and without the perfect strain, I find myself focusing on the wrong activities throughout the day, not getting my work finished.

Currently, I work from home as a professional copywriter and budding entrepreneur. Since I found kratom, I've tripled my work output and have picked up several high-profile clients. Before kratom, getting out of bed was a chore, and falling asleep without cannabis was nearly impossible - to the point where I would stay up for 48 hours straight without trying. And when I could sleep, the nightmares continually kept me up.

Kratom has done nothing less than give me my life back. My relationship with my fiance is healthier, I'm keeping my home cleaner, my work is getting finished more quickly and is of higher quality, and my nightmares are now few and far between. Kratom also treats my back pain (nothing extreme, but I see a chiro every so often to have it re-aligned), so I can sit at my desk for longer without needing to take a break.

Kratom is a beautiful herb, and is proof to me that Mother Nature takes care of us if we choose her medicine over man made substances.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

My name is Ryan and I live in Buffalo, NY.  I am a 21 year old engineering student who uses Kratom as an anxiety supplement.  Unfortunately, the DEA's move to make owning Kratom a felony offense punishable by years in prison has caused me to write this letter anonymously.

I do not agree with the DEA's move to ban kratom.  This will make millions of law-abiding Americans into criminals for nothing more than eating a leaf to feel better.  Kratom is safer than alcohol, coffee and cigarettes and has zero recorded deaths related to its use.

Kratom does not make you high.  Kratom provides mild stimulation, and a calming, anti-anxiety effect.  Its effects are as strong as a cup of coffee or a green tea, but different.

No other supplement or drug has worked to help me with my anxiety without making me feel different.  Kratom is the only thing I can take for my panic attacks that won't make me feel high, robotic, or lethargic.

Please do not ban kratom.  It should be regulated like any other dietary supplement and available to purchase without a prescription.

At night, I felt more relaxed and didn't have a problem with my mind racing all night with worry. I was feeling better, and my pain was decreased so much. I also noticed that my blood sugar was easier to control and I wasn't needing as much insulin. I am now able to clean my house, keep up with my active husband and daughter and our two dogs. I am leading my daughter's Girl Scout troop and playing a positive role in the lives of so many girls. All thanks to Kratom. I don't have to take Kratom every day. If I don't take it, I don't have withdrawals like I did with Hydrocodone and Percocet. I am happy! My anxiety and depression packed their bags and left! I hated the way opiates made me feel, and with Kratom, there aren't any of those awful side effects. I feel like since choosing to take this great herbal supplement, Kratom, I have my life back! My Husband has his wife back and my daughter has her Momma back. Feeling better than I have in years because of Kratom, I am constantly reminded of what a great life I have when I feel good. For the first time in years, I look forward to tomorrow. I'm 39 years old...way too young to have felt the way I have. I can't wait to see what each new day brings. You see, this plant that is related to the coffee plant is to thank for this. It is all natural. It doesn't kill people. It isn't addictive. This wonderful plant has helped so many people and should continue to do so. Please take into consideration all of the good that it does for so many people. I know it may seem as if I rambled, but when it comes to talking about Kratom, it is exciting. I want others to receive the same benefits that I have. We all deserve to be happy and healthy. Lori Flohr

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

And last but certainly not least: Prohibiting kratom WILL worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose. There will be blood on your hands.

Truly Yours,

PvV

documents.commentText: My name is Bretton Maybee, I am 34 years old, and have recently graduated with a BA degree in economics from University of California San Diego. I have been married for 7 years and am currently employed has a manager at an Italian restaurant in La Jolla, California. I began using kratom in July of 2015 after a coworker suggested that it might help with the pain I was experiencing prior to a root canal operation. He gave me a small amount and showed me an online supplier where I could purchase more. After doing some research online, I decided to begin taking about 3 grams in the morning before work. Though my tooth pain became less distracting, I began to notice other effects that were positive. For most of my adult life I have suffered from severe depression, and struggled with alcoholism. Over the years I have been treated with prescription anti-depressants and  attended counseling as well as alcoholics anonymous meetings. During the time I began taking kratom for tooth pain, I would regularly drink a 750 lm bottle of hard alcohol every day. Even though I wanted to cut back, I lacked the motivation to break the habit. Once I began taking kratom my craving for alcohol diminished considerably, and I found myself drinking much less than before. In the past I would buy alcohol every night after work. Even if I had some at home, the thought of not having enough to drink would cause me to buy more when I knew I shouldn't. It was affecting my marriage and every other part of my life as well. If I was not at work, I had to be drinking. When I started taking kratom I noticed that my compulsive drinking habit was changing and that I was drinking less each night.  Prior to taking kratom I would drink compulsively until there was none left and I would pass out around 3 or 4 in the morning. Once I began taking kratom I found that I drank much slower, more time would pass before I made another drink, and I wouldn't feel the urge to force myself to drink more than I should. I hadnt planned to use kratom to change my alcoholism, but it seemed to be doing just that. I began brushing and actually flossing my teeth before bed, when in the past I would just pass out often times with my clothes still on. It has been over a year since I began taking kratom, and the effect on my alcoholism is still positive. I have tried prescription medications for depression such as paxil, prozac, mirtazapine and wellbutrin, and found the benefits not to justify the side effects. I feel as though kratom has been far more effective in breaking the cycle of depression and obsessive behavior. I am healthier and happier than before, and it's difficult for me to identify any negative side effects. I feel as though listing kratom as a schedule 1 substance without medical value would be a mistake. It has helped me and I feel that with proper regulation the potential dangers could be minimized. Possibly one of the most dangerous things about kratom is how it is sold and labeled. I purchase kratom online and it comes in a big bag and looks a little like tea. The alkaloid content is not listed and there is really no way of knowing how strong it is, so dosing is done by trial and error. Perhaps if there was a regulation calling for the standardization and labeling of the alkaloid content, it would be safer for users and reduce the risk of mistakenly taking too much. I have learned from experience that taking too much kratom leads to nausea and dizziness. Unlike alcohol, one doesn't take more and more kratom to get "higher". The few times I have taken too much, I was sick to my stomach and very dizzy. However, I would not describe it as intoxicating or "mind altering" the way one would describe the effects of alcohol or other drugs that can severely alter one's judgement and character. I would describe the feeling from a reasonable kratom dose (3-5 grams) as an increase in energy and motivation, and a decrease in anxiety. I would compare these effects to a strong cup of coffee, but without the anxiety and edginess. It doesnt seem to affect motor skills, however in larger doses in can make one dizzy and drowsy. I would compare the drowsy effect from large doses to cough medicines and antihistamines such as benadryl. I am aware that kratom has been sold in a concentrated extract form. These may be more dangerous than the plain dried leaves that I use because it is easier to unintentionally take a much higher dose. I am not a doctor or a pharmacist, and it isnt my intent in writing this letter to give medical advice, It is to share the positive effect I believe kratom has had on me. I imagine it can be abused, however as someone who has abused substances, I dont feel as though the potential is very high; certainly not high enough to warrant a schedule 1 listing or for someone like myself to be seen as a criminal for using it. I believe with  proper research and regulation, kratom can effectively help many people.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am a doctoral candidate completing my 5th year in a School Psychology program with an emphasis in neuropsychological assessment. I was required to undergo coursework in psychopharmacology and have academically and personally investigated the positive and negative effects of the kratom plant. To say kratom use has no negative effects would be a lie, as such is also true for the use of alcohol, cannabis, or coffee; however, overall the positive effects of kratom use outweigh these potential negatives.

The responsible use of kratom assists in mild pain relief, motivation, energy, and mood elevation. The abuse of kratom leads to constipation, nausea, lethargy, and mild withdrawal effects (headache, bad mood, etc. for a short duration). Though such abuse can cause problems, it is not a serious threat to our society any more than people abuse caffeine pills; furthermore, the abuse of tobacco products or alcohol cause significantly more detrimental effects to our communities both health-wise and financially as a society. Kratom should not be made illegal, especially not in something as severe as schedule I, as it has both medicinal effects and mild abuse potential. I have used kratom for two years to combat joint pain from years of athletics that took at toll on my body. I also use kratom with my coffee in the morning to stimulate productivity at work. I have on occasion taken too much kratom, and the results were a stomach ache and dizzy sensation that required a short nap to alleviate the symptoms. It reminded me of having too much coffee, when I became jittery and dizzy.

It is my professional and personal opinion that kratom not be made illegal. In fact, I believe that if the DEA decides to schedule kratom, we as a society will see a worsening of the current opioid epidemic, as the research indicates the use of kratom as an excellent tool in the treatment of opiate addiction. Opiate addicts can use kratom to taper their opiate abuse and eventually get clean, due to the pain relief properties of the kratom plant. Although nowhere near as strong as opoid medications, kratom works on the same receptors in the brain, allowing these individuals to more comfortably and realistically reduce their opioid dosages over time.

In a day where accessible drugs like Tylenol kill thousands of Americans each year, plants like kratom need not be the priority of this administration. This substance is not a dire threat to our society, and although there are negative effects of abuse, just like with any substance (legal or illegal), the positives outweigh these negatives significantly. The DEA should focus their priorities on heroin and methamphetamine use, as these substances hurt our communities. Mildly mood altering plants with few downsides and minimal to no overdose potential need not be the priority of the DEA. Please keep kratom legal! I can't speak enough to the benefits of this plant, and in two years I haven't experienced any significant downsides outside of a stomach ache if I put too much in when making my tea. It would be a real shame to be a criminal for the responsible use of such a helpful plant.

RE: Docket No. DEA-442W

Hello, I would like to express my disagreement that Kratom be placed on Schedule 1. I understand the purpose of emergency scheduling and I do not believe that Kratom needs to be scheduled.

We have an opiate / opioid epidemic in this country. I personally have lost  two co-workers / friends to overdose; one to heroin possibly laced with fentanyl, and the other to Opana. I have also had friends of friends lose their lives in the past year to overdose. Having tried Kratom myself and having read countless accounts of how Kratom has helped people either ween off of opioids or helped manage their pain, I wish I could have shown my dead friends this supplement as a possible way out of addiction. 

To make Kratom a Schedule 1 drug would fly in the face of doing something that can actually save lives from opioid addiction. At this point why would we as a country turn our backs on a supplement  that has such potential, along with all of those who use it responsibly for relief. Let's do the research and see how this can help. But in the meantime, please do not turn tens of thousands of law abiding citizens, Veterans, Americans in to criminals for seeking out alternatives to prescription pain killers or worse. 

Thank you for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText:
Greetings,

I am writing to ask that the DEA keep kratom legal for adults to buy and consume in the United States.

I am a 45-year-old man with a history of back problems, and in recent years kratom has been immensely helpful in maintaining my health and productivity.  Before using kratom powder I managed this pain with over-the-counter pain medicines during the day and alcohol at night.  These affected other areas of my health negatively, such as sleep and weight management.  A friend recommended kratom to me several years ago.  His back problems are similar to mine but more severe, and he had developed a dependence on opioid painkillers as a result.  With kratom he was able to break this dependence on opioids and is much healthier today.  

My own use has been limited to a dose of one teaspoon of kratom powder in the morning, and on some days a teaspoon after working hours.  I have followed this pattern for nearly three years without raising my dosage, and have noticed no negative side effects.  In this time there have been several periods when I was traveling and did not bring kratom with me out of concern for its legal status in the state I was visiting.  While my back pain returned, I did not experience any symptoms of withdrawal or distress.

When the DEA sought to classify kratom as a schedule one substance with no recognized medical benefit, I was surprised and sought out evidence of the harm it could supposedly do. What I found was that the cases of toxicity or death seemed linked to a number of factors of which kratom was just one, and that there was not a case in which kratom was identified definitively as the sole cause of someone's death.  On this basis, banning kratom and hindering research by classifying it as schedule one does not make sense at this time, especially given the thousands of deaths attributable to legal substances such as alcohol and opioids every year.

I urge the DEA to keep kratom legal for adults to buy and consume in the United States.

First off, I would like to start off by saying I am very grateful for you guys at the DEA to be taking the time and resources to collect more information on kratom, thank you.

I found  out the basics of it, that it can be helpful to a range of things such as depression, insomnia, fatigue and the big one for me.. anxiety. 

I didn't only pay attention to the positive side tho, I also got a good perspective on the possible negative side of kratom like how it can cause withdrawals in some users, but my personal belief on that is that there can be withdraws from many things that we glorify today such as coffee, heck, sometimes I feel depressed and experience "withdrawals" from clearly healthy things like missing a run in the morning. So if the user isnt responsible enough yes there can most definetely be consequences but.. more people have died from caffiene consumption than kratom and we all love our coffee!

So I decided to give kratom a try and I purchased some "green vein bali kratom" and it was in a powder form and I started off by first trying 1 teaspoon ( a very small amount of the plant) I had to workout that day and after about 10-15 minutes I started to feel the effects come on. I took it immediately after waking up and as soon as it kicked in the morning brain fog started to fade. I didnt feel a "high" I just felt as if I had a cup of coffee without the jitters and more motivation. If I could explain how kratom effects me best, I would give this analogy: Off of kratom my mind, my thoughts, ideas, goals, everything that motivates me is like a pile of dominoes and on kratom all of those dominoes are lined up perfectly, allowing me to have more clarity and a better picture of my goals. I feel incredibly motivated on kratom and it is honestly life changing, I've had depression and anxiety most of my life and using kratom has been a miracle for those things affecting me.

documents.commentText:
My name is Roy Johnson. I am 51 years old. I live in San Antonio, Texas. I work in construction.
When I was 45 I began have health issues I relate to andropaus: insomnia and high blood pressure. I slept and average of 3 hours a night, was always irritable from lack of sleep and my blood pressure was constantly skyrocketing. I went to The Sleep Center of San Antonio and my general practitioner Dr. Jirka for help. 
Dr Jirka could do nothing for me. The sleep center gave me a sheet of paper with a list of sleep hygiene regulations: (no coffee after 3PM, exercise, have a good bed, ect) and an option to use a couple of different sleep drugs. One had a time release and kept me down all night. I would wake up in the morning and have a hangover like an alcoholic. 
Needless to say there was no effective treatment for me. My sleepless nights went on for about 5 years. Once a month I might sleep 8 hours in a single night. I was going crazy and did not like being alive because I always felt so miserable. My eyes were red and sore all the time. I hallucinated. MY ears rang. My fingers trembled. I was old and falling apart.
I researched and tried many things. Melatonin cocktails. Mixtures of prescriptions with vitamins. Catnip. Aspirin. Nothing worked. My blood pressure was so high from stress caused by sleep that I I thought I would have to drink alcohol or consume sleeping pills all day just to remain calm.
I found kratom through my own research. The first time I took it I thought it tasted gross and it was another lost cause. No. It worked! I slept and I woke up. What was this miracle herb that was giving me my life back? That was 2 years ago and I am almost in tears thinking how this plant has changed my temperament. 
Banning kratom is a very bad thing to do, people like me would go back to suffering physically and emotionally. The government that is supposed to protect me and my rights would be hurting me and all the good work I did for myself would be wasted. If the FDA regulated it I could never afford it along with the time and money it costs to go see a doctor. I know what strains work for me and how to consume it. I experimented and learned what is good for me. 
Anybody can learn how to take it. You cant take an abusive amount of it because your stomach will just throw it back up. I have never heard of any legitimate case where a new user or regular user had any type of medical emergency due to kratom. These stories we hear of people in the emergency room due to kratom are full-on fabrication. They are similar to a person drinking a bottle of whisky and getting his stomach pumped but then forgetting to tell the doctor he also inhaled a gram of illegal cocaine with the alcohol.  If a person ends up in the hospital due to kratom they were doing something else on the side with it. That something else caused the real problem but its probably illegal and nobody wants to talk about it. 
Thank you for reading my letter. Please dont ban kratom.

documents.commentText:
Hello, I am a 56 year old grandmother and Gulf War Veteran who has served in the U.S. Army for 35 years. I am a college graduate and have worked for the DoD for 28 years. Before I became ill, I was the most outgoing, fun-loving, positive, funny, optimistic person who would sing every day and enjoy life like I never wanted it to end.  
In April, 1997, I became quite ill with recurring nausea, weakness, headaches, sun-sensitivity and was eventually diagnosed with an auto-immune disease known as Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD). After numerous attempts to contain the illness, the doctors were finally able to control the disease with the medication Hydroxychloroquine, otherwise known as Plaquenil. During that time, I also learned I was at the beginning stages of osteoarthritis. Unfortunately, in January, 2015, I had to stop taking the Plaquenil as my eyes showed signs of Plaquenil Toxicity (a side-effect of Plaquenil) which, if left untreated, can cause blindness.
Approximately three months later I began to experience severe, unrelenting, shocking pain in my muscles and joints throughout my entire body. The fatigue that accompanied the pain was debilitating. It was something that I have never felt before and I knew something was very wrong. It took months before I received an official diagnosis - Fibromyalgia and Gulf War Syndrome. At the time I knew nothing about the illnesses but found out rather quickly that this was not something I wanted to live with for the rest of my life... 
It had been over a year and a half since the onset of these illnesses and with numerous types of medications, I had gotten to a somewhat, more manageable state; however, I was still reeling with many symptoms of these awful, debilitating illnesses to include Degenerative Joint Disease and Degenerative Disc Disease, and I was desperate to get my pain-free, old-self back. The illnesses had stolen so much from me. Leisure activities were non-existent. Plans could not be made as I never knew how I was going to feel on any particular day, especially on extreme weather days as the sun/heat made me very ill and the cold was brutally painful on my joints. The pain was so severe at times that tears would begin to fall as I tried to be brave and stay strong.  
My mood had become very somber; I was less-optimistic about my future. I had to seek professional mental health counseling for depression and anxiety. I was not accepting this way of life. I was going to find relief somehow, some way... I decided to find some Facebook friends who shared the same fate as me. I did a search and found a FB page for those diagnosed with Fibromyalgia. I was amazed at all of the people who suffered just as I did. From them, I learned how I could better manage my illness (foods, vitamins, etc.) and I learned about Kratom - the all-natural God-given plant that helps thousands and thousands of people who, without it, would greatly suffer on a daily basis. I was quite skeptical at first but the more I learned about it, the more comfortable I became. This miracle plant had literally saved lives! Not only did this plant help those with pain but it also helped with depression and anxiety. There were shared stories of heroin and narcotic addicts who became clean from consuming Kratom and it completely changed their life for the better. I was in awe over all the wonderful testimonies and stories. I decided to give it a try to see if it could help me like it helped so many others. As nervous as I was, living with this horrible pain, I was willing to try anything at that point. My fianc was extremely supportive of Kratom because it was natural herbal remedy and not some man-made chemical concoction. I took  teaspoon of the awful-tasting Kratom with some orange juice and waited to see what would happen, if anything. Right around the 20 minute mark I began to feel the excruciating pain in my lower back, neck, and legs begin to subside. The pain sensation became less and less and I began to cry, I became  emotionally overwhelmed by how well it helped ease my pain. I had finally something that gave me hope in getting my life back.     
Today, I couldn't imagine my life without Kratom. If a ban would take place I would have to go back to living in pure agony as would thousands of others. A Kratom ban would truly be detrimental to recovering alcoholics, as well as heroin, opioid, and other illicit drug addicts. Please do not make Kratom a Schedule 1 substance. It is beyond my comprehension that our government would even consider trying to make a safe, all-natural herbal botanical (in the coffee family) that helps so many people in so many ways, illegal. With the current opioid epidemic we are losing so many people on a daily basis, it's time to start saving lives, not ending them. Kratom saves lives! Do the right thing and let this plant alone. It's not hurting anyone; it's helping everyone...

documents.commentText:
How Do I Share My Comments on Kratom?

The American Kratom Association has led the charge in an attempt to keep kratom legal in the United States.

This organization has launched a website at www.KratomComments.org where users can complete a simple form that will be submitted directly to the DEA. The site was created to ensure that all comments are being counted and that a independent count

In addition to your comments, the form asks for some basic information, such as your name, address, email and phone.

Please note that you can submit the form anonymously by entering the word "ANONYMOUS" in each of the fields for name, address, phone and email.

 The comment section is where you can share your experiences with kratom and your thoughts on why it's so important to keep this natural plant legal and unrestricted in the United States.


What Should I Write in the Kratom Comments Section?

We encourage you to share your personal experiences as a kratom user. Just keep the 5,000 character limit in mind when writing your comments. (You can use the "preview" button on the bottom of the form to check the length before sending.)

If you're unsure of how or where to start, consider these points as you prepare to write your comments to the DEA:

 What first attracted you to kratom? Were you seeking a natural pain or anxiety reliever? Were you addicted to prescription painkillers or heroin and seeking something to ease the withdrawal symptoms? Do you suffer from chronic pain, but cannot afford prescription drugs? Paint a picture of what your life was like before kratom and what motivated you to try kratom. I experienced all of these.

 What has kratom done for you and your life?  Explore the benefits of having kratom in your life. Has kratom relieved your pain or anxiety? Has kratom allowed you to become a more productive person? Has kratom allowed you to overcome an illness or condition that you were unable to overcome previously? Does kratom make you a happier, more well-adjusted member of society? Explain precisely WHY kratom is important to you! Yes all of these.

 What would you lose if kratom was banned tomorrow?  Would you be unable to work due to pain or anxiety? Would your social anxiety prevent you from pursuing college classes? Would you be unable to care for your children effectively without kratom? Would your overall quality of life suffer? Paint a picture of what your life would look like without kratom. What losses you would you suffer if kratom was made illegal? I might seek pain killer opiods.

 Have you ever experienced serious problems in terms of a kratom overdose, addiction or side effects? Do you feel kratom is safe? Have you experienced serious side effects? Do you feel you're addicted to kratom? These are primary areas of concern for the DEA, so any thoughts on safety and addictiveness are important to discuss. Cheap Kratom would have a sulfur smell upon burping, but no side effects.


Why is All This Happening? 

On August 31, the DEA announced its plan to make kratom's two main alkaloids a Schedule 1 controlled substance - a category reserved for dangerous drugs with no recognized medicinal usage, including heroin, LSD and methamphetamine. September 30 was the earliest this new classification could go into effect, making kratom illegal to possess or sell.

The DEA attempted to justify the emergency scheduling measure by calling kratom an "imminent" health threat. The DEA cited kratom's connection to 15 deaths (although 14 of those incidents involved other drugs in addition to kratom.)

The agency also cited the 660 kratom-related calls to poison control centers between 2010 and 2015, although just 428 of those calls involved kratom only. For perspective, over the same six-year timeframe, the CDC has received 23,203 calls concerning caffeine and a total of 66,300 calls concerning essential oils.

The DEA's plan to list kratom as a Schedule 1 substance drew significant objection from kratom proponents, many of whom use kratom to self-wean off dangerous opiates or to self-manage pain that would otherwise require opiate painkillers.

In fact, a DEA spokesperson named Melvin Patterson told the media that "I have been with the DEA for 20 years and have never seen this level of public response." A number of lawmakers also spoke out, as did attorneys for The American Kratom Association, amongst others.

So in a rare move, the DEA has backed off its plans to list kratom as a Schedule 1 controlled substance, but now, your action is more important than ever! This public comment period is extremely important, as the feedback that the authorities receive from members of the public - people like YOU - will help paint a more accurate picture of kratom's real characteristics and benefits.

To whom it may concern,

I am writing this to ask that the DEA to please hold off on banning kratom. It has been a lifesaver for me and some of my family members, they are each sending their own comments but as for myself-
In 2003 I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia and within 6 months time my doctor had me on morphine, Vicodin, tramadol and the fentanyl patch all at the same time. It was a complete disaster. After a year of that I went on suboxone to get off of all that medication and while I have never gone back to taking any of it I did wind up seeing a dr who prescribed subutex for me for over 4 years. I thought that was my miracle drug, no need to to ever increase my dosage, didn't get all looped out while taking it, thought I was fine. I did find myself thinking that I did not want to stay on it forever though and in time that dr lost his license and the decision was made. Anybody that has ever taken that medication for any length of time will tell you how excruciatingly painful it is to get off of and I can tell you, for myself, it was hell. 
Finally, about 3 weeks in and still suffering miserably, I found out about kratom. I researched it and learned about all the facts I'm sure you already have in front of you. It's related to the coffee plant, been used for thousands of years, is not inherently dangerous at all (in fact any deaths people try to use as evidence against it are deaths where other substances were involved.)
Kratom gave me my life back. After years of chronic and debilitating insomnia I was sleeping peacefully. Any pain I felt was managed without having to deal with the horrible side effects of narcotic use was gone and I felt like me again. Happy, motivated, productive...everything positive. Kratom does not make people high, does not cause hallucinations, or psychotic issues, it is simply a natural plant that grows on our planet and you can not overdose on kratom. Should someone ingest too much your body simply rejects it. 
I think we all know, whether or not they want to admit it, that the big pharmaceutical companies are the ones truly behind banning kratom because of all the people that are no longer taking their chemical narcotics. And I have never been someone to believe in conspiracy theories, so I am not just throwing that out there. Banning kratom would be a huge disservice to everyone in this country that has been able to take their lives back. I fully support regulating it, but banning it is completely uncalled for and should never happen.
Thank you for taking the time to read this comment and the thousands of others that you are receiving. I hope that the DEA will take the time to really investigate the realities of this miraculous plant and act accordingly. 
Sincerely,
Leisl Larson

documents.commentText: Removing the ability to further research kratoms beneficial properties by classifying it as schedule 1 is a very curious (at best) attempt by the DEA. I no longer use kratom but took it daily for 2 years as a herbal alternative to Methadone. I have nothing bad to say about Kratom and it helped me get off of the drug methodone, which arguably is worse than the pain medicine I was addicted to causing me to use Methadone in the first place. Kratom is a far cry from any other opiates. There's a natural ceiling that keeps abuse and overdose from happening that real opioids don't have. I could say a lot about its benefits compared to any real opiates but I digress. I mainly benefitted from kratom for its anxiety curbing affects which is the main reason I became addicted to afore mentioned opiates to begin with. I have yet to find a non-addictive alternative to kratom that helps me with my anxiety, despite taking several prescribed drugs to replace kratom. In the very least, more research should be done (and allowed for crying out loud?) because my experience with kratom was only positive and I'm not alone. It could be found that long term effects from daily use are problematic. However this is unlikely because kratom has been used daily by field workers in Asia for hundreds of years with no real documented negative health concerns.. much longer than any prescription drugs currently on the market today. Me and my family doctor who discussed the use of kratom with me at length can attest that the time I used it daily there was no negative effects. We did blood work and other tests because I wanted to be sure I wasn't hurting my body inadvertently and they too showed no negative effects. We were both very dissapojted at the potential ban but I wanted to be prepared for it so I stopped it's use. Now I take anti-anxiety and anti-depression meds prescribed at a much higher cost and with many side affects and am back to the daily struggle of not using addictive opiates without kratom to satisfy the cravings. I've taken many medications and have experienced no negative affects from kratom like I have on those approved substances. Now I'm taking numerous prescriptions to take the place of the one herbal supplement and they don't work as well. I hope the truth wins out and undoubtedly many, many will be helped out if it does, and I can quit struggling with addiction depression and anxiety. On a final note: The poison control calls don't seem like a solid case to build against kratom use. Nearly any supplement or substance intentionally abused will lead to people calling poison control. Kratom is no different, and again, it just causes a nervous and nauseous stomach and possible vomiting if one does over do it, much like caffeine. Also like caffeine this can be a panicky feeling and no doubt can cause one to think something's wrong. Especially children mostly who try to "get a buzz" off anything they can get their hands on. If this poison control thing is really the issue than why not simply put an age restriction on it rather than classifying it erroneously? There must be something else to this story because my experience and almost everyone else's is that kratom is harmless and beneficial, and it being some sort of health hazard is comical. Just my 2 cents.

documents.commentText:
My name is Marco Flores. I beg on behalf of myself and my family to keep kratom legal. I've been drinking kratom for 2 years now. I struggle with a chronic panic attack disorder having 2 to 3 attack in a day, every day. I've tried over 2 dozen different anti-psychotics, anxiolytic, and anti-depressants some prescribed at outrageous dosages yet I've never had any success at being treated or even relieved from my nightmarish condition. Kratom is the only thing that helps, it's not a cure and sometimes on really bad days it won't help. However the other 90% of the time, it's the only defense I have. It helps me be normal, a feeling that I had long forgotten. There is a ill-conceived notion that kratom gets you high or intoxicated. This couldn't be further from the truth. Kratom, as you know, is from the Rubiaceae family making it akin to coffea from which coffee is derived. Similarly, kratom helps boost cognitive performance which is the polar opposite of intoxicating the drinker. It is NOT an opioid or an opiate. Another poorly conceived notion due to the fact that it contains alkaloids that are selective full agonists of the -opioid receptor. However by this definition, that would indicate that vitex, also known as chasteberry, is also an opioid/opiate because it contains biochemicals that bind to opiate receptors (Journal of Ethnopharmacology ISSN: 0378-8741) yet Vortex can be purchased over the counter at Walgreens.  Remeron, an anti-depressant I currently take to aid my sleep would be, by the DEA's definition, an opioid/opiate as well for it also acts as a -opioid receptor partial agonist (British Journal of Pharmacology ISSN: 1476-5381)
 I see the doctor regularly and constantly take a variety blood panels and urinalyses. I have no physiological abnormalities. I am healthy in every way except my chronic panic disorder. Please, I've only recently gotten my life back, please don't snatch it away from me, there's so much I want to do and if you make kratom a Schedule I substance, it WILL mean the end for me. My life and thousands of others WILL be destroyed. Please don't take our lives away.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

I am a chronic pain patient who has struggled for the past ten years of my life with chronic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and debilitating nerve pain. I have tried many pain medications from doctors over the years: various NSAIDS, opiates, gabapentin, baclofen, muscle relaxers, and more. None of these medications helped me half as much as kratom has in managing my pain and allowing me to live a semi-normal, happy, and productive life.

Before I started taking small doses of kratom each day, I was unable to hold down a full time job and was limited to part time work, because I would miss so many days due to severe nerve pain and muscle spasms. As you can imagine, this was incredibly depressing and difficult to deal with. I had no energy, was always in pain, and felt generally miserable. Other medications left me feeling too foggy to be functional, too sleepy, or too impaired to be productive. Kratom allows me to have the energy to get out of bed in the morning, and brings me irreplaceable pain relief that drastically improves my quality of life and ability to contribute to the world as a productive citizen. I've been able to go to work consistently this year, and kratom is the biggest reason for this. I can honestly say that kratom has changed my life and maybe even saved it. I used to contemplate suicide from the pain I was in. These feelings will likely come back if I am unable to use kratom to treat my medical conditions.

If kratom is criminalized and I am unable to take it, I will lose my most valuable pain management tool and my ability to live a somewhat normal life. Not to mention, I would be treated as a criminal simply for trying to treat my pain and feel better. It is important to mention that kratom powder or leaf has shown to be very safe when used responsibly. There are no deaths on record that can be attributed to solely kratom overdose. The only deaths reported by the media, have shown that other opiates or illicit drugs were responsible for overdoses that the DEA has unfairly attributed to kratom. Meanwhile, according the CDC, "from 1999 to 2014, more than 165,000 people have died in the U.S. from overdoses related to prescription opioids." There are thousands of Americans struggling with opiate addiction in the US, and kratom has been shown to be an safe and effective tool for weaning addicts off of opiates in addition to its various medical uses.

It is also worth noting that placing this drug on the Schedule 1 Controlled Substances list takes away a huge and valuable opportunity for scientists to engage in further study on kratom's active ingredients, and create promising pharmaceuticals for pain relief in the future. This would be a huge blow to the medical research community in America and the thousands of patients this research could help.

Thank you for your time, and I strongly urge you to consider the negative impacts that criminalizing kratom use could have on patients like me suffering from otherwise untreatable pain. I beg you not to take this medication away from me and thousands of others who have found relief and productivity from it. It brings us patients unimaginable relief, spares us from daily suffering, and gives us hope for the future.

Sincerely,

Scott Anderson


References

1. CDC. Wide-ranging online data for epidemiologic research (WONDER). Atlanta, GA: CDC, National Center for Health Statistics; 2016. Available at http://wonder.cdc.gov.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA

Below is a testimony written by my colleague who wishes to remain anonymous. He is a father, husband and sole bread-winner of the family. This is in response to the DEA's intention to make Kratom a Schedule I substance. It includes a great amount of information on what Kratom is and the what will happen if the DEA goes through with the emergency scheduling.

Thanks,

Jim

Dear DEA,
 
Please remove Mitragynine & 7-hydroxymitragynine which is in Kratom from becoming a Schedule I substance.
 
I am 29 and suffer from a herniated disc, chronic neck pain, TMJ, arthritis in my neck. I support a family of four on a single income as a Help Desk Tech. I have been to many doctors with little success for treatment. I have found that Kratom improves my quality of life after a hard days work. It isnt comparable to any drugs, marijuana, alcohol or other stimulants.  Kratom helps to improve my quality of life that I suffer with chronic pain. Please dont make this herb illegal. Cervical injections, botox injections, chiropractic care, physical therapy, acupuncture, massage therapy, yoga exercises have not helped with my pain.
 
Kratom is a well-known, well-researched herbal substance drawn from the leaves of trees within the coffee family. The number of cases of documented harm from kratom use is remarkably low, both as an absolute matter and when considered against the extensive history of use of kratom, both inside and outside the United States
 
Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine are two of the primary alkaloids of this plant. These two compounds are not synthetic and should not be lumped together with  "bath salts" or "spice".
 
Kratom has been used as a medicine by many people for thousands of years. It is a potent remedy for physical pain, anxiety and depression, and could be used to aid with opiate withdrawal by those who would like to quit using illicit drugs such as heroin. Kratom is NOT a hallucinogen and should not be classified as such. Adding mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as a Schedule I substance is rash and unjustified prohibition, resulting in a foreseeable increase in street drug-related crime, as well as a punishment to those who are currently using it responsibly to treat various ailments.

The reason that there are no deaths solely attributed to Kratom is because Kratom does not affect your respiratory capacity. It does not slow down your central nervous system. It's potential to do harm is virtually impossible.

Kratom has very limited recreational capacity.  The White House petition has over 100,000 signatures for the "Please do not make Kratom a Schedule I Substance." 

The federal government has invested significant resources to develop alternative pain management strategies. This includes a study funded by the National Institutes of Health in partnership with the University of Massachusetts and the University of Mississippi to investigate the use of Kratom as a remedy for opioid withdrawal. This study led the researchers to apply for a patent identifying the Kratom extract, mitragyinine, as a useful treatment for other addictive drugs besides opiate derivatives. The DEAs decision to place Kratom as a Schedule I substance will put a halt on federally funded research and innovation surrounding the treatment of individuals suffering from opioid and other addictionsa significant public health threat. Remember the DDear Colleague Letters of Senator Hatch and Congressman Mark Pocan.
 
We hope you realize the threat this scheduling causes the people seeking legitimate use of this special plant to improve our quality of life. Attached are testimonies and facts about Kratom along with other facts listed below. 

Sincerely,
 
Anonymous

Florida Department of Law Enforcement Report
speciosa.org/official-statewide-intelligence-drug-report-kratom-and-the-impact-to-florida/

documents.commentText: I am posting my personal opinion, and experience with kratom.  In June of 2010  I was injured in a MVA. My general practitioner prescribed me opioid pain medication along with a muscle relaxer for the hip pain following the accident. I  went on to physical therapy and eventually was diagnosed with si joint dysfunction. I went on to a surgeon who recommended fusion surgery. After the surgery I developed what my doctor said was radicular symptomatic dystrophy and sent me to a pain management doctor. I was giving high doses of the narcotic pain medicine oxycodone and a long acting morphine along with almost 2 dozen spine blocks and epidural injections. After all that my doctor recommended a nerve stimulator and/or a pain pump. I didn't elect for additional surgery, but was still given high amounts of the narcotic pain meds. I couldn't work, and had to quit my job. I became seriously depressed. Those drugs changed my personality and I no longer cared about anything. Then it came a point in time where the drugs no longer were effective. I literally was in MORE pain while taking the pills then I was without them. I t became very difficult to get relief with my current dose. I struggled with the dependency on the pills often running 3-4 days short every month. I finally decided to stop cold turkey. I was miserable for about 3 weeks, but I was free of the dependency. About 3 months later I found a job and went back to work, but was still in pain, I tried some kratom ( I had previously read about it for pain) and it worked!! That was a year ago and I have used kratom ever since. There were times I would run out while waiting for my order to arrive, and I had Zero withdrawal symptoms. The way kratom works is so different from opioid drugs, kratom doesn't interfere with the reward  part of the brain. It also doesn't give a crash once it wears off. No spike in pain, no strong urge to re-dose. I am a married woman with 3 children, I am 43 years old, and I work as a professional in the college school system. Kratom has given me my life back. I have also returned to college to seek my bachelor's degree in sociology. I hope to work as a drug councillor one day. I would love to help others who find themselves dependant on substances after being injured. Making kratom a schedule 1 will definitely impact my life and my ability to remain a functional member of society. My husband,children, and grandchildren will be negatively impacted as well. No matter what  I willl never take opioid pain relievers again, but my ability to work and take care of my family will be seriously affected, and my ability to support my myself. Pain pills cost me a job, my house, almost cost me my marriage, but most of all almost cost me my life. Kratom is a God send for people like me. I truly believe we haven't seen the worst of the opioid crisis. The effects of the crisis are far reaching. It doesn't take much for a person to be in it's grip. I feel only people who have had the experience can truly understand why Kratom is so important. I implore you to take what all of us kratom users are attesting to, and separate the few unscrupulous people who marketed kratom as a " legal high" and find that kratom in and of itself not dangerous. I believe this earth has given us this plant to heal and not harm. People who abuse drugs will find themselves disappointed with kratom because it will not get them high. Kratom is useful for opiate dependency IF the person wants to abstain from opiates. This plant is not a heroin substitute. It is hard to explain why Kratom works so well, there is nothing to compare it to. If you or your loved one were stricken with a chronic pain condition, wouldn't you want to be able to manage your pain and be able to get your life back? That's how crucial kratom is for me. It makes life worth living again. Keep kratom legal!!

documents.commentText:
My name is Torri Raines, and I am a 22-year-old graduate student in Linguistics.

I am writing to voice my opposition to the DEA's proposed scheduling of the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. I wholeheartedly oppose the DEA's proposed scheduling action because I and millions of others have experienced kratom's value firsthand, and making this valuable plant illegal will damage the health and livelihoods of perhaps millions of Americans.

I started taking kratom during my undergraduate studies five years ago to help relieve the stress of academic life as well as manage depression and anxiety for which I have also been attending therapy throughout my college career. I take kratom now for the same reasons with the additional factor that it relieves my chronic jaw tightness and pain, which my dentist told me is indicative of developing TMJ. 

I am a highly ambitious, high-achieving student and hopeful career academic/teacher, and kratom is an irreplaceable asset in managing the mental and physical ailments that may otherwise impede my ability to succeed. Kratom relieves my symptoms without altering my psyche the way an anti-depressant could, and without dulling my intellect the way pharmaceutical painkillers would.

Kratom is important not only to me, but to my partner and family. My partner utilizes kratom to help alleviate symptoms of chronic facial tics and the pain from chronic mouth sores.

This plant is a lifesaver to countless people. It is a safe, natural alternative to addictive pharmaceuticals and improves my quality of life as a productive member of society. It is not addictive or harmful. Classifying kratom as a schedule I substance is a mistake that will only result in more deaths in the US's opiate epidemic.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. With U.S. currently suffering from an overdose epidemic linked to opioids, it's absurd to criminalize a substance that many people use to help with opioid withdrawal. people use to help with opioid withdrawal. If you prohibit Kratom more people who struggle with addiction could be criminalized, which is exactly the opposite direction drug policy should be going.
 In the meantime, given the now-widespread moral, political and scientific consensus that drug use and addiction are best treated as health issues rather than as criminal issues, there's no good reason for people who use kratom to be treated as criminals - especially considering how much we already know about prohibition's disproportionate impact on people of color and other marginalized communities.
 In fact, strict regulations are exactly what we need - such as quality control measures, product labeling requirements, as well as marketing, branding and retail display restrictions, which are long proven to reduce substance misuse and youth access.  (Funnily enough, it was reported last week that teen rates of alcohol and tobacco use are at their lowest in decades - a massive public health success that was accomplished through education and legal regulation, rather than criminalizing and arresting teens who smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol.)
 STOP THE BAN ON KRATOM !! Plz & Ty

documents.commentText:
I would like to request that the DEA retract the rule proposing to place the psychoactive compounds found in kratom into Schedule I. 
Placing kratom in Schedule I would be tantamount to placing a sheep in a lions' den. Kratom is nowhere near as dangerous as heroin, cocaine, and mephedrone. Patients admitted to the emergency room with kratom in their system are there because of whatever else they took, not because of kratom. The effects of kratom in moderate doses are comparable to drinking a cup of coffee. Yet, no one in their right mind would consider banning caffeine after people who drank too much of it, or mixed it with other substances were admitted to a hospital or died.
Most importantly, kratom could have many medical uses that will never be explored if it is closed to clinical trials. Personally, the way it clears up my seasonal allergies is incomparable to anything I've tried before and it doesn't have any negative side effects. I also use it to manage menstrual pain. Unlike NSAIDs, which is what I would take instead, I never have to worry about whether kratom will upset my stomach, taking away one kind of pain only to cause another. I feel better about taking a natural substance than something created in a laboratory. I don't notice any withdrawal symptoms if I don't use it.
Kratom has been used for hundreds, if not thousands of years in Southeast Asia, yet there is no epidemic there. 
Please keep in mind that kratom leaf, by itself, in a reasonable amount, does not cause any problems, but rather solves them. Caffeine and alcohol have the same, if not greater, potential for abuse than kratom. Alcohol caused 88,129 deaths from 2006-2010, according to CDC's Ardi application (https://nccd.cdc.gov/DPH_ARDI/default/default.aspx). 15 "kratom-related" deaths, not due to kratom alone, from 2014-2016 are incomparable to that number. 660 cases of kratom exposure over 2010-2015, again, most likely in combination with other substances, does not compare to 2,200 DEATHS from alcohol poisoning each year, not just cases (http://www.cdc.gov/vitalsigns/alcohol-poisoning-deaths/). 

I wish to thank you for allowing the public to voice our opinions on this matter. Please do not take this plant away from us. There are greater evils out there.

documents.commentText:
I am deeply thankful you are taking the time to hear from the public on this important matter, which will impact millions of people in the United States. Your consideration is much appreciated.

I am a 39-year-old, responsible, happily married, classical musician, and mother-of-two who has been safely and moderately using kratom for the past two years to treat my lifelong struggles with anxiety and depression. I discovered this wonderful plant following many failed attempts to treat my mood disorders via pharmaceuticals prescribed by my psychiatrist. Kratom is the only thing that has consistently worked for me after twenty-five years of trying standard methods. In the two years I have been using kratom on a daily basis, I have experienced no increase in tolerance to its mood-improving benefits and have experienced no negative side-effects. Kratom does not produce a high (and I know what a high feels like, as I was prescribed Adderall at one point for attention-deficit issues). In my experience, kratom is safer and more beneficial than any prescription medicine; it produces a gentle (more gentle than coffee) increase in energy and mental focus and improves feelings of well-being while not causing any unwanted effects. Another miraculous aspect of kratom is that it does not lose its effectiveness over time as with prescription drugs and other substances; preventing tolerance is made possible by rotating strains of kratom, each of which has slightly differing alkaloids. My tolerance has actually lowered over the past two years from 4 grams a day to only 2 grams while enjoying the same results. There is no drug on earth that works as beneficially, as consistently over time and as harmlessly; thankfully kratom is not a drug. 

My husband (who was at first skeptical) and my children have been thrilled with the help kratom has afforded me, so kratom has indirectly had an immensely positive impact on my family, and even my friends and coworkers. Please do not categorize this plant as an illegal, recreational drug;  to do so would endanger millions of Americans who rely on the health benefits that Kratom alone can provide.

I appreciate your intention to ensure public safety. Thank you so much for your time.

documents.commentText:
My name is Alicia Zvonar and I think making Kratom a Schedule I drug is a mistake.  I have several medical issues that cause me to have chronic pain.  I have several bulging and degenerating discs, bone spurs on my spine and scoliosis.  I also suffer from osteoarthritis that is continuing to get worse; some days I find it hard to tie my shoes, write or even type.  Typing is essential to me because I am in school to get my MS in Substance Abuse Counseling.  I also have a job in retail as well as a job cleaning corporate apartments for another company; being able to move is essential to me.  
     My story begins back a little over 10 years ago, I began seeing a pain specialist who began treating my chronic pain with Percocet and Vicodin.  I believe he was over-prescribing me when I stopped seeing him.  I then began buying oxycontin on the streets.  Soon I was doing heroin to treat my incessant chronic pain.  I got help to get off the heroin with Subutex but the withdrawals were worse than the heroin withdrawals.  After consulting with my regular doctor, I went off the Subutex cold turkey with the help of beta blockers and Klonopin.  As I am sure you are aware, I could no longer take prescription pain medications due to my addiction.  I did some research on natural, herbal solutions to manage my chronic pain.  I found Kratom.  
     Although Kratom does not completely eliminate my pain, it makes it tolerable so that I can do everyday things like work and cook dinner for my husband.  Kratom does not cause the euphoria that prescription pain medication or heroin did.  It only helps to manage my pain and the depression that coincides with that pain. I have never had a problem with taking too much Kratom.  I did, however, overdose on heroin once and Percocet several times.  When I am not in pain, I have more energy; I was even able to enroll into a Master's degree program to become a substance abuse counselor.  I am studying to be a drug counselor and Kratom is helping me to do that.  What kind of example would I set if Kratom should become a Schedule I drug? 
     There is a severe epidemic in this country of prescription pain pill and heroin addiction.  Making Kratom a Schedule I drug would leave some people no choice but to go back to prescription drugs and illicit drugs.  I wasted too many years of my life in a euphoric stupor to help ease my pain.  Please do not take away the only thing that helps me that lets me maintain a clear head and is not lethal.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am a 29 year old male living in central North Carolina. I have been employed full-time as a technical support agent for a large communications company for over three years now. I make a decent wage, and combined with my fiance's, my household income is over 70k per year. I am also a recovering opiate addict, and I am writing to ask that the DEA to NOT schedule the plant known as kratom or any of its components.

After many years of addiction to opiate painkillers and eventually heroin, and having made several attempts at getting clean through rehab and self-medicating with suboxone purchased on the street, I entered an outpatient methadone program. I took methadone for two and a half years, and after the long and difficult process of tapering down my dose, and then ceasing to take it entirely, I began using kratom to ease the severe withdrawal symptoms. After being clean for about a year I had a short-lived relapse, and again began taking kratom to ease the cravings - though not full withdrawals - that I had awakened.

That last relapse was over two years ago, and I have not consumed any type of opiate since. I have continued to take kratom regularly as I've found it has other beneficial properties, such as slight mood elation, greater focus of attention, and a generally more positive outlook. Most importantly, it has kept away any kind of desire to seek out opiates or anything that would lead to relapse (I also have completely abstained from alcohol during this time, something else I had abused though to a lesser extent). During these two years I have even been prescribed opiates (hydrocodone) legitimately following several dental issues and have left them all in the bottle, because a) I've found kratom to be a more effective painkiller, and b) I have no desire to risk falling back down that hole to addiction.

Scheduling kratom would turn myself and millions of others into criminals overnight, and further this country's failing, regressive, and almost universally reviled "war on drugs." It would create a new criminal enterprise where there previously was none. Kratom is certainly worth more research, and perhaps regulation as a supplement to ensure a standard of quality and lack of adulterants. But taking the action of emergency scheduling kratom would be a drastic overreaction the the laughable evidence of 15 kratom deaths - only one of which being actually attributable TO kratom - and the infinitesimal 660 calls to poison control centers over a period of years. In this current opiate addiction crisis we need to make it easier to obtain alternatives to opiates, not harder. And as much as I appreciate the small but daily benefit I get from taking kratom, my concern lies more with those who use it for painful chronic conditions who would then be forced back in to a very real and much more life-threatening opiate addiction if kratom is scheduled.

I do very much appreciate the opportunity to share my comments. Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:
I am a 31-year-old local food system organizer, event coordinator, growers' market manager {plus an aspiring grower, myself}, and father of three. The positive and productive life that I live today in comparison to what it was like a decade ago, is stark. That time ago, I was a full-blown heroin addict, but thankfully found a way out through the peer-run, work-driven, residential rehab called Delancey Street in San Francisco. For two years, I worked on myself  and my future, and when I got out, I was hired because of the reputation of the program I came from. Everyday I am grateful for that place and the people behind it, but the only way I was able to get to the stage of long term recovery, was to go through a process that is quite terrible . . . opiate withdrawal. I tried everything. Methadone, buprenorphine, cold turkey, valium, all which perpetuated the same behavior, and rubbing elbows with other addicts that were on the fence like I was. If only there was something that could've helped me drop the habit and maintain my cravings in a healthy, time-tested way . . . like what people are saying about kratom. Though I have never used kratom for opiate withdrawal, I have found it to be a very beneficial plant for me. 
A little over a year ago, a friend had mentioned kratom just before I had a minor surgery. Not wanting to go the route of pills, I asked him whether kratom might help with pain. He said it might, so I tried it, and it did. I didn't need anything else. Not only that, but I found that it worked very well to help me focus at work when I returned a couple days later. Being diagnosed with ADD as a kid {a label I do not own, but a brain type I recognize}, I have tendencies that don't make a lot of the task management that comes with my job very easy for me. At the time, I was starting a new business, a cafe, while still managing the growers' market, along with other projects, and a lot was going on. When I got home, I still had to be fully present for my kids and wife, and kratom helped me do that.  In less intense periods of time, I have not had a problem cutting off my use. Kratom is DEFINITELY not addictive like heroin is . . . I can say this with confidence and experience. It's a beautiful plant, that grows abundantly in a region that has been using it for a long time safely. I believe that plants are intelligent medicine. When we start meddling with them and stripping parts of them from their source, we lose something, and we increase the potential for abuse. 
For the tens of thousands {or more?} of people that are addicted to opiates in our country to have the option of an inexpensive plant support for weaning them off a destructive way of life, to veterans with chronic pain that don't want to get caught in the cycle to begin with, to 'regular' people like me, who can use some extra support sometimes, . . . PLEASE, don't make kratom a Schedule 1 substance! The examples of harm being connected to this plant compared to the other substances it would sit next to are negligible. At least give researchers a chance to study its risks and benefits before making such a harsh and swift switch. We have an opportunity with the capabilities of science to suspend our judgement in these matters and let the good data tell us whether something is beneficial for people. In the case of kratom, it seems pretty clear that there is benefit. Let's work together and allow all of the stakeholders to come up with a science and public health based approach that ensures we continue to learn about how to use the plant to its fullest, and keep it available for responsible adults to help take care of themselves with something as mild as kratom. I thank you very much for changing your stance and being willing to hear our voices before making a decision. I certainly hope that with the majority of people in our country now supporting the deregulation of cannabis, we may recognize that criminalizing plants is not the way of the future.
