documents.commentText:
Hello. I am writing to you on behalf of my father, who benefits from kratom. I, myself, have never used kratom but after my mother passed away last September I started looking for a way to help my father improve his life. After extensive research, I found kratom so I sent him a sample. Since then, it has helped him to survive the loss of the woman he loved and took care of for 36 years. Not only did it help him through that loss but he has been able to stop taking Paroxetine, hydrocodone and tramadol for chronic pain and post traumatic stress disorder. You see, he fought in the Vietnam war in 1965-1967 and experienced horrible mental trauma, as well as losing complete sight in his right eye. He has been on Paroxetine for his PTSD but has had trouble getting his prescription filled through the VA in the past year. My mother was always the one to handle those things and no one else in the family seems to be able to get through to the VA and get things accomplished like she did. My dad has told to me how much he hates the way the tramadol and hydrocodone make him feel and kratom has given him a way to stop using those.

Please do not place this remedy into Schedule 1. It hasn't caused my father any harm whatsoever and people worldwide have used it for thousands of years to make life bearable. We all know how horrible our lives can be and I would hate to see something that is so beneficial to those who suffer be banned. If you ban this remedy, the people who use it will lose the thing that has made their life almost normal again. I can't bear to see my father suffer any more than he already has, so please don't take this away from him. It has helped him so much. I feel that continued use of kratom will provide him a better and longer life and losing him so soon after losing my mother isn't something that I or my family can cope with.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Jake Firmin, and I am a 26-year-old former student of University of California, Santa Cruz who now works in a law office in San Francisco. First and foremost I would like to thank you for allowing myself and others who have benefitted from kratom a chance to voice our opinions and concerns regarding the DEAs plans to make the two active compounds mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine schedule one substances. As a kratom user who was diagnosed with ADD at a young age I can attest to the fact that kratom works unlike any of the various prescriptions I have been prescribed to. Going on and off Ritalin and Adderall from a young age, I have always had a love hate relationship to the medications. While I love the fact that both of them can help me concentrate (something I am surely not the best at), I could never stand the agitation they brought upon me, or the ways in which they enhanced my social anxiety, and anxiety in general for that matter. 

	Finding kratom has been a monumental experience in my life because it has provided me with a better and milder means towards achieving a state of enhanced focus without the strong psychoactive effects of prescription ADD/ADHD medications. What I cannot stress enough here is the fact that kratom has never given me a high. I have certainly felt such feelings with Ritalin, Adderall, and even coffee (when I drink way too much), but never kratom. Kratom has enabled me to feel like myself while giving me a boost of ability to remain focused. Throughout the four years I have used kratom it has helped me immensely, first in my studies at college, and now with my work in a law office, and I find the thoughts of a work life without it to be concerning. 

	Since I have brought up the fact that I find kratoms potential unavailability to be worrisome, I must emphasize that I feel this way strictly for the ways in which my abilities in the work place could potentially suffer dramatically. I want to heavily stress the fact that kratom has never caused me to feel addicted in any way, shape, or form. During weekends, when I am not working, I go throughout entire days without even having remote thoughts about it. To find something that has been as beneficial as kratom that does not alter my overall psychological state has truly been remarkable. I am just one of many people in the U.S. that has benefitted from this remarkable and safe plant, and while my story is like many others, I still felt the importance of sharing it with you. My dad who suffers from chronic pain has also benefitted from it, and I am urging him to write to you as well. 

	I will end this letter by thanking you once again for giving the public a chance to voice our opinions, and it is my hope that many others have come forward and shared their own personal experiences with this plant. Please remember that kratom is related to coffee and while it is understandable that it was initially compared to the horrendous array of synthetic drugs that hit our nation in a dramatic wave, such a comparison is totally unjustifiable. This is not bath salts, nor synthetic marijuana, nor any other crazy and dangerous man made chemical. This is a plant that has been used responsibly in our country for years, and in Southeast Asia throughout generations. Im sure you are aware of all this, and I urge you to think of the sociological repercussions of outlawing something that helps so many people abstain from hard drugs such as heroin. Since those are not my experiences I will refrain from elaborating further. I hope that my words are taken into account, and I sincerely hope that you will make the right decision.

Sincerely,

Jacob Firmin

documents.commentText:
Regulating the mitragyna speciosa plant is the equivalent of regulating chamomile and other herbal teas (including traditional green tea, bancha tea, and oolong tea). America's medical researchers need the advantage of exploring the medical value of plants under the current IRB regulations. I've used kratom to make tea for headaches and symptoms associated with hormonal changes during menopause and I can attest to it's efficacy in reducing and eliminating the effects that interfere with working and day-to-day activities. If the kratom tea had not relieved the symptoms of fluctuating hormones, I would have had to seek much stronger prescription drug therapy, at a time when I did not have health insurance coverage. The time and cost savings of non-pharmaceutical treatment, i.e., eating salad to cure obesity, diabetes, high cholesterol, early heart-disease, etc, and the broad-range of potentially life-threatening complications that arise from non-treatment or delayed treatment of easily-remedied disorders give good cause to classifying mitragyna speciosa as a dietary supplement, rather that a Schedule I substance.

People who consume kratom as a dietary supplement (such as St. John's Wort, DHEA, melatonin, etc.) are not likely to continue to use it after their symptoms subside or if they experience unpleasant side-effects. Similar to 1 mg sublingual melatonin (as well as higher mgs of the same), kratom will simply not do anything for folks who don't "need" it. I've not experienced an allergic reaction to it, but I assume that a small percentage of people consuming it for the first time could have allergy symptoms.   Responsible American supplement companies (such as General Nutrition Co. / GNC) would be an excellent choice for measuring and capsulating the supplement.

In the competitive market of cutting-edge medical science, advances in technology are expedited when research opportunities are unhindered by additional regulation on materials. Advancements in communication have allowed Americans to educate themselves on dietary and nutritional uses of vegetables, vitamins, and fish oils, with surprisingly positive results that go undocumented, but which can be gathered by scientists, analyzed for accuracies and discrepancies, and then studied in detail by medical researchers.

I, personally, trust individuals to make educated health choices for themselves and to use dietary supplements, essential oils, and nutritional information from doctors responsibly due to extensive public use of such readily available treatments, to date. I consider kratom to be another tool in the toolbox for self-care.

Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
A SOLUTION, NOT PART OF THE PROBLEM (Addicts will always find some substance to abuse.)
    I was on dr prescribed opiates for 14 years.  I never took them to 'get high'.   Not once.   I took them for chronic pain related to Lyme Disease that went undiagnosed for 5 years before being treated. 
     Enter the New Era of Opiate Phobia. ( "Save an Addict - F*ck a Pain Patient" ...or, as I'm now starting to realize was actually, "Let 'Em All OD- No More Problem").   But that's a whole other issue.
     The very real threat of losing the medication that made it possible for me to get out of bed and actually do things like play with the dog, go visit a friend, etc, put the fear of God into me.  I didn't want to lose this medication 1. because I needed it, and, 2. suddenly, and without any assistance getting off it (as has happened to many).  But I was physically dependent.  
     I attempted to taper over 5 weeks and it was A NIGHTMARE no one should have to go through.  But I was able to end the cycle of physical dependency  (taking opiates whether I needed it for pain or not, just to avoid the withdrawal,)  and just take it when I had a pain flair up.   
     But then there was a long flair up, and I had to take the medication every day for 4 months.  Now I was physically dependent again.  The thought of 5 weeks of horror and the constant fear of losing my necessary medication had me suicidal.  
     Then I read about Kratom.  2 weeks of Red Kratom and I was completely off the opiates.  No nightmare, no horror, just minor discomfort and the need for Imodium.  (and I never 'got high' from it.  Not once.)
      I will have another pain flair up.  I will become dependent on the opiates again.  I'd like to be able to get off them again without a 5 week, life altering nightmare.  
     WHY would you take away a solution to the life destroying nightmare of opiate withdrawal that keeps so many people chained to things like heroin?  You would be doing a disservice to all people in this country that are impacted by the opiate crisis.  KRATOM IS A SOLUTION, NOT PART OF THE PROBLEM.    Please reconsider. 

PS.  Addicts will ALWAYS find something to be addicted to.  Are you going to ban mouthwash, sugar, coffee, beer, blood pressure medication, anti depressants...........?

To whom it may concern,

My name is Travis Clark and I am 29 years old and I work in the Information Technology field. I oppose the DEAs proposal to make the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, two constituents of the Kratom plant, schedule 1 controlled substances.

I first stared using Kratom about a year ago after finding out about it through a friend. I was addicted to Suboxone for about 2 years and successfully detoxed from it "cold turkey" about 2 years ago now. After I stopped Suboxone, I started getting cravings for my drug of choice again, oxycodone. I was also suffering with mental illness and I was self medicating. I was also suicidal at times and was hospitalized for it a few times. Suboxone was not a good option for me and anti-depressants never worked.

When I found Kratom, it was literally a life saver. Instead of getting back on Suboxone I liked the idea of taking something natural. Since I have been using Kratom, it has kept me away from oxycodone. It has also helped more with my depression/anxiety problems than any anti-depressant. If it wasn't for Kratom, I don't know if I would still be here. I probably would have died of an overdose or a suicide. Thanks to Kratom I am not on antidepressants or Suboxone, Methadone anymore but a natural plant. I am happy, sober, and a productive member of society today because of this miracle plant Kratom.

I honestly believe that Kratom does not belong anywhere near a category Schedule 1. Kratom is not synthetic and it has very mild effects with little to no side effects. This needs to be available to the public and to the science community so we can study it. We need to keep this around as a natural option in the midst of the opiate epidemic we have in this country. I think Kratom has the potential to save a lot of lives. I KNOW it saved mine.

Sincerely,
Travis Clark

documents.commentText:
My name is Charles, I am 26 years old, and I am a web designer, small business owner, and full-time caretaker of my two 90 year old grandparents. 

Kratom and its constituents should not be shedule 1. As you know, by definition schedule 1 has no potential medical use. Methamphetamine and Cocaine are schedule 2, meaning they have some potential medical use. To claim that Kratom has NO medical application while Cocaine and Meth have SOME is absolutely ridiculous, and leads me to believe this move to schedule Kratom is not about FACTS. Surely if this was about facts - there is clear factual evidence through thousands of peoples experiences/testimony to show that is has medical value and warrants further research before jumping to such an extreme and senseless conclusion. 

I do believe it has some potential unwanted side effects (if taken in excess) akin to drinking to much coffee (headache) or drinking to much alcohol (nausea). I would not want children under 18 to be able to buy this at the store, but I can say from personal experience that this plant can be used safely by adults with very little chance for misuse/abuse or danger to others.

I first used Kratom about 4 years ago. Since then I have found this plant to improve my quality of life in numerous ways. It helps me sleep, it helps ease my lower back pain, and most importantly Kratom's use does not create a dependency that negatively impacts my ability to be a productive, happy, and healthy human being. I use Kratom as needed, and do not feel any long term withdrawals/cravings.

My grandparents are both allergic to codeine, and have a terrible reaction to other opiate medications such as hydrocodone. They used Kratom 1- 2 times a day 3-4 times a week. It relieves their chronic back pain, while not making them constipated, bloated, or unable to eat. It relieves their mental and emotional stress, and gives them energy to seize the day as two 90 years young senior citizens.

I believe this should be available for adults as any other supplement, and should DEFINITELY NOT be schedule 1.

Thank you, and best regards

I've been taking Kratom for the past approximately 18 months to 2 years. Prior to that I was prescribed tramadol for some pain issues experienced as a result of a broken neck, and for severe RLS. initially, I was incredibly thankful for the tramadol. I could finally sleep at night and could actually relax instead of being restless and in pain but after a few months I started losing energy and experiencing a variety of side effects that were actually deteriorating my health. It got to the point where getting out of bed was an incredible challenge, although I always fought through because I have a family to provide for and take care of. Because I had no energy and total lack of sex drive at 31 I went to see a doctor only to find the my hormone levels had tanked completely, and several other issues were. Whining to creep in to my overall health.

I felt like I needed to find a better solution and after much research I decided to try kratom. It didn't take long to completely eliminate the tramadol and replace it with kratom. I've felt far better without the side effects. I'm now exercising daily and being a more active husband and father to my kids. For me, kratom has been a blessing that I hope is not taken from me. I've never done any type of illegal drugs in my life, I've never even tried alcohol. Taking kratom is certainly not a recreational activity for me. I take it to live the best possible quality of life. 

Thanks so much for taking the time to listen to my story and others. I do realize, that like almost every medication, there is a tolerance issue and therefore it's important to be responsible while taking kratom. That said, I believe it to be far safer than most medications taht are prescribed. And it's certainly far safer than drinking alcohol.  I stopped taking it for a couple of weeks when the initial ban was out in place. It wasn't easy to do but I was able to manage through it, although I had to take gabapentin as a replacement which left me feeling frequently dizzy and foggy. I hope that kratom will remain legal and available for use by adults age 21 or older.

documents.commentText:
My name is Brooke Cooper and I am a 35 year old Talent Acquisition Manager. I have taken Kratom on a regular basis for the past 4 years.  Kratom is a 100% natural supplement made from the leaves of Mitragyna Speciosa, a tree related to the coffee plant. Kratom has helped me cope with an autoimmune disorder that causes severe and chronic pain, chronic fatigue, depression and overall ill health. This disease was previously debilitating but kratom has helped me get back to living a somewhat normal life. I am not just able to work but I have a successful career. I dont think this would be possible without kratom. I would most likely be unable to work and dependent on disability benefits or a burden to my family. Instead of being a burden on others, I am able to contribute to society through work, charity and volunteering. 
Kratom has allowed me to not depend on opiate painkillers to relieve my pain. I fear that I would become addicted to opiates as so many that have chronic pain do.  It saddens me that there is an ever growing opiate epidemic and that so many people die from it when there is a natural alternative. That this natural alternative is possibly being banned is truly heartbreaking. 
Emotions aside, the DEAs move to make kratom a schedule I drug is rushed and baseless. There is not sufficient evidence that kratom is a dangerous drug, scientific evidence nor anecdotal. The studies that the DEA has cited as their reasoning have many flaws. The 15 deaths they attribute to kratom have all involved another substance that could have been to blame. The CDC reported that opiate painkillers kill 46 people a DAY. CDC Director, Thomas Frieden stated When prescriptions [opioids] go up, deaths go up. When they go down, deaths go down. Kratom is a natural alternative to these deadly pharmaceutical opiates. 
I should have a right to make the decision for myself of whether I want to risk my life with opiates or take a natural plant with little to no risk. This is not just about kratom, this is about the right to choose natural healing over pharmaceuticals. 
Thank you for taking the time to read this. I hope that I have swayed you in some way to keep kratom from becoming a schedule I drug.

documents.commentText:
I urge you to end any efforts by the DEA to ban kratom (mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine). Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. Indeed, many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

In the interests of public health, please end the efforts to ban kratom.

documents.commentText:
DEA, 
Nicholas Fox,
Born 2/23/1986 (30 years of age)
At 16 years of age. I started having issues with my back. Through a long and unbearable process, I was diagnosed with Degenerative Disk Disease. Immediately after I was put on a lot of narcotics to help me function in life. At the start I was prescribed Morphine and had my medications jumped around year by year. Oxycodone, hydrocodone, Tramadol. All these opioids began to catch up to me by the time I was 20. I was crushed by toerance issues aka addiction that, was completely sanctioned medications by legitimate doctors. Ended up on Methadone / Norco / Tramadol due to the large tolerance I had developed. Again, all by a legitimate doctor. Methadone worked well for the first couple of years. Yet, the human body adapts to the drugs and tolerance grows. By the time I reached 30 years old. I was so heavily sedated that my body at night had only 7-12 breathes per minute along with a resting heart rate at 25-30 bpm. My nervous system was literally near shutdown every night. Honestly in my opinion, I am lucky to be alive to even write this. During these years I could never keep a job. I barely functioned at all in society. I was lucky to have a wonderful mother to look over me. I was  very ill, not to mention sick of just existing. I began to seek alternative options for help with opioids and came across Kratom. Initially I tried to get off Methadone cold turkey. The withdraw process was just to extreme. I would go a solid week without sleep to start and little to eat, and my chronic pain was excruciating. Along with the myriad of the other classical withdraw symptoms. It just wasn't possible for me to kick even with the determination I had set in my mind. So once I found kratom. I tried it. To my surprise, it not only stopped all withdraw from the opioids. It took my pain to a minimal. After a month of no pills I began feeling human again. I choose to continue with kratom for several reasons. The three major ones were as follows: Pain management completely controlled, No urge to relapse at all, and  taking kratom I am not impaired or sedated. With pills one would be completely in a altered state. This is not the case with kratom. Its absolutely amazing that it carries such medicinal properties yet will not impair you like traditional opiates. Not only that, there is NO RESPIRATORY DEPRESSION (something I know all to well with where i was at). I have a sleep number bed that measures breathing and heart bpm to confirm this (which is also how I knew about the problems i had when on pills along with feeling like i had zero oxygen when i would wake). Since taking kratom my life began to get on track. I went back to work without issue. Stayed employed. I kindled relationships which was/is wonderful. I found my fiance through work and currently have a baby boy on the way come April. My life is finally together and not in shambles. This is in large part due to the ability of kratom to not only get me clean, it stops my chronic pain issues, and all without being impaired. It would be an absolute disgusting act to ban something that not only helps me, but so many others (especially considering associated nervous system depression so common with any other narcotic painkillers). To rip this plant from the hands of the people that constitutionally have the right to choose what they put in they're bodies. This is nonsense. It has no risk factor association. I would know. It would also devastate my life, with a family being built around me. I need to stay working. I need to be right-minded for my fiance and soon to be born son. Do the right thing. My name is Melissa Saunders and I'm a former " junkie", heroin addict, prescription pill addict,basically a garbage can for anything I could get. This plant saved my life
 Instead of methadone or suboxne which to me is a substitute why not promote Kratom instead? I have never experienced a " high" from this nor has anyone I know. It makes no sense to ban this non harmful plant. Too many people are dying from Heroin right now. Other drugs, yes, but the heroin epidemic is terrible. I have been clean since 2003 and never looked back. I beg you to keep this plant legal to help people who are struggling terribly. I have a great job, fianc, home and 2 great dogs. I have a life. documents.commentText:
I am a 60 year old retired Chiropractor. I was diagnosed with a malignant brain tumor 10 years ago. I had a lot of acute pain from brain surgeries and side effects from the shunt and hydrocephalus. I also have arthriris, chronic neck and back pain from a 20 year career that caused a lot of stress on my joints. I was taking prescription pain medicine for the past 10 years. I wanted to stop taking them so over a year ago I Googled "alternatives to pain meds" and found Kratom. After researching it thoroughly, I decided to try it. I've been taking it for the past year and a half. I stopped taking all pain meds and anti depressants. I am no longer in constant chronic pain as a result of the mild pain control the Kratom offers. I do not feel medicated or compromised in any way. Kratom has changed my life. I have more energy, less pain and overall improvement in my sense of well being. As a healthcare provider, I truly believe this plant has many credible beneficial properties to assist those in pain without the dangers of overdosing or becoming compromised or incapacitated like prescription meds can cause. I support the continued legalization of Kratom. I can't imagine having to go back to dangerous opioids ever again! I can't believe I was ever a part of that nightmare. I know there are many more people like me who have experienced positive results. I hope they come forward with their stories of success using Kratom as an alternative pain reliever!

Sincerely,
Mary K. Brittain, DC

documents.commentText:
To whom this may concern,
    I am writing to ask you to reconsider or at least amend to age restrictions with regard to the supplement Kratom. I am a 24 year old recovering opiate addict and Kratom has been a blessing as a supplement to stop the pain from my herniated disk in my neck and also opiate cravings. I overdosed on pain medication in the beginning of the 2015 summer and am thankfully I am still here to even be able to write this. I struggled greatly with overcoming addiction even after rehab, spending my whole summer in an outpatient program, and meetings. A ban of this natural supplement Kratom would literally be sending tens of thousands of people to their grave. I am opposed to this ban and making it a schedule 1 substance is absolutely ludicrous. I have a great psychiatrist who has been practicing over 30 years who is very supportive of me using it and also my chiropractor feels the same way. I asked them why the DEA would do this and both of them said their best guess is it comes down to money. If they are right then just tax Kratom like tobacco and alcohol already are.
 Please do not ban it and instead keep it the same or at least require someone has to be over 18 to purchase it. I finally have my life together and am finishing my bachelor's degree this winter and am expected to start graduate school next fall. Addiction is a disease and anyone in favor of a ban is literally sentencing addicts to death. It is not just people overcoming addiction being affected, but people with chronic pain, anxiety, depression, insomnia, etc. I do not understand how a supplement with no side effects, does not alter ones mind (like prescriptions, alcohol, marijuana), and has positive impacts on an enormous amount of people could be banned. The DEA is supposed to be against illicit drugs but when you ban a natural supplement you are doing the exact opposite and supporting illegal drug use. Thank you for your time and I hope you care about not only saving addicts lives, but also helping others with the many health benefits they use it for. I would love to hear back from someone with a real reason as to why they would even think about banning this supplement.

Sincerely,
Michael Gallo
